review: Creepy!Premise: A journalist is reporting on a murder case that has sparked a media frenzy and a detective investigating that same case – and then it Creepy!Premise: A journalist is reporting on a murder case that has sparked a media frenzy and a detective investigating that same case – and then it twists and turns into a psychologically suspenseful, oh my gosh, did that really happen? – nothing is as it seems – kind of – did it really go there? – story! It begins with this premise that could easily lull readers into a false sense of security – and then pull the rug right out from under us. Because that is exactly how it felt like! It is narrated alternately by two protagonists whose dubious connections to a murder victim make them instantly unreliable guides through this story. And as readers we are in the passenger seat on a twisty journey to find the truth about a local woman’s death. Anna is the journalist. Jack is the detective. They each have connections to each other…And…They also have a connection to the deceased. All these connections should be revealed. But…Are they revealing this to the appropriate bosses? Of course not! So, we as readers, are being led down this twisty road that leads from the scene of the crime to the truth of what happened there…There will be periodic flashbacks. We will learn backstories. Let me just say this…Everyone is a suspect, and everything should be questioned – and all your guesses are probably wrong....more

title: American Sherlock: Murder, Forensics, and the Birth of American CSI
author: Dawson, Kate Winkler*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For anyone who is following my s, you can probably tell that the majority of my s (although I have not counted them or done a percentage bFor anyone who is following my s, you can probably tell that the majority of my s (although I have not counted them or done a percentage breakdown) are mysteries or thrillers. That is my favorite genre. And what really started me down that path, was my love for Sherlock Holmes. So, when I found this book at another Little Free Library, I was instantly intrigued. I couldn’t help but wonder…“You mean, there was a real Sherlock Holmes?”Premise: The author looks at the life of Edward Oscar Heinrich, whose pioneering work in forensic science led him to be dubbed as the American Sherlock of the 1930s. She details some of his most famous cases and methods used to investigate them. He may have established many forensic techniques in his lifetime, but most, more than any, were quite flawed – still, he started something that established modern crime scene investigations. The author writes in a narrative style, drawing the reader in. Her storytelling flow keeps the book easy to read, especially as a non-fiction book. Although, there were times that the style was a bit distracting from the facts of the cases. The cases were the most interesting. This book begins and ends with one of Heinrich’s most famous cases about a man accused of killing his wife. The author takes the reader through the case and his methods. In the end, she leaves it to the reader to determine if the outcome was what it should have been. As readers, we encounter movie stars, priests, and a number of other fascinating cases. As readers, we are introduced to the beginning of forensic techniques that are still used by police today – including detector tests, fingerprint analysis and ballistics – and how they assist in cases. Readers also learn what methods are no longer reliable in forensics, such as handwriting analysis. As one who loves mysteries, and police procedurals, getting an insider view of early forensics fascinated me. Trigger alert: some case details could be off-putting to those who are a bit squeamish. ...more

author: Anderson, Laurie Halse*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was another donation to my Little Free Library Shed. It was actually released in 2008 as part of a special Black History Month program. It was a This was another donation to my Little Free Library Shed. It was actually released in 2008 as part of a special Black History Month program. It was a National Book Award finalist, and it won the Scott O’Dell award for Historical Fiction. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. This story vividly portrays slave life in colonial New York. The author includes rich detail not found in the average history textbook. Issues such as having to suppress feelings, being ill-treated, never owning shoes that don’t pinch, and what it feels like to be branded. Yes, you heard me correctly…branding humans. The story is about teenaged Isabel and her 5-year-old sister Ruth who were under the impression that they would be freed upon the death of their owner. But recent Revolutionary upheavals in distant Boston prevent contact with the lawyer who drew up the will, and the girls are sold to a Loyalist couple, who take them to New York. Isabel is made a half pet, half page for the wife, Mrs. Lockton. While doing her duties, Isabel overhears Lockton’s friends plotting to kill George Washington. She is hoping that if she passes the information on to the Rebels, they may be grateful enough to assist in her freedom. Her information helps to foil the plot, but both sides view slaves as legal property. In her fight to get away, she is branded in the face. Worse yet, Ruth has been sold away from her. How can you not feel something when you read the following:“Melancholy held me hostage, and the bees built a hive of sadness in my soul.”What will become of Isabel? Will she find justice?Will she find her freedom?Will she be reunited with Ruth? Even though this is fiction, it is an absorbing read. The book was written for children/young adults, but any age group can appreciate it. It would make a good book group selection. An appendix at the end of the book gives insights into whether Isabel is based on a true person. And, apparently there is a sequel to Isabel’s story, called Forge which came out in 2010. ...more

author: Itami, Emily

review: I was surprised when I saw this as a donation for my Little Free Library Shed. I had been seeing s, and was curious about it. Then I saw the notI was surprised when I saw this as a donation for my Little Free Library Shed. I had been seeing s, and was curious about it. Then I saw the note in my little notebook that I keep in my LFL that people can write in. It was from a fellow LFL steward I had met on Facebook a while ago who had admired my “shed” and wanted to develop one himself in his town of Santa Cruz, CA. He was visiting my area and decided to drop off a few books, and take a few from my LFL. This was one of them. BTW, one of the books he took was Les Miserables https://www.goodreads.com//show... which I had recently ed here. He gave himself a challenge to read it and finish it by his next visit to town in September! On to my .The first thing that attracted me was the cover of this book. Look to the left of the paragraph. It’s beautiful, right? As I understand it, it is a skyline picture of Tokyo in a deep blue with pink text. There is a feminine, delicate feeling to it. I almost wanted to pick the flowers. Premise: Mizuki seems to have it all. 2 perfect children. Devoted husband. Or is he? As we come to learn, he embodies a traditional sense of the world – so he sees his wife in a stereotypical way – she is his wife/servant. She has no purpose to him, other than to serve him. Which leads her to an affair with restauranteur Kiyoshi. While we explore this facet of Mizuki’s present life, we get a glimpse into her past – her study abroad in the U.S., her living with a rich white family, knowing what life is like outside the boundaries of Japanese society. We learn about her ambitions in her previous life, and how lonely she has become in her current life - her marriage.Morally, we as readers may find ourselves conflicted. We understand her unhappiness and why it would lead her to an affair. But is this the way to address her problems with her marriage? In many ways, this story is a character study. As readers we can look at the situation from a holistic approach. If we were the therapist, what would we be advising the characters to do?Would it have been easier if Kiyoshi and Mizuki’s relationship were platonic and it was just an emotional affair? Or would the fact that it is still happening outside the marriage still make it wrong? This is the author’s debut novel. The writing is beautiful, despite the moral dilemma we are having to read. Definitely a great discussion selection. ...more

title: Answers in the Pages
author: Levithan, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Less than 48 hours ago, this book was donated to my Little Free Library Shed. I was intrigued. Being a short book, I began reading. I didn’t stop. I jLess than 48 hours ago, this book was donated to my Little Free Library Shed. I was intrigued. Being a short book, I began reading. I didn’t stop. I just closed the book, and I am feeling every moment of it. I want to talk about it with you. I would love to hear your thoughts below. Interestingly enough this book is meant for middle-school aged children. Premise: It is an attempt by parents to have the book, “The Adventurers” removed from a fifth-grade curriculum because of the ending sentence in the book, which one of the parents discovers. This sentence reads as follows:“At that moment Rick knew just how deeply he loved Oliver, and Oliver knew just how deeply he loved Rick, and the understanding of this moment would lead them to much of the happiness and adventure that came next.” This is a powerful and realistic book. It portrays the forces that battle to determine and control the novels and topics that some people feel are appropriate for young people to read, as opposed to trusting the wisdom of teachers. Those conflicts have always existed, but this author showcases the debate – between parents, students, the school board, and teacher. And even allows the “author” to bear witness to it all, as well. It exposes the pitfalls of championing a cause based on what is best for “others,” showing that such crusades tend to marginalize whole groups of people in the process. As readers, we see a far-fetched misinterpretation of how a few pages unleashes a town’s misunderstanding about and lack of acceptance of the LGBTQIA+ community. And, like many instances in real life, the young people of this story are the most measured, reasoned, accepting and helpful voices. Young voices should be part of the discussion. Their perspective is relevant. It resonates even more now, because they deserve to have the opportunity to be fully educated and not be denied the opportunity to learn. Mr. Howe (a character in the book), their teacher (who identified as gay), had the opportunity to speak at the school board meeting, and gave a very moving speech during his allotted 3 minutes. “Well. Let me be the first to say it tonight: There is nothing ‘inappropriate’ about being gay… There is nothing sinful about it. There is nothing to be ashamed of. There is nothing about being queer that deserves censorship rather than expression. Nothing. This should not be a matter of debate, because a person’s humanity should never be a matter of debate. Instead, it is a matter of the highest principle we can aspire to, which is equality. …In challenging a book, they (his parents) would have been trying to turn off a tap, when who I am is actually an ocean…But even if you pull all the queer books from our class, even if you could manage to somehow pull all the queer books from this town, I guarantee you, you will not stop us from being who we are. The worst damage you can do is to make the more vulnerable of us feel bad about it. But you cannot hold back the ocean. The ocean will not be contained in such a way.” (Page 146-147)In this book, the kids and teacher won over the town. But in towns across our nation, this is not what we are seeing happening. Books are being banned in such a way that even librarians and teachers have to get parent’s permission for what books can either be put in the libraries or taught in the classrooms. My personal thoughts…As a college educated individual, I also spent many years honing my craft at teaching. Beyond my Master’s degree, I also got a specialized certificate from Harvard University in Program Development to enhance my teaching experiences. I was proud of what I could bring to my classroom. I don’t know if I could ever live under the edicts of a DeSantis or parents suddenly questioning some of the Dr. Suess books, I was using to instill creativity in my students. Let alone the sensitive issues we were discussing from a peer counseling perspective. Books teach. This is a beautiful teaching book. And the message of trusting teachers, is a good one. (Bias intended.)Also…People need to be allowed to be who they are – and we should be allowed to read about them – at any age. So that we can appreciate and understand differences. We need to honor and embrace and accept each other. And the sooner we can do that – the sooner children can learn and grow and love themselves as they are....more

review: This book is a long stay – in the south of France, in the small village of Roussillion. As readers, we are given the opportunity to slow down and savoThis book is a long stay – in the south of France, in the small village of Roussillion. As readers, we are given the opportunity to slow down and savor the pace that life offers.Lisette and her husband Andre, an expert maker of frames, leave Paris to be with her dying father. The pace of country life is difficult to transition to for Lisette, and she misses Paris desperately. Gradually she lightens up when Andre’s grandfather invites her into his stories of the great artists Pissario and Cezanne and the paintings he has been given by them. She begins to study the paintings, appreciate the “sacred light” of the South, and her surroundings. She hopes that this knowledge will serve her when she can return to Paris and work in an art gallery. Then WWII intervenes. And along with it, the Nazis take the paintings. When the war ends, Lisette vows she will find them.The author brings the sights, smells and sounds of country life to vivid reality, along with the emotions of her characters. Especially as they experience the war around them. As readers, we are especially drawn into the beautiful descriptions of the paintings, the capturing of light and shadow, and how well they are presented. Even though it took a while for the story to start for me, I couldn’t help but be engaged by the hope and struggles of what was happening for the characters.We also have hope that Lisette will achieve the goals of her “List of Hungers and Vows.”...more

She was a successful journalist, but she was let go, and she has few job options left. She ends up working in the local bookstore, where her late mother use to take her to read. Eva Meeks, a dear old friend, owner of the local hardware store, falls from the lighthouse, and the Police Chief deems it a suicide. Since this is the same circumstance that happened to Callie’s mother years earlier, she doesn’t believe it was suicide. Something sinister is afoot and Callie is determined to discover what it is. Even as she pursues leads, her complicated emotions have her wondering if she is searching for closure for the teenage girl she used to be, who was scarred by her mother’s death. This is the author’s debut novel. As readers we can view it as a sensitive story of a reporter coming home to face her past, and hopefully lay it to rest. Only concern…Sometimes it felt like Callie was rushing too quickly to judgment, but the author seemed to use those moments to show her protagonist’s fallibility. Could this mean…Perhaps that is a sign that this might be an ongoing series? This might be fun to see another bookseller solving crimes. 3.5 stars. ...more

review: Nora thought her past was behind her. She has moved on, has friends, a business and the love of a wonderful man. But the appearance of Kelly and her sNora thought her past was behind her. She has moved on, has friends, a business and the love of a wonderful man. But the appearance of Kelly and her son tears down the walls she has built around her heart. The child is her ex-husbands, and he is struggling with his mother’s death. Suspects pile up as to who could have killed his mother, Nora's ex-husband’s wife, who happened to be the affair that took her husband from her. More fingers point to Nora as the culprit. The problem is, most likely, Kelly’s son, knows who did it, but he has severe autism, and his only form of communication is through his origami creations. I had a hard time getting into the story. Here are some of the reasons why...I don’t think this is a true stand-alone. It appears that these are reoccurring characters. So, they have a history, and it was hard to follow. The author could have done better in bringing new readers in. There are also a lot of characters, and it was difficult keeping up with all of them. I’m not sure how I felt about a child being involved in a cozy mystery. In some ways, this one is supposed to feel justified, but it seemed a tactic that I wasn’t too comfortable experiencing as a reader. The evidence gathering wasn’t always clear to the reader and the suspects were a bit too easy to spot. The story was straightforward, but a bit slow at times.It might be better for readers to start at Book 1. Still…It didn’t leave the reader hanging, as there was resolution.The one thing I will say I enjoyed the most was the opening line of the story. “I loved this book.” I just wish I could say that it applied to this one. P.S. - I am not going to rate this book. I know I am an outlier about this book. The fact that I have not read the earlier books, I think has put me at a disadvantage for having more insights into the existing characters. ...more

author: Hannah, Sophie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Premise: Shortly before her murder, newlywed Jane receives an anonymous note warning her to be wary of the couple seated at “the table nearest to yourPremise: Shortly before her murder, newlywed Jane receives an anonymous note warning her to be wary of the couple seated at “the table nearest to yours.” This only causes suspicion for her, because the way her table is placed, it is hard to know who this could possibly be. The novel begins months before Jane’s murder – a brutal stabbing is committed in their holiday cottage later that day. Police aren’t getting much help from guests because all the suspects were together dining and are each others alibis. The one suspect who has no alibi, is her new husband, William. But, forensic evidence seems to prove his innocence. The investigation seems stalled until one suspect, William’s ex-wife, Lucy decides to provoke a reaction on the part of the killer. Oh what a web we weave!The novel goes back and forth in time, mixing first person narration from Lucy, William’s ex-wife, with third person accounts of the past. A bit frustrating to follow. Even though it was executed well enough technically, it did not contribute much to the reading experience overall. Lucy comes across as the most complex and sympathetic character. She was given some interesting, harder edges. She is easy to sympathize with while being quite difficult to like, at the same time.Other characters are barely fleshed out – other than maybe Jane prior to her murder. Because of their lack of play in the novel overall, by the time we came to the end of the story, any revelations seemed unimportant, as to what role they may have played. As readers, we need to understand motivations, and this wasn’t fleshed out very well. Which brings me to the book’s solution…All the way through the book I thought there was going to be a twist ending – a magical reveal. The author didn’t go there – but…the actual explanation that is delivered isn’t a satisfying one, either…to this reader. That partly reflects that the killer’s identity, while not the one I presumed, is not a surprise either. The clues presented, just didn’t work for me – and it was a flimsy motivation for murder. Promising but…3.5 stars....more

review: I almost didn’t read this. There were so many mixed s, and I have had so many hit and misses with this author, I was ready to give up. But GoodrI almost didn’t read this. There were so many mixed s, and I have had so many hit and misses with this author, I was ready to give up. But Goodreads went down yesterday and after our walk with the corgis, I sat down and read. Premise: We meet up with Harriet, a conflict-avoidant surgical resident, and Wyn, a quick-witted charmer who dances through life. They share a close group of friends. And every year there is an annual getaway. But this year they have broken up – but they still decide to go, but they aren’t going to tell their friends they have broken up. So, they will just pretend they are together. Sigh. Hallmark Movie been-here-before drama. But…Are we as readers still rooting for them? Do we want this happily ever after? Oh…I wanted to really like this book a lot, I really did. I am a romantic at heart. But because the narrative relied heavily on the tensions of their fake dating and their shared past, the chemistry between them did not have time to mature and develop. And I found myself just so not in to them. Their witty banter just felt out of place. Their slow burn romance did not feel like something that had to be earned, and thus the happily ever after, while satisfying, did not feel as deserved. Sigh.The author uses a non-chronological structure that alternates between the Maine cottage set and present day and flashbacks to Harriet’s past labeling chapters accordingly – i.e., Real Life or Happy Place or Dark Place. It causes the pace of the book to suffer and the chemistry between Harriet and Wyn to be less convincing.Now having said all that – I will say, I enjoyed Harriet’s friends. Henry did a wonderful job of capturing the complicated, chaotic relationships between Cleo and Kimmy. She could have developed the relationship of Parth and Kimmy better. But it was a nice ensemble cast of characters. And…Henry gave us an ending. She always gives us an ending. 3.5 stars ...more

And Senator Townsend is a force to be reckoned with, pulling every string possible to convict Sherise and obscure the truth about his own son. title: Opening Doors to College Success
author: Bergher, Karen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Full Disclosure. This is Me. My one and only book. You won’t find it anywhere, because it is out of print now. It was published in 1992 by Kendall/HunFull Disclosure. This is Me. My one and only book. You won’t find it anywhere, because it is out of print now. It was published in 1992 by Kendall/Hunt Publishing Co.The publisher came to me because they were impressed with the Orientation for New Students program that I established at the college I was teaching at in San Luis Obispo, CA. I had also created a one-day new student orientation program for students and parents that they would attend prior to the semester beginning each fall – called SLO Days, which was very popular. All my notes for the program that I used as part of this program and class that I helped to create, eventually became this book.The book was used in the classes, and taught by several other instructors over a period of several years, before the orientation program was transferred into the counseling division. The purpose of this book was to empower students to make the best possible use of their time at college. The intent was to provide them with a discovery process that involved learning about themselves, the college they were attending and its processes. (After all, even though the book was written to use at my own college, the publisher had intentions of selling it to other colleges, as well.) I always believed that empowerment leads individuals to personal responsibility taking and accountability, moving from an attitude of: “What do I have to do to pass this course?” to “How can I get the best possible education and experience for myself?” The subjects covered in the book included: transition to college; relationships with instructors; library and campus resources; learning styles; study and learning skills; time management; stress management & wellness; problem solving/decision making; assertive behavior; goal setting; values; cultural diversity; and, majors & careers. I also included evaluation and self-assessment tools to help students get a sense of where they were at, and where they would like to go – and to see how far they have come by the end of the experience (semester/book). The idea for the book was simply to help new and returning students adjust to college life. I thoroughly enjoyed this experience of writing, teaching, and experiencing students in this transformative stage of life. Of course, I will rate this a 5-star book. After all, I will be the only one who can! Most of all, thank you for reading my ! ;)...more

This is a fictionalized account of the transport of 100’s of wartime brides from Australia to England aboard a ship filled with 1,000’s of young men Marines. Many of the women have spent very little time with their husbands and almost all are leaving behind the only life they have ever known. The 6-week journey is filled with many emotions. But it is the journey that the novel plays on. The novel focuses on 4 young women who are forced to share a cabin. Though they are very different, they become friends and learn to rely on each other. The challenge of the captain is to keep the men separated from the women. So, you can imagine the antics that take place!Even the ship feels like a character as it limps along before being decommissioned after the war. There is much to appreciate about a historical fiction novel such as this one. Consider the euphoria facing those who married their sweethearts before they went off to war – how little they may have known each other – to how things have changed for both since the war. Or what it might be like to be living independently as a woman and then suddenly with a man. Will they be that wonderful sweetheart they thought they knew and loved and married?Compelling. What will everyone gain in this unknown future? 3.5 stars...more

Although yoI read this one long ago, but it was part of my gift package from my Sister of my heart, Verlie. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Although you can read this as a stand-alone mystery, it is easier if you have read previous novels first, because these are continuing characters who grow over time. Premise: This is a Ruth Galloway mystery set in Little Walsingham, Norfolk. It is a town known for its deep roots in the Catholic past and the subsequent transition to the Church of England. It opens with Cathbad, the druid, and former Catholic, who is housesitting for a friend. When he emerges from the cottage one night, he sees a woman. At first, he believes he has a vision of the Virgin Mary. What he really saw was a young patient from a nearby recovery clinic – now dead – had been murdered. In the meantime, Ruth (a forensic anthropologist) hears from an old university friend, now a woman priest, who is also in Little Walsingham for a theological conference and wants to meet with her. She shares some threatening letters that have been written to her. With the young woman murdered, and Ruth’s friend under threat, Ruth, DCI Harry Nelson and Cathbad, reunite the team to seek the killer who is targeting these women. Griffith’s novels are usually good when they are immersed in lore, legend, ritual and history. And this one fits those categories. This is not a typical police procedural. Instead, you get more of Ruth’s and Harry’s thoughts as they contemplate what is going on and how they are reacting to the information they each are collecting in that moment. As readers, we can appreciate that they both are propelled by wanting to right wrongs and getting justice.Even as slow as the first half of the novel was in getting to the point, the last part of the book with the crime’s resolution makes it worth the read. Comfort. Cozy Read. 3.5 stars...more

He does 3 months in Rikers for the rape before he is released without any explanation, a brutal experience that has changed him. The plot takes readers in two directions. The first is his search for who set him up for the rape and why. He soon discovers through a letter from the woman used for the set-up, confessing to it, and her willingness to make it right. The second is an attempt to vindicate Leonard Compton, a civil rights warrior who is on death row for the murder of 2 policemen. This case is brought to him by a legal aid working for Compton’s attorney, after the disappearance of a key witness. Of course, as is to be expected, these two plot strands seem to coalesce into one. The pace is quick, the action intense, and the resolution is satisfying. But…There are a lot of characters. I am not one to like lots of characters or having to keep lists, or having a character have multiple names. It gets kind of confusing. So, this happened to this reader quite a bit. There will be a liberal use of fists and guns in this story, and a weakness for the ladies that got King set up in the first place. For those who like knowing why author’s name their books the way they do, the answer is within. This is a gritty mystery, but…so much darkness. Elissa Perez is the sheltered daughter of a wealthy sugar baron. Her life takes a fateful turn when she begins a passionate affair with a revolutionary named Pablo.The second is told from Elisa’s granddaughter Marisol’s POV when she travels to Cuba in 2017 to scatter her grandmother’s ashes. While there she experiences the current political climate and meets Luis with his own secrets. Even though it appears to be a romance novel, it seems more focused on pillow talk about Cuban politics from a generational perspective. An ongoing theme of the book is family loyalty and expectations. We also experience the hardships and experiences of leaving and staying in Cuba and/or adjusting to a new country. It is also obvious that the author has some strong passionate views about Castro that are felt through her characters. In this way you can feel the experience and terror of the hold of that government on the people. The author does a wonderful job of painting Havana with its flaws and natural beauty. This was an interesting read with history, and some mystery, and romance. 4.5 stars....more

This story is told through a dual timeline. In the present we have Theo who has bought Boatman’s Cottage on the banks of the Tamar without even seeing it. She moves in after the breakdown of her marriage. The cottage needs lots of TLC. While renovating it, she finds some letters that were dated from a century earlier. Love letters. It is through those letters that we are taken back into the second timeline of the story. This timeline is of Lady Alice, the letter writer. She was sent to the countryside in disgrace after speaking out about women’s suffrage, and Zach, the young gillie on the estate. (A gillie is a young man who attends to someone on the estate.)Theo is fascinated by these letters, and begins her investigation into finding out more about Lady Alice. Theo also has her own secrets, which soon come to light. And of course, there is the setting. Beautiful. Boatman’s Cottage, with ten acres of woodland on the Cornish bank of the Tamar. Chapter 1.But…We have been here before…Girl walking away from her marriage. Has a cottage to renovate. Finds letters. Investigates the past and the history of the cottage. While there is some romance in this story, it also was about giving the characters some space and time to grieve and find a way to move on with their lives. title: Behind Her Eyes
author: Pinborough, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I never would have known about this author or this book, if it weren’t for my Goodreads friend Dan’s  of it. Thank you. I read this over a 24-hoI never would have known about this author or this book, if it weren’t for my Goodreads friend Dan’s  of it. Thank you. I read this over a 24-hour period. My husband, wondered where I disappeared to – well, not really, he knows he can always find me with my nose in a book, somewhere close by! Anyway, this book. Wow! Can I just say, that for a moment? Some books and stories will do that, where you walk in to a novel, and you think you know what is going on, and then, there is a twist, and a turn, and then…What? Did that really happen? You know when they call a book a psychological thriller? Well, this one is. It is engaging. It is unsettling. It is unusual. And yes, you have to suspend disbelief. And if you can, well get your popcorn ready and settle in for a strange read.I am not going to go into the premise because to tell anything of the plot will give away too many spoilers. I will say this though…There are some flaws in this storytelling, because the author withheld a lot before taking us to the ending. Her ending was the equivalent of someone jumping out from behind a door and yelling “surprise!” I remember shaking my head in that moment, and saying to myself… “What? Did that really happen?” (I know you already heard me say this, but now you know why I said it!)I read somewhere that the great mystery writer P.D. James was adamant that readers be allowed to figure out the truth for themselves. She said authors “should be deceptively cunning but fair” in their planting of clues. With her surprise ending, well…how far were we as readers to suspend disbelief? So, for this, I had to cut a star in half. Still, just because of that, I don’t want you to walk away from this book. This is an engaging, intricately plotted, well-constructed, super twisty, page-turner, suspense thriller. And if you aren’t a stickler for realism, this book is quite entertaining. Who doesn’t need a breath of fresh eeriness now and then anyway?Again, I am grateful to Dan for this recommendation. I was ready for a good mystery. And he delivered this one to me. 4.5 stars....more

TI got into this series years ago, and really enjoyed the character of Cliff Janeway. How can you not love the idea of a cop-turned rare book dealer? These series first came out in the 1990’s. So, I guess now they would be considered classic. The good news is that the series was re-released by Scribner in the early 2000’s so that new readers could be introduced to him. And, I was one of those new readers that had that experience. This was my second novel, even though it is the 3rd in the series. You can read it as a stand-alone.This one I found at another Little Free Library. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Before I go into the premise of this story, I want to share a brief comment on the author. I love his writing style. He shows great knowledge of what it seems to be a cop solving murders concerning valuable objects, such as rare books. Yet, on another level, the text and history of the books he is looking for (and the lives of the famous authors that are brought up in the books he is looking for) serve as both clues, red herrings, and solutions…which create creative twists to his stories. I admire the way he does this! Premise: Cliff Janeway has been tasked with finding a lost collection of books by famed explorer Richard Burton (no not the actor). In addition to the mystery of the collection, there is a murder to be solved. The author is brilliant at hiding the clues in plain sight and just waiting for the reader to connect the dots. (It took me a few extra moments!) Wonderful, cozy, page-turning, twisty, mystery....more

title: The Hunting Party
author: Foley, Lucy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have to believe that writing murder mysteries is a hard job. How will the author set up the story, playing fair with the reader without giving too mI have to believe that writing murder mysteries is a hard job. How will the author set up the story, playing fair with the reader without giving too much away – yet do everything possible to keep our attention? I couldn’t help wonder this after finishing this book. This is the author’s debut novel. She tries something different, but it doesn’t quite land right. For me.It boasts a strong sense of place and engaging characters, but the presentation choices really lessen the story’s impact. This was a donation to my Little Free Library Shed a while ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Premise: Just before New Year’s Eve, a group of old university friends decide to go to an estate in the Scottish Highlands for their annual getaway. They arrive at the end of December. Just before a blizzard cuts them off from the outside world. As the weather worsens, so does everybody’s mood. And then…Someone is murdered. Who did it?The plot description makes it sound like a whodunit. It was marketed as a thriller. But is it?The book is told in 5 POV’s. Over 2 time periods. The first 3 perspectives narrating the story is prior to the murder, and the latter two is telling the story in the murder’s immediate aftermath. The central issue with the book is that it goes to great lengths to hold back on the identity of the victim. Even though we are told early on that one of the guests died, Foley keeps the readers in the dark. It isn’t until half way through the book, that we find out the gender of the victim. Why?And in the final two chapters before the end, we find out who it is, but to be honest, by then, I figured out who it was – did you? So, is it really a mystery? There are clues and red herrings – but they don’t work well when you don’t know what mystery you are trying to solve. And the eventual reveal is simply that someone saw the crime committed. Sadly, the suspense only carries the story so far.Am I being too analytical here?The good news…yes, I will give it that…everything comes together in the last 50 pages. But, did we have to wait for it all then? Couldn’t the suspense have been evenly distributed?Mixed emotions about this one. 3.5 stars. ...more

title: I Am Malala: The Girl Who Stood Up for Education and Was Shot by the Taliban
author: Yousafzai, Malala
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was fortunate that I found this book at a library book sale before the pandemic. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. It is now one of the mostI was fortunate that I found this book at a library book sale before the pandemic. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. It is now one of the most popular books in my Little Free Library Shed. On October 9, 2012, at just 15, Malala was shot in the head at point blank range while riding the bus home from school. She fortunately survived. This book shares her extraordinary journey from northern Pakistan to the halls of the United Nations in New York. By the age of 16 she had become a global symbol of peaceful protest, and the youngest-ever Nobel Peace Prize laureate. To consider what she and her family had to endure in the fight against global terrorism, and the right for girls’ education, is such a remarkable story of love and survival. I had been aware of her on the periphery of my own life, especially when she was being mocked by Trump. The audacity of the man, sickened me, considering all that she and her family traversed to fight for the rights of girls and women – and at the time, it seemed like something that would happen only in her country. To see so many rights being challenged here in the United States, happening now, is a travesty. Yet, what is shared in her book, gives us great insights into the type of person she is and the type of ruling circumstances she lived under – and what it takes for people to overcome it. Her story isn’t just about the political and social atmosphere – it also conveys life as a young girl – enjoying friends – thinking about the future – being with family. There is much to appreciate about the openness – honesty – hardships – and challenges she experienced in her young life. And for those reading (experiencing this) in book format, at the back there is a glossary of terms, and important events page on what was happening in Pakistan and Swat from August 14, 1947-July 12,2013 when Malala addressed the UN. In her notes, Malala writes as to why she has developed the Malala Fund https://malala.org.“My goal in writing this book was to raise my voice on behalf of the millions of girls around the world who are being denied the right to go to school and realize their potential. I hope my story will inspire girls to raise their voices and embrace the power within themselves, but my mission does not end there. My mission - our mission, demands that we act decisively to educate girls and empower them to change their lives and communities.” You can’t help but be in awe of her courage. And her continued willingness to support girls around the world. It is nice to know that since this book has been written she has gone on to graduate Oxford University. She is married to Asser Malik, a manager with the Pakistan Cricket Board. Her production company, Extracurricular, has a deal with Apple TV+ for a wide range of film and television projects. Triggers: Be aware there will be violent content in the book as she describes the shooting....more

review: This is a Reese’s Book Club Pick.This isn’t why I picked it. It was actually a donation to my Little Free Library Shed. So, I thought I would read it.This is a Reese’s Book Club Pick.This isn’t why I picked it. It was actually a donation to my Little Free Library Shed. So, I thought I would read it. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.This is a collection of short stories which seem to give attention to the inner lives of women. When we consider or discuss imagination in fiction, we often just mean worldbuilding. This author is set resolutely in the ordinary. She has us in parking lots, or “nice” restaurants, in local gyms and SUVs. Her imagination is not fantastical; it is empathetic. She has a vision that makes us consider that character’s inner life, along with a backstory.And...Women in these stories often have a consuming, vicious resentment of each other, the kind that comes from seeing someone who seems like either a better or a worse version of themselves. But, before each story’s conclusion, these resentments are subverted, and a more complicated and richer version of each woman is revealed. And lots, and lots of feelings. So...You either like them, or you don’t. And maybe that is how you will feel about this collection of stories....more

review: Is this a simple children’s hero story told in the style of a classic fairy tale? I wondered. I first saw it as a story of a mouse who is born differeIs this a simple children’s hero story told in the style of a classic fairy tale? I wondered. I first saw it as a story of a mouse who is born different from “others.” As he grows, he doesn’t develop an interest in typical mouse pursuits and is somewhat spurned by the mouse community. One day he hears music and follows it through the walls to find himself in the princess’ room. He is now hopelessly in love with the princess. When the mouse community hears about this, they condemn him to the dungeon, hoping he will be eaten by rats. (And this is the point I wonder – is this really a children’s story?)As the story progresses, we meet many interesting characters. Despereaux grows in strength and courage. As I mentioned, I wondered if such darkness could make this a children’s read on their own kind of story. But I also felt that about Harry Potter, too. There is a lot of psychological realism here. The actions of characters – they bring up some interesting talking points to address. Would it be better for parents/teachers to address it with kids?Darkness. Light. Good v. not so good. Being different. Class differences. Compassion. Because of those points, it may make a good story to do as a read-together book. What do you think?...more

review: Premise: This story is about two women. Clara Darden and Virginia Clay. First...Clara in 1928 where she is teaching at the Grand Central School of ArtPremise: This story is about two women. Clara Darden and Virginia Clay. First...Clara in 1928 where she is teaching at the Grand Central School of Art at the Grand Central Terminal. She is a talented illustrator, but the Great Depression gets in her way. Second...We find Virginia Clay in 1974. She is recently divorced and working at an information booth at Grand Central Terminal. While there she stumbles upon an abandoned art school and discovers a striking watercolor hidden under the dust. It is her mission to find out who the artist is. The author does a wonderful job of creating out-of-the-box women for their time. Clara is brash, fiery, confident and single-minded. Virginia, who had been a stay-at-home wife and mother, recovering from a mastectomy doesn’t come into her own independence until she embarks on this journey to find the artist. As readers, the POV is from both women.And... The author does a wonderful job of creating distinct voices. The women are complicated, flawed, but intelligent and strong. It is nice to read a story elevating women in this way. And...What a setting for the story! Having never been, and only seeing pictures of this majestic place, I was in awe of the historical significance and relevance of all that it meant – including who Clara’s character was based on. (Yes, there is a real person – read the author’s notes. Including how Grand Central was threatened in the 70’s. Developers actually went to the city to try and reverse the preservation status of the building! For shame!)This is truly a story with a bit of mystery, romance and historical context. If this is what you are needing, consider this your next read....more

Little does she know what is in store for her heart.I thought the premise had potential, but then I realized I have been here before with so many other stories like this, so, I immediately found myself bored. Isabel didn’t really know how to do much of anything other than take care of her own self, so she was a bit dysfunctional when left to her own devices, or being available for her teenage children. Not that I am faulting her for having a career. (I certainly had one. But I was also very engaged with my children’s lives, too.) So, I couldn’t relate to her, very well as she began to try and manage life in this new setting. And for this, I apologize for my lack of empathy for this character. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Premise: 16-year-old Hannie’s part of the story takes place in 1875, 10 years after the Civil War. She works as a sharecropper on the plantation wherePremise: 16-year-old Hannie’s part of the story takes place in 1875, 10 years after the Civil War. She works as a sharecropper on the plantation where she was originally enslaved. She hasn’t seen her family in the last 10 years. She is then on the road with the plantation owner’s 2 teenage daughters from his mistress. During the journey they take shelter in a church with a wall full of newspaper clippings on it. The clippings are called “Lost Friends.” For 50 cents, a person can publish the details of their family member to get a hold of the “seeker” if anyone had information. We also find ourselves in 1980 with the character Benny in Louisiana. She has her first teaching job at a poor high school in a small town. Her students get involved in a research project about their ancestors. Benny is also living on the plantation where Hannie once lived. How will these two stories connect?Did you know that the Lost Friends column actually existed? It was sent to black churches, where the pastor would read the column to the congregation. Some thoughts…Hannie’s story illustrates the trauma of slavery and being separated from her family. But it also illustrates her bravery and strength. (She obviously was based on real people.)Benny’s story showed that people are still struggling with poverty and prejudice, and that there is still an importance of knowing and preserving history. Think about what kinds of decisions are being made in several states regarding what can be taught in the classroom – especially as it relates to black history. There is much to gain from this book. ...more

As her love grows, she becomes closer to her lover’s family, and at the same time, struggles with the realities of life under brutal Kenyan leader Daniel arap Moi. The author has created a naïve protagonist, even with her sophisticated upbringing. She is naïve about travel, safety, love, tribalism, war, and sickness. And as readers, we are thrown in the middle of it all, too. Also, as readers, we get a view of the corruption and violence under President Moi; the unsanitary conditions of the hospital; and military life. Being a short book, it is quick to get through the ugliness – and still give us an inside view of the love story. title: Gilead        (Gilead, #1)
author: Robinson, Marilynne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How can this little book be described? Slim. Spare. Yet exquisite and wonderfully realized. A story the reflects the routines and wonderments of prayeHow can this little book be described? Slim. Spare. Yet exquisite and wonderfully realized. A story the reflects the routines and wonderments of prayer. Like a good sermon, or a passionate meditation. The story takes the form of a letter from 76-year-old John Ames, a 4th generation Congregationalist minister, to his just about 7-year-old son. Ames is suffering from heart disease, and his letter, written in 1956, is a summing up of the past sprinkled with anecdotes and advice and sketches of the present, especially of his son and his wife, and his best friend, also a minister. I won’t go into all that is shared throughout this story. I will just say…it is beautiful, touching, and rich. Very little of the politics of the outside world intrude directly into Ames’s letter to his son, but the events that forge and form the characters – war and the Great Depression especially – are there as a constant backdrop.He writes towards the end to his son, “I have been thinking lately how I have loved my physical life.” How many of us do? Think this. The author has given us much to reflect on in this beautiful love letter of a book....more

title: Ready Player One        (Ready Player One, #1)
author: Cline, Ernest*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read that it took the author 10 years to write this book. He said there were times he felt he would never finish the manuscript, let alone how was hI read that it took the author 10 years to write this book. He said there were times he felt he would never finish the manuscript, let alone how was he going to get it published? And yet, he did. And this book, set in a global online meta-verse called the Oasis, went on to become a bestseller.Then in 2018, Steven Spielberg made it into a movie. This isn’t my kind of book. First the good parts: it is light, crammed with familiar cultural references from the 1980’s that the author reimagines in surprising ways. The bad parts (for me): the prose was clumsy. It is science fiction – futuristic. Not my genre. But, if Steven Spielberg was interested in it, and it was a donation to my Little Free Library Shed, I was willing to give it a try, I said to myself reluctantly. I know, that wasn’t putting myself into this book fairly or wholeheartedly. But I was being realistic about how I felt about the genre. Not my thing. Premise: Teen protagonist Wade Watts is a games fanatic living in a slum town outside Oklahoma City, spending most of his time in a virtual world. The death of James Halliday, the eccentric creator of Oasis, triggers a treasure hunt that revolves around Halliday’s main obsession: 1980s pop culture. Whoever solves a series of puzzles within the game becomes its new billionaire CEO. Of course, Wade enters. Kicking into gear the story – breathless? Nerd? Empowerment? Fantasy? Without sharing spoilers questions do emerge with this kind of a storyline. Can we truly manage this global online meta-verse and hopefully help humanity rebuild the physical world? Or will they become victims of their own success, amassing wealth at the expense of continuing a legacy of helping humans escape reality using VR technology?With all that is going on with technology, and virtual reality, there is a sense of what are we (humans) in for here? What is the author trying to warn us against? This kind of a book definitely makes readers think. So yes, not my genre, but it definitely made me think. ...more

I originally picked it up to fulfill a book-to-movie prompt in one of my 2019 reading challenges with a friend. What about you?I found there to be some genuinely hysterical moments, but mostly felt this was a medium dark read. The author delves deeply into the way Pat’s (our protagonist) mind works. At times it feels uncomfortably specific in detail. But, if I am being realistic, that is what makes this book work. The characterization of Pat’s thoughts and emotions feel exceedingly real. After all, Pat portrays a unique 30-something guy who has just been sprung from “the bad place” by his mom and her legal team. And he is trying hard to reintegrate himself into the world. Now to complicate matters, the author introduces the character Tiffany as Pat’s female friend. Even though Pat is married, we come to learn he is estranged from his wife. Still, he is uncomfortable with Tiffany. She has her own issues. But, it makes for some interesting relationship dynamics.All in all, this is a strong book that tackles some tough issues. It is willing to portray mental health issues openly, but sensitively, as well as family and new relationship dynamics. So, which was better the book or the movie?...more

title: White Fragility: Why It’s So Hard for White People to Talk About Racism
author: DiAngelo, Robin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A couple of years ago, during the height of the pandemic, I attended a Zoom book discussion group on this book over a period of a few weeks. At the tiA couple of years ago, during the height of the pandemic, I attended a Zoom book discussion group on this book over a period of a few weeks. At the time we were discussing it, obviously it was a highly polarized ideological climate in the United States. George Floyd had just been killed and there were many demonstrations that had been taking place around the country. The author, who is white, wrote this book prior to any of these incidents, but she did write it after Trump had become President. Her book laid out how racism is the bedrock of American society and how she believed white Americans are holding it in place. Her term “white fragility” refers to the intense emotions, the defensive stance and the argumentation white people experience, take and utilize when confronted about the topic of racism. She provides many relevant examples which we discussed in our group – such as: A white man insisting that white people are being discriminated against because of affirmative action.Or a woman of color claiming a white woman is speaking over her.Other examples illustrated white fragility at a national level, such as the Black Lives Matter movement being contorted into ‘All Lives Matter’ by white people who feel threatened. Or... The anti-immigration policies of Trump’s administration. Her book skillfully walks readers through many elements of white fragility, as well as providing a history of racism and our assumptions. She shares,“If we cannot discuss these dynamics or see ourselves within them, we cannot stop participating in racism. The good/bad binary made it effectively impossible for the average white person to understand – much less interrupt – racism.” (page 72)The hardest part of the group experience was reflecting on gaining a window into the white supremacist society and movement. She feels we each have a responsibility in dismantling this movement brick-by-brick. Her point…We live in a broken system that holds up white supremacy and racism, and it is our job to work towards fixing it. Educating the populace is one answer. Voting is the other. This was not an easy read. And definitely not an easy discussion. But…we need to start somewhere. If we are going to fix our world....more

review: I had been wanting to read this for the longest time, but I had never been able to get hold of it in book format, until it was donated to my Little FrI had been wanting to read this for the longest time, but I had never been able to get hold of it in book format, until it was donated to my Little Free Library Shed. So, now here it is, and now I am able to bring my  to Goodreads.If there is matchmaking there must be romance. Right? Recently, I was watching a Netflix show called Indian Matchmaking. It was so fascinating to watch how this matchmaker would work with these families to find matches for couples. This truly is a very trusted way of doing it. And now, Netflix has the Jewish Matchmaking show. And this matchmaker works the same way. Interestingly, in this particular show, not one couple matched through the whole season. Why was that? Hmmm….On to the …So, let us say that matchmaking leads to romance. But romance can also create obstacles. And, if there is a beginning matchmaker, there must also be a seasoned matchmaker to instruct the novice. And this is where we begin. With Marnie. She is an inexperienced matchmaker. She thinks she knows what she wants. Marriage to Noah. She thinks she knows herself. She doesn’t. Now, Blix is a veteran matchmaker who also happens to be Noah’s great-aunt. She knows Marnie, too. She knows what Marnie needs. Even though Blix and Marnie are of different generations, they are distinctively connected and share a narrative voice with each chapter heading sharing who is telling the story. This reader, is rooting for both these women.I won’t go into all that happens for these women, because a lot does – and we know that Blix is wise, and Marnie should listen, and she doesn’t – and yet Blix finds a way to still wisely support Marnie. And eventually…(well, no spoilers from me…)The question is…So, in the end who matchmade who well?Cute. Sweet. Compassion. Enchanting. Suspend disbelief. This is the kind of book that makes a reader sad when it is over because the characters have become such dear and treasured friends. And then there is this mantra from the book that just feels perfect to carry wherever we go…Whatever Happens, Love That....more

review: This is a Reese’s Book Club Pick. I really wanted to like this one. But, part of liking a book, is liking its main character, and well, that wasn’t liThis is a Reese’s Book Club Pick. I really wanted to like this one. But, part of liking a book, is liking its main character, and well, that wasn’t likely to happen for me. I am a fan of magical realism. I was so ready for the magic. But this magic was pushing me in directions that just didn’t feel fun.Premise: Cassandra is neurodivergent. The author portrays her as an annoying and anal character. She is dumped by her boyfriend and her job in the same day. Also, her flat mate situation has become untenable. So, let’s just say it is a very bad day for her. And it isn’t looking good for me as a reader, either. Now here is where the magical realism comes in. Through mental effort, Cassandra can travel back along her own timeline and relive her life at any point. Not a long distance – but at least 4 months to possibly save her relationship – her living situation and her career – right? A do-over button. Groundhog Day? And this is where it gets blurry. Living a single day over and over is one thing – redoing it weeks at a time? Too many unanswered questions. First, there is no explanation for her special ability. Second, why arbitrarily only about 4 months?Third, why put readers through this blurriness?Doesn’t time travel alter people’s lives? Why should I care about getting answers as a reader when I don’t even care about the main protagonist? I don’t know. I have been debating this book since I started to read it. Premise: Present-day: Caroline wakes up in a Paris hospital with no memory of her past, she’s confused, and has amnesia. Past: In Nazi-occupied Paris, young widow Celine lives a quiet life with her father, and her daughter, Cosi. Then a ruthless German officer discovers the family’s Jewish ancestry, and decides to blackmail Celine, forcing her to become his mistress in exchange for her family’s safety. Parallel timelines intersect when Caroline discovers Celine’s diary tucked away in a closet in the walls of her apartment while she is recovering. There is much to appreciate about Celine’s story. However, the overall premise about Caroline and even Celine’s story feels like we have been here before. Diaries or letters from the past being found – their stories being revealed. It doesn’t mean that as readers we aren’t broken by the abuse that Celine had to endure at the hands of the German officer, or that kind of story doesn’t feel real when it is read. title: Abide with Me
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a hard book to get in to, and usually I am all in with Strout books. Because I am a big Olive Kitteridge fan. But this one, was tough. But, oThis was a hard book to get in to, and usually I am all in with Strout books. Because I am a big Olive Kitteridge fan. But this one, was tough. But, once I did, it was worth it in the end. There is lots of drama here. Death. Couple of murders. Rumors and gossip. Betrayal. Sex. Marital infidelity. Lots of secrets. But let me be clear. Most all of it happens offstage, and what the reader gets is the aftermath. Decent ordinary people dealing with the aftermath of all of what I just mentioned. This book introduces an intriguing premise. We have a small-town minister who is recently bereaved, raising his eldest daughter on his own. As the reader, we want to know what happened in the past – what happened to the wife? – what will happen in the future? – how will the little girl survive her grief? Tyler, the small-town minister seems such a good man. And Katherine, his daughter, so silent so heartbroken. How will they get through all of this?Eventually, by being patient, (because sometimes it seemed like Strout veered off into passages that didn’t seem to make sense), I began to feel for these characters.My heart was there for the characters. Strout invited me to look closely and think deeply and forgive and be human. Because some of those other characters were truly mean-spirited.And when you get mad at characters, you know you are invested in what is happening within the story. Tyler says, “The question is – how do I live my life? Do I live my life as though it matters? That our relationship to God, to one another, to ourselves – matters.” And Tyler has his opportunity to give his best sermon when it matters, which allows the congregation to become their better selves. One of the things that Strout shares at the end of the book as a note is the following…“Through the telling of stories and the reading of stories, we have a chance to see something about ourselves and others that maybe we knew, but didn’t know we knew. We can wonder for a moment if, for all our separate histories, we are not more alike than different after all.” ...more

review: Intense.This is a story of family, loss and hope. Although this has been “advertised/classified” as a crime fiction novel – and technically there is aIntense.This is a story of family, loss and hope. Although this has been “advertised/classified” as a crime fiction novel – and technically there is a crime that needs to be solved – this isn’t a typical crime fiction novel. The story follows 13-year-old Duchess and Sherriff Walker as they both try to navigate their own difficult lives that occasionally intersect due to Duchess’ mother, Star. The story takes place in a small coastal town in California. The people living here are resistant to change. The story kicks off when Vincent, a man who has been in prison for the last 30 years, returns to town and some unexpected events occur. The story is told from Duchess and the Sherriff’s POV. This is a slow burn of anger, dejection, loss and hope with steady pacing. It was a difficult story to read because of its realness and rawness. I am not going to go into the plot or the story…I will just say this…I could feel those characters deeply. Their pain. Their sadness. Their lives. Keep Kleenex nearby.And even if the ending might seem uplifting, I still felt a sadness at how everything was resolved. It is that kind of feeling where you tell yourself as a reader, “well, maybe that was best considering everything that has happened.” Yet, who am I to really know what was best? I am just the reader! To be honest, I didn’t feel a sense of warm or fuzzy at the end – but, maybe, that was the intent of the author – to once again show the realness of life.This is a truly heartbreaking book that is captivating in its storytelling. review: This story is told in first person by Martha, a woman with an undiagnosed mental health disorder (for most of the book). This is the story of her messThis story is told in first person by Martha, a woman with an undiagnosed mental health disorder (for most of the book). This is the story of her messy life, structured around the breakdown of her marriage – her second one. The book goes back and forth between present day, her courtship with her husband Patrick and her childhood. This also is a story about her sister Ingrid that feels interesting and insightful. Almost as if it were a memoir. Of course, this isn’t a memoir, but the writing style makes it feel as if we were reading about someone’s real life. But going back to the intricacies of the relationship between sister’s it was easy to recognize the intimacy and love between them, as well as the limits of their relationship – especially having a sister. I could feel how real that was to want to be there to support and protect each other. The characters are multi-faceted. Martha’s behavior was erratic. As a reader, I wondered, could I empathize with her, even when her behavior was difficult for those around her? Was I personally giving up on her? And when she finally did get her diagnosis, was I relieved? Or burned out? Where did my sensitivity go? Where is society’s sensitivity to how mental health issues affect those that impact their lives?Martha never seems to live up to her potential, suffers paralyzing hours of depression and behaves erratically. Yet Patrick and her mother are devoted to caring for her. Their love for her is genuine.Still... I felt mentally and emotionally exhausted from this book. If it was meant to be dark humor, it didn’t find that place for me. I found it an interesting study of the human condition. Perhaps a cautiously uplifting book of those who love imperfect people, despite their imperfections. 3.5 stars...more

review: This story is told from 3 POV’s – one American, one Polish, and one German, during and after WWII. In some ways, this story is based partly on a true This story is told from 3 POV’s – one American, one Polish, and one German, during and after WWII. In some ways, this story is based partly on a true story which is shared in the author’s notes. Premise: The story of these women, and what occurred with them as part of Nazi experimentation, and horrendous operations on camp prisoners. Including the rabbits that were also used as part of the experiments. To be honest, this was a difficult read, and I found myself having to skip some of the more difficult parts. Also, there were areas of the book that didn’t seem necessary to include, like Caroline’s social life – it could have been edited more.The ending is heartwarming leaving readers feeling a sense of warmth that humanity can triumph over the worst of mankind. I understand there is a book 2 (Lost Roses) and book 3 (Sunflower Sisters), but I don’t know if I would be interested in continuing a series. This was too much for me. 3.5 stars. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a story about Daniel Boone. Yes, that Daniel Boone, the international frontiersman legend. Here, however, is the fictional Boone who narrates This is a story about Daniel Boone. Yes, that Daniel Boone, the international frontiersman legend. Here, however, is the fictional Boone who narrates the story in hindsight, haunted by his legend, feeling guilt about the price his family pays for his weakness. And more often than not, his few successes come not because of his actions but despite them.Boone has a good PR man, who likes to exaggerate about Boone. So, the legend is born, and Boone becomes an unwitting victim of his own fame, often disappointing himself and those around him. For not meeting up to his own image. The author masterfully creates both a dreamlike world and a fearful fantasy. We get to know her Boone intimately. The cruelty of the 18th century frontier environment is present to readers. But the magic…Hawley’s treatment of Boone’s inner life. This book does an amazing job in creating an interesting view on how Daniel Boone was manufactured and how his myth was perpetuated. ...more

Her mother, Lucy opens the door to a detective who is inquiring about a murder. Lucy is implicated for a murder that occurred in 1942 in Manzanar camp where 10,000 Japanese/Americans were interned following the bombing of Pearl Harbor. Patty is baffled, and knows nothing of her mother’s past. Thus the story goes back in forth between the 2 timelines. Lucy is featured in both timelines, with a second murder halfway through. The book is well plotted and moves at a brisk pace, but there were moments that it dragged a bit. The forced removal and incarceration scenes will leave readers feeling a sense of outrage. The mother-daughter relationships are probably the book’s strength. Some of the historical accuracies are off, but they shouldn’t take away from the fiction story. title: A Line in the Sand
author: Powers, Kevin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is an unexpected page-turner.We first met this author with his PEN/Hemingway prize novel, The Yellow Birds. A few critics considered it an exemplThis is an unexpected page-turner.We first met this author with his PEN/Hemingway prize novel, The Yellow Birds. A few critics considered it an exemplary war novel from the American perspective. I had a few issues with it, but I still felt it was a good story.With this novel, he reconsiders the Iraq War through the eyes of a police procedural. It is edgy, hardboiled and driven by dialogue. He takes us from the swamps of Tidewater, Virginia to the chaotic streets of Mosul. We witness the atrocities of war. We know who loses in conflicts between nations, but who really wins?This story is set in Norfolk in 2009 opening with a body being discovered by Arman Bajalan, a handyman at a local hotel. He had observed two men who had used Arabic terms before leaving the area. He knows these terms because he had served as a translator assigned to American troops engaged in combat back in Mosul 4 years earlier. Arman has many scars from that experience, and not just physical. He lost his wife and son to the horrors of that war. And now being in the middle of this murder investigation doesn’t add to his life. Lots of characters doing bad things in this novel, for a variety of reasons. The book peels away layers of violence, interrogates the corruption, and finds the investigation dependent on technology to survive. Much of this plot is layered, and that makes the author's characters rich in development. But...The author gets political in here, as well. Pointing accusatory fingers. So much is complicated about this, so this part may be a bit uncomfortable for the reader. And...How will this investigation/mystery be solved?...more

title: The Christmas Train
author: Baldacci, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Years ago my husband and I took the Coast Starlight train from San Luis Obispo, CA to Seattle, WA. We read this book together, out loud to each other Years ago my husband and I took the Coast Starlight train from San Luis Obispo, CA to Seattle, WA. We read this book together, out loud to each other as part of our trip. We had our own private cabin, so there was nobody to disturb, and it was rather a romantic reading experience for the two of us. As a side note, if you have never taken this train, I recommend it highly. The coast is beautiful, and the train is one of the most delightful ways of travel. Sitting with different eating partners along the trip is also a joyous part of the traveling experience.Onto the ...Premise: Disillusioned journalist Tom Langdon must get from Washington DC to LA in time for Christmas. Forced to travel by train (too bad he sees it that way), he doesn't know what he is in for on this trip!First, I am not surprised he ran into so many amusing characters. If you have ever travelled down the halls of any train, it is always amazing to see how many people are sitting around dozing, talking, playing games, or into their phones or computers while languishing away the time. Lots and lots of people. And second, as a journalist, I wouldn't be surprised that he would want to start conversations. After all, he wants to know their story. And then he sees Eleanor (Ellie), a woman from his past. And why not have a bit of romance. Of course, my husband and I were all into romance when we were reading it, so we were cheering for Tom and Ellie. To be honest, I picked up this book for two reasons. 1) because it was Baldacci. And I was a fan of his mysteries. I knew it wasn't going to be a mystery (although there is a reveal within this story), but it was Baldacci and I like his writing.And, 2) because my husband and I were taking a train trip, and I thought this would be a perfect book for us to read together. I think I got what I wanted....more

And then that same What happens when a competent labor and delivery nurse is removed from caring for a newborn baby by the white supremacist parents? And then that same baby goes into cardiac arrest and this same nurse is the only one that can save this baby - and that is exactly what she attempts to do - but, the baby dies. What do the parents do? Get her charged with murder. There is no doubt that Picoult is a gifted storyteller. She is Brilliant. Well-researched. This novel tackles race, privilege, prejudice and justice. Her suspenseful control of the courtroom scenes are masterfully done. She seems genuinely best-intentioned when it comes to drawing attention to insidious white privilege and "spreading the conversation" about racism. There are obvious complexities here in the political and social landscape to portray. And it is a delicate tightrope. Does she do it well? That is debatable. title: The Dutch House
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ann Patchett is one of the most popular authors around - at least in my Little Free Library Shed. Because I get a lot of her books as donations, and tAnn Patchett is one of the most popular authors around - at least in my Little Free Library Shed. Because I get a lot of her books as donations, and they go as quickly as they come. She is an interesting author, who in my mind, embodies compassion.How would I describe this tale? Paradise Lost dusted with a sprinkling of Cinderella, The Little Princess and perhaps a bit of Hansel and Gretel thrown in?Two bonded siblings, Maeve and Danny Conroy have only each other after their mother leaves them when they are only 10 and 3. Their home is called the Dutch House, a 1922 mansion outside Philadelphia owned by their father, Cyril, bought fully furnished when Maeve was 5. His wife hated it, and flees to India to support the poor. Her family suffers by this loss, and are left with a father who only cares about his real estate. The lust of it. And then...Enter the wicked stepmother with 2 kids of her own. The story is told in first person from Danny's adult POV. Because Danny is by design a clueless tight-lipped character, as readers we aren't sure he really is the best one to be telling this story. His older sister may have been a more interesting character to have told the story. Or better yet, an unbiased narrator. The story focuses on unconventional families - motherless children, blended families and children left too much to their own devices. Does it work?Still...You can feel the themes of gratitude, compassion and forgiveness and a sentimentality throughout. A sense of warmheartedness, too. It's just hard to find sometimes....more

And then...Disaster strikes, and Dora has to return to her childhood home and take over running Mimi's vintage clothing shop. And now...She is surrounded by all these beautiful dresses. Can she trade her safe life in for something better now?As readers we watch Dora grow from an invisible quiet doormat to a confident young woman with a plan and a vision.
