review: I want to put this out front. I read this before his outburst at the Academy Awards. I don’t know if that is what “you” would call it, but it was not I want to put this out front. I read this before his outburst at the Academy Awards. I don’t know if that is what “you” would call it, but it was not a good look, and I’m not going to debate it here. I just wanted to mention it here, because whatever happened that night has had no influence on how I felt about this book, or the Will Smith writing the book. What happened that evening was a tragedy. I’d like to believe Mr. Smith has learned from that event/experience. On to the …I feel like I have grown up watching Will Smith. And each time I have seen him, whether it was in his sitcom, or movie, or a random interview, I always caught myself in a smile. Even if he was in a serious dramatic role, he had a way of capturing something emotional from me. I couldn’t help but admire him. So, when his book came out, I was interested to read what he had to say. This book for me was entertaining, funny, introspective. Extremely personal. Open. In my mind…Will Smith is charismatic. It comes out through the pages. Mark Hanson co-writes with him. His memoir begins with childhood and continues through to creating his successful legacy. He is open about giving credit to others for how he got to where he is – family – co-stars – mentors – life-long friends. We learn about his music days. Quincy Jones days. Beginning fame. The downfalls of his fame. And his personal growth. We learn that there is more to the name of this book – than the fact that it is his first name. If you are curious about the man, you will enjoy the story. 4.5 stars...more

review: Here is another one I read awhile ago that I am now bringing to Goodreads. Another one that I removed from the thumbs-down shelf. This is the end of tHere is another one I read awhile ago that I am now bringing to Goodreads. Another one that I removed from the thumbs-down shelf. This is the end of the Grant County series. So, if you haven't read #1-5, it is recommended that you do so. The story finds us with Detective Lena Adams in a jail cell suspected of murdering a woman. Chief Jeffrey Tolliver has gotten the call that she has been arrested. Jeffrey's wife, Medical Examiner Sara Linton, has little patience for Lena. (You see why you need book 1-5?) While Sara is fighting her own battles at home, she has little patience for her husband having to fight for his detective. So as Jeffrey and Sara try to save Lena, we can only expect a climax and a final, unforgettable twist to keep us readers engaged! I will say this, Slaughter is a dark and twisty soul writer - she is also gritty. She will take her readers to the darkest places. I wasn't sure I ever wanted to go there, and sometimes I was reminding myself, "don't read this book at night."To be honest, I don't read her books any longer - for this very reason. She is too dark for me. But...This may be your thing...And if it is...Welcome to this series. But,Start at the beginning, and read them in order. ...more

author: Slaughter, Karin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this awhile ago and when I went to look at my notes again, I realized this wasn't a thumbs down book as I had originally shelved. I actually liI read this awhile ago and when I went to look at my notes again, I realized this wasn't a thumbs down book as I had originally shelved. I actually liked it. Anyway this is one of those books I needed to catch up and get my  to Goodreads... so here goes. Slaughter has a unique ability to make you care about the most damaged of characters, creating unlikely heroes who get thrown into the most twisted of circumstances. Her books are without fail dark, disturbing and utterly impossible to forget. Fans of her Grant County books will probably enjoy Will Trent (did you know there is a TV series now?). Those unfamiliar to Slaughter’s work will find this a good place to start before diving in to Slaughter’s serial thrillers. One problem I encountered which tended to strain my suspension of disbelief was the introduction of a reasonably highly-placed investigator with dyslexia, yes, Will Trent. I wondered why she felt this was going to be necessary, and how she was going to play this since she made it such an integral part of the plot. Still, as interesting and deeply flawed as he is, there is much thrown in, in this first book. We meet Georgia Bureau of Investigation Special Agent Will Trent when he is asked to help investigate a murder/rape. We also get some back story on Will in this book which introduces us to character Angie who works as a Vice cop. All in all this could be the beginning of a very interesting series. Hang on to your hat. 3.5 stars....more

Premise of story: a young girlStill catching up with my getting my s to Goodreads. Be forewarned. This one is dark. Chilling. Character-driven. Premise of story: a young girl is abducted and the first death is linked to an even more brutal crime. Will Lena, Sara and Jeffrey uncover the deadly secrets in time...There is no doubt Slaughter has a talent for building suspense. Still, this novel at times felt difficult to like. The horrifying plot was hard to maneuver through for a mystery novel. I am finding that serial killing and sadistic murder seems to hit the best seller lists, but for me, I am finding myself less than motivated to want to read them. There is nothing entertaining about these themes. Maybe the problems for this author is that she goes a little deeper than most into the psychology of the use of abuse of children, making clear the damage it causes. Thus, to read this book, when seeing such pain in others... especially children, well, I believe, it places the reader (in my opinion) in an uncomfortable position. I think the author when doing this...is pushing the boundaries. Maybe it works for some, but I am not that person. 2.5 stars....more

title: Fahrenheit 451
author: Bradbury, Ray
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this classic story years ago and had the wonderful opportunity to discuss it with a few friends. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. WhatI read this classic story years ago and had the wonderful opportunity to discuss it with a few friends. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. What is particularly interesting about this 70 year old story is that it presents as a futuristic American society where books are outlawed and "firemen" burn any that are found. The story is told in third person. It follows protagonist Guy Montag through his routine as a 24th-century fireman. He seems content with his lifestyle, recognizing that burning illegal books is a good thing. This changes when he meets a strange girl who portrays creativity. Why will this be significant to Guy?Bradbury is making us question how we are viewing our world. There is much philosophical significance, especially for the time period in which it was written. However, what is profound about this premise is what we are experiencing 70 years later - today. The banning of books - the presumption of what books should or shouldn't be allowed to be taught in the classroom. Even though Bradbury was published in 1953 (perhaps considering what had occurred during WWII Germany just a few years earlier), there is still much to contemplate about what we have or haven't learned about history continuing to repeat itself. The message of the book is significant. The characters a bit flat. But because it is a classic, it is worth its time and discussion and that is why it gets 3.5 stars....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the story of Pino Lella a normal Italian teenager. Unfortunately, his days of innocence are numbered, because soon his family home will be desThis is the story of Pino Lella a normal Italian teenager. Unfortunately, his days of innocence are numbered, because soon his family home will be destroyed by bombs, and he will be part of an underground railroad helping Jews escape the Nazis. His parents think that if he enlists as a German soldier he will be protected, but once he is injured, he is recruited at 18 to be the personal driver for General Hans Leyers, one of Adolf Hitler’s most important commanders. Now, with the opportunity to spy for the Allies inside the German High Command, Pino endures the horrors of the war and the Nazi occupation by fighting in secret. Pino’s story is closely based on a true story, which makes it even more compelling. As the story progresses into the war years, it becomes more fascinating and action-packed. The author makes us witness to the many atrocities of the war, which are difficult to read at times. But as readers we are pulling for Pino. At the same time, we root for Pino as he experiences the tenderness of romance with Anna, a girl he met while helping with the underground railroad. This is a thought-provoking, emotional story. Heart-wrenching, as well. A well-researched WWII drama. But...Flawed in some ways. The author could have done better. Still... I stayed with it, and appreciated it. ...more

review: I can't say enough how much I love this author. She is a wonderful storyteller. My first experience with her was reading and discussing Bel Canto in oI can't say enough how much I love this author. She is a wonderful storyteller. My first experience with her was reading and discussing Bel Canto in our Library Book Discussion group. She has a way of taking us inside her stories and making us feel as if we are present - a part of what is going on - maybe as an innocent bystander. Mostly I love her because she writes with amazing warmth. She wrote these essays during the pandemic. She said she wrote them as essays as opposed to fiction because of her "fear of death." She says while writing any novel, she considers what would happen to her fictional universe and all her beloved characters if she dies before it is finished. She worries that they would be wiped out too. And just from that sense alone, we feel that this probably would be the greater tragedy. So for her, during this pandemic period, "what was the point of starting (a novel) if I wasn't going to be around to finish?" She felt death had no interest in essays.I won't go into dissecting each essay. Many of them are less than 10 pages long. I just think that if you love her as an author, why not take some time with her musings. ...more

review: This is a big book. With a lot of moving pieces. Meaning that Tom Hanks felt a need to describe everything a little too much. So, I will not go into tThis is a big book. With a lot of moving pieces. Meaning that Tom Hanks felt a need to describe everything a little too much. So, I will not go into that in this . Let me just say, that for me, as much as I love Tom Hanks the actor, and loved his book, Uncommon Type: Some Stories, I had a very difficult time immersing myself in this one. It took a long time to get through the details – the stories on each of the characters he chose to introduce on his way to making the masterpiece movie. And if you are really interested you can download the screenplay by scanning the link at the end of this book. Seriously. I am not kidding. Having said all that, how did I really feel about this book? Let me say this…Tom Hanks has a way with charming banter, inspirational speeches about show business – “the Business of Show” as his characters like to call it – that truly show what he knows intuitively – instinctively. These speeches are usually delivered by an experienced hand to a promising tenderfoot who is new to the business, but nonetheless instinctively gets what it will take to get a movie made. He made me believe that show business can be made up not of attention-desperate moneymen type drama addicts, but of hardworking individuals plucked from obscurity on the basis of their glorious talent for getting it done. There is no way we can’t admire his (Tom Hanks) commitment to moviemaking… one that ignores the corrupt, even ugly parts of the process. I admire his relentless good cheer. I admire his nice guy persona. I just wish it didn’t take so many pages to tell this particular story. I don’t think it was necessary. 3.5 stars....more

title: The Castle on Sunset: Life, Death, Love, Art, and Scandal at Hollywood's Chateau Marmont
author: Levy, Shawn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Chateau Marmont is more than the location of the death of John Belushi. As a non-fiction story sharing all the inside views of how the hotel came The Chateau Marmont is more than the location of the death of John Belushi. As a non-fiction story sharing all the inside views of how the hotel came to be, what happened in its 93-year history…it read like a fiction story. For those of you fascinated by Hollywood history, it’s stars, and others who lived, stayed, breathed or played at Hollywood’s most iconic, storied and scandalous hotel, you will want to read this book. This was an absolutely fascinating and absorbing piece of history! The Sunset Strip is an iconic part of Los Angeles. The Chateau Marmont has been the perfect choice for anyone seeking premium privacy – thus it made sense that it would attract Hollywood types from actors to producers, and later on, rock stars, and those who engaged in all manner of lurid and scandalous activities. So many famous people resided there for months at a time and sometimes longer, while others passed through briefly…making their mark. The author had a monumental task telling the famed hotel’s history which he did quite well. I thought he did an amazing job with familiarizing the reader with all the owners, the staff, and the guests throughout history and managed to recreate the mood, ambience, and atmosphere of each decade and what the hotel meant to the generations of people who passed through its doors. For me, personally, I enjoyed reading about the guests from the thirties through the fifties best of all. The glamour and style of these decades disappeared, never to return. Even so, it was a time when such great innovators and game changers gathered under the same roof, where the party never seemed to end and the creative juices flourished, and it was all done with great style. The scandals were titillating, but much was still left up to the public’s imagination- not like today when there is very little of the myth or mystery left (especially with the onset of social media) which helped create true Hollywood legends. Still one hopes that the Chateau Marmont will survive whatever the next big curve in the road brings, and will remain a steady keeper of secrets for Hollywood’s elite for decades to come… Enjoy a piece of decadent history....more

title: Drowning
author: Newman, T.J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Breathe. Just Breathe. And then...Breathe again. Because this is one book that you will read in one sitting. And you will feel your heart racing, and Breathe. Just Breathe. And then...Breathe again. Because this is one book that you will read in one sitting. And you will feel your heart racing, and you will need to put your Hand Over your heart so that you can help it to stop racing. Because it is that kind of a book. It starts off with the first sentence..."Will Kent opened his eyes just in time to see the engine explode."And that is where we are as readers. On a plane, watching and waiting and anticipating what will happen next. Only we don't have much time to catch our breathe. Ever. Because everything happens quickly. The plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean just off of Hawaii. Captured from the perspectives of various passengers, both pilots and the lead flight attendant, the author takes us from the cockpit to the back seats. And it isn't just the crash. There is more. She gives us a sinking plane with survivors and a rescue operation that includes Chris Kent, Will's ex-wife - the one who was the first line in the book. A few survivors are trapped in a plane under water. Oxygen is running out. Time is running out. Breathe. As a reader, it all felt so real to me. I felt claustrophobic. I felt the emotions of the characters. I felt the tension. The suspense. And if you haven't read this author's first book, Falling. Do that, too. But...My heart is still racing...I need a moment. Hand Over Heart Breathe....more

review: Still playing catch-up bringing my s to Goodreads...here goes with another one. The story begins with a man carrying a little girl into an inn. Still playing catch-up bringing my s to Goodreads...here goes with another one. The story begins with a man carrying a little girl into an inn. She is alive - but...is she really? There are questions about this reality, throughout the book. And who is she? Could she be a kidnapped daughter of a well-off couple that was taken who would rejoice in her return? Or is she the not-exactly-dear daughter of a well--liked local farmer's oldest son, whose reaction to the girl might be considered more ambiguous? And what does the parson's housekeeper who calls the girl by the name of her long-dead sister, have to do with it all? The characters in this novel are...well, colorful. And there are a lot of them. And they all seem to have a lot of secrets, too. But no one, seems to have more secrets than this little girl. Whether you follow this story all the way to its conclusion or drift away partway through will probably depend on two things: how urgently do you want to know who this little girl is, and/or does this story interest you enough to want to care?...more

review: I read this one awhile ago, but I'm now catching up and getting this  to Goodreads. When I first started reading mysteries, I started with the cI read this one awhile ago, but I'm now catching up and getting this  to Goodreads. When I first started reading mysteries, I started with the cozies. I wasn't much for "blood and guts." I think I have since graduated on - having a great love for, well...substance. I like police procedurals. Good discussions. But there is still something to say about the "golden age" of detective fiction. And this is where we begin... 1923. Peter Wimsey is in his first case, which could be considered a good, fun read. He is a tad superficial. He even has a butler! But then again, maybe that has a lot to do with the era. The basic story is Wimsey teams up with his friend Charles to solve the discovery of a murdered naked dead man in a bathtub. I'm not into spoilers, so I'm not going to tell you what happened or who dun-it. But I will share that Sayers as a writer has a depth of intelligence to her. She is witty and she has a way of humanizing her characters. By the end of the novel we have a respect for Lord Peter Wimsey and are eager to follow his character in any future endeavors. A good start to a detective series....more

review: Catching up...Okay, look at the cover of this book? Now, consider the title of this book. Now consider that the series is titled, Mobile Library MysteCatching up...Okay, look at the cover of this book? Now, consider the title of this book. Now consider that the series is titled, Mobile Library Mystery #1. Now…I am a fan of anything books, libraries, and bookstores. So…I was all in. Ready, set, read. This is actually a cozy set in Northern Ireland. It has a quirky, awkward, central character, Israel Armstrong from London, who is a librarian, as the central character. He is offered what he believes will be his dream job to be a librarian in Northern Ireland.Who…Has also decided to be the sleuth along with a cast of other colorful characters. And…It takes place in a small town where everybody knows everybody else. Hmmm…Have we been here before? Now…That we have all the background let’s get to what happens in this story.Armstrong is trying get settled in this new place where the locals are somewhat welcoming and also kind of standoffish. At the same time…He has a case of missing books. You see, he thought he was going to be working at a library, but he actually was given a mobile library – with no books. So, where are the books.Thus…The sleuthing begins. The plot is relatively straightforward. But…Armstrong in his bookishness and bumbling sleuthing, with few social skills or powers of deduction, and his strong ability to offend just about everybody, almost makes it difficult to be a likable character. And yet…We really want him to succeed and find a way to stock that mobile library so that the townspeople will have books to check-out. After all, this is the first in the series, and don’t we want Armstrong to make it to Book #2?And…This is a book about books. 3.5 stars...more

I am disappointed, I was not as enamored of The Last Chance Library, as much.Especially…When this book has library in its title. Premise: June Jones has worked at the public library since she was a teenager. It is her safe and happy place. Her mother use to be in charge, but now after her death, 28-year-old June is a quiet library assistant, still there, quietly tucked away offering support to patrons, rather than leading story times or programs. But…Closure of the library is a possibility. And…The villagers want to do something about it. To be a part of the protest, would be under threat of being fired, but June really wants to help. So…What is she to do?This part of the story was…Charming. With…Some larger-than-life secondary characters. And…A gentle romance. But…Is June going to find her voice? Confront her fears?The good news is… That it is always nice when stories showcase the importance of libraries to communities… And… Community members become champions of their local libraries. But…There were a lot of triggers in this book to wade through – grief, death of a loved one, alcoholism, homelessness, family estrangement, cheating, depression. It was a bit of an overwhelm. I would rather have just stuck with watching June grow into herself. 3.5 stars. ...more

review: At 105, Woody is in a VA center, well aware of the extinction of so much wildlife because of the ever increasing human population taking over their haAt 105, Woody is in a VA center, well aware of the extinction of so much wildlife because of the ever increasing human population taking over their habitat. This includes the beloved giraffes that were very much a part of an earlier life experience for him. He decides that before he dies he wants to make sure to write down in a journal his memory of an eventful trip he took many, many decades ago during the Great Depression. And this is that story. A wonderful, bittersweet coming-of-age novel designed to celebrate hope in what sometimes feels like a hopeless world. The first female zoo director for the San Diego Zoo happens to procure two giraffes and a rhino from Africa. This is the story of how the two giraffes survived the transport via ship and now surviving the quarantine in New York, must now make the trek all the way to California. And of course, this is Woody's story, too, because he happens to hop-a-long to be one of their caregivers. It doesn't matter that he doesn't have any experience. This novel is beautifully written. It has intrigue, guilt, desperation redemption, giraffes, caring humans, and a story to love....more

title: Stamped: Racism, Antiracism, and You
author: Reynolds, Jason
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…I was invited to one of our Zoom library programs during the height of the pandemic to listen to the authors discuss this book/their book.Catching Up…I was invited to one of our Zoom library programs during the height of the pandemic to listen to the authors discuss this book/their book. It seemed like the perfect time, while people were still feeling raw after everything that occurred relative to George Floyd. First, let me talk about the book. On some levels it is attempting to teach about the history of race in America. On other levels it is offering to teach about critical thinking – as in presenting history as a set of ideas about race through the lives and work of historical figures. (Even though the authors insist this is not a history book.) So…It has educational value.It also intends on spreading positive messages on how people communicate and support one another, by how they come to understand differences. This book was written for adults, even though it is a middle-grade version. It frames African-American history as a history of competing ideas: 1)	Haters – segregationists believe Black people are different from and inferior to White people and preach separation of the races. 2)	Cowards – assimilationists believe Black people are damaged, whether through external or internal causes, and focus on how they can win the approval of Whites. 3)	Antiracists believe there is nothing wrong with Black people and focus on dismantling systems of racism. It also charts historical and contemporary events involving violence, including lynching, police brutality, assassinations, rape, and the killing of Emmett Till. There was much to read between the pages, but, if it wanted to engage young readers, I think it missed its best opportunity. How to engage them in talking directly with one another. I guess I wanted more on how to better open the lines of communication with each other. And not so much on the negative side of history. Not that knowing this isn’t important to point out. In discussing the experience with listening to the authors, it was fascinating and gripping and provocative and inspiring. The book is a beginning for understanding. Opening doors. But…We still have a long way to go as a society....more

review: Time to bring this  to Goodreads.A week before she left for college, Maya's best friend Aubrey dropped dead. Maya buried her feelings about it iTime to bring this  to Goodreads.A week before she left for college, Maya's best friend Aubrey dropped dead. Maya buried her feelings about it in a haze of alcohol and drugs. 7 years later a video reveals a similar death while a woman is sitting with the same man - Maya's ex-boyfriend, Frank. Maya is alarmed. She tried to get people to believe that Frank had harmed Aubrey, but no-one believed her then. How can she convince people that he did this again? And who knows what he may have done in the previous 7 years? The problem is, who is going to believe Maya with her current addiction problems? So what is the problem, Karen? (That's me.) The plot flips back and forth between time periods which disrupted the flow and adversely affected the pace of the story. The main heroine, was untrustworthy and weak. Towards the last part of the book, when readers really needed things to come together, things just seemed to fizzle with no real climax. Was memory being manipulated, or were we - the readers? Did they ever really tell us how the two young women really died? Were their deaths natural? Did other readers feel like there was closure at the end, or did readers feel that it was kind of an abrupt ending? I don't know...I don't like having questions when I'm done with a book like this. Thoughts anyone?...more

title: East of Eden
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Read years ago, this  is now being made available for Goodreads.Was it the 5 stars that gave away my feelings? This novel follows the destinies Read years ago, this  is now being made available for Goodreads.Was it the 5 stars that gave away my feelings? This novel follows the destinies of two families - the Trasks and Hamiltons - whose generations sound hopelessly biblical. Steinbeck is a visual writer. I am a visual learner. Already we have a connection. Setting is important to a Steinbeck novel. This setting is the first thing we experience in this novel. The way he describes the Salinas Valley of the time, makes it sound like Paradise. I find myself enchanted. Even though I am a beach girl, through and through, his descriptions of the valley are mesmerizing. This is truly a human story. Steinbeck shares... "We have only one story. All novels, all poetry, are built on the never-ending contest in ourselves of good and evil." Cain and Abel. The re-telling of that bible story. But he also creates characters that resonate with us. One actually based on his own grandfather - the character of Samuel Hamilton (his grandfather actually being born in Salinas). Mostly this is truly a literary story because it is so good. It is thrilling and suspenseful, funny and heartbreaking. It is full of great characters that you care for and sometimes fear for them, as well. You can see what horrible things are awaiting them, and want to warn them, because you are so invested in their well-being. Sometimes you might even recognize yourself in their strengths...and weaknesses. When you are this close to a book - you know, this one is the one that stays with you. And when you close the pages at the end, you can't help but notice... this book, it is still with you. What do we call this book - East of Eden? A masterpiece. Am I wrong?...more

review: I originally read this book and posted a  of it to my Facebook page in 2019. My cousin recommended this book to us (my cousins group), and so I I originally read this book and posted a  of it to my Facebook page in 2019. My cousin recommended this book to us (my cousins group), and so I decided to add it to my political reading list. I am glad I did. A short, compelling read, (written and) published at a time when its message is incredibly important.He shares that the enemies of the common good range from the slumlords to megabanks and untrammeled hedge funds. He feels that these "enemies" all disregard the rules of society for selfish gains. Reich stresses the importance of the truth; and, he proceeds to point out the problems caused by lies.He presents a few reassuring words and suggestions on what we must do to restore Americans' faith in the common good which includes a model built on the ideal of truth and equitable competition, not the ideal of individualism without rules or constraints. Consider what Reich shares here: “If we are losing our national identity, it is not because we come in more colors or speak more languages than before. It is because we are losing our sense of common good…We have never been a perfect union. Our finest moments have been when we sought to become more perfect than we had been.” A superb and quick read recommended for everyone’s reading list. ...more

review: Catching Up…This donation to my Little Free Library Shed reminded me again that I am long overdue in posting my  to Goodreads. So here it is. WeCatching Up…This donation to my Little Free Library Shed reminded me again that I am long overdue in posting my  to Goodreads. So here it is. Well. Let me share what I was excited about first. The title of the book. And the book cover. And the premise for the story. Okay we have 3 potentially positive possibilities going for this book. Who wouldn’t get jazzy about a bookshop in Paris? Look at the Eiffel Tower on this book cover? Sounds dreamy, right?The premise was that bookshop owner, Sarah was going to do a 6-month job exchange with Parisian friend, Sophie and run her bookshop in Paris. How fun, right? And, Sarah thought her boyfriend Ridge would be all excited to come along for the ride, too! (He didn’t.)So, what’s my problem, then?Well. Okay, don’t get me wrong. I love stories about books and bookstores. And I love stories about love and romance…that works. But I was really getting very annoyed at the romance/ ‘happily ever after’ aspect of the story. Especially when the boyfriend kept saying he would come and he didn’t come/sort of, barely showed up. Still there are more redeeming qualities to the story.I did love the way that Sarah explored Paris and the way she chose to make things work in Paris and at the bookstore when everyone was working against her. She made it an adventure – she wandered – she stood up for herself – she explored. That part of the story worked for me. The wrap up ending did not. “Distance made everything that much sweeter. I missed him, and he missed me. I was falling into the abyss of messy, manic love. And it was divine.”Blech. Ugh. Seriously? Is that what it takes?So, what does this mean for the overall story? Romance fails in my eyes, even with a HEA trope. If you understand me, thank you. ...more

This story explored different faiths, love, happiness, and acceptance which made a compelling story. Now... This book may not be for everyone. But... For me, I was drawn in from the start. (Obviously!) This story had moments of clarity and insight. There were moments of pain. But... Above all else, if you stripped away all of the "extra verbiage and unique cultural nuances", it was a story about how we in community can either be generous and loving or hypocritical and cruel or actually a combination of all of the above. Which is universal.It was not perfect for me but it had a definite perspective and was willing to go all-in with it. If you are willing, there is much to learn. For me... It made me think, analyze, be retrospective and appreciative. Any book that encourages all of those actions, is a positive one for me. ...more

review: This is a memoir in essays. They are the authors observations about her life. At home. At work. Her creative life. It shows the conflicting pressures This is a memoir in essays. They are the authors observations about her life. At home. At work. Her creative life. It shows the conflicting pressures of modern womanhood with a heart. She shows us that identity crises don't just happen at midlife; that they can be normal - can happen at any time. Most importantly, she has a strong message that if one isn't satisfied with their life, they can find things to do to change it. Like take a hike to somewhere different. I recommend this to any woman who is running on empty and needs to know...they are not alone. And... you can always start over, if you don't like where you are going. (P.S. - men can appreciate this book, as well. - There is a lot to gain from this woman's POV.)...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the eighth Chief Inspector Gamache novel. However, new readers may find this book a good volume to enter the series because of its unique settThis is the eighth Chief Inspector Gamache novel. However, new readers may find this book a good volume to enter the series because of its unique setting and independence from Penny’s typical characters that reoccur in her novels. The book stands alone. However, as a trusted Goodreads friend reminds me, because of the character development throughout, it is probably better to start from the beginning. Still...it is up to you, how you choose to get in to this series. Just know...you have been appropriately advised!This story has him investigating the murder of a monk at a monastery. But interwoven through the murder investigation are deeper, darker and more personal mysteries. Penny focuses a lot on interpersonal relationships. As you get to know her characters, you begin to understand this about her. Penny has done her research, and weaves a captivating tale that reaches the very heart of what makes us human: music. Through her storytelling, we feel the essence of the existence of these monks’ music and it helps to bring the novel to life. There is a sense of richness and beauty to what we read – and it becomes difficult to put this book down – not just because we want to know what is going to happen with the investigation, but also because we are listening to the music, in our own way, as readers....more

review: This story is told in two timelines. Present day - 2020 and 1791. Present day Caroline is investigating the unsolved apothecary murders after discoverThis story is told in two timelines. Present day - 2020 and 1791. Present day Caroline is investigating the unsolved apothecary murders after discovering a vial that's related to the apothecary on a mudlarking expedition in London. The 1791 storyline details how the (lost) apothecary became linked to the murders in question. Nella (1791) creates poisons for women who are being threatened by men. She felt it was her way of protecting the women who had nowhere to turn. A significant part of this story as it twists through the lives of these two women and the disappointments they have in their own personal relationships, is how it reflects on the implications of committing murder. Even when it is done to protect those who cannot protect themselves and have no recourse in the law, is it right? Is it justice? How does it weigh on the reader? How does it weigh on the characters souls? I am curious how readers felt about the ending. No need to give it away. Just how did you feel? Were you satisfied? I'm not sure I was. 3.5 stars....more

title: Dolly Parton, Songteller: My Life in Lyrics
author: Parton, Dolly
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…I read this coffee table book in April 2023, and thought I had already written and posted my …But…I was mistaken. So…I checked it ouCatching up…I read this coffee table book in April 2023, and thought I had already written and posted my …But…I was mistaken. So…I checked it out from the library again, to revisit her-story. Which…Became even more relevant to me after having the opportunity to have read her book, “Between the Seams.” Review here: https://www.goodreads.com//show... Dolly Parton has written over 3,000 songs, with approximately 450 of them being sung and recorded by other people.“I am a singer, an entertainer, and a businesswoman. But if I had to choose just one thing to be, I would choose to be a songwriter...Everything I am starts with that song. No matter who you are as an artist, if you don’t have a great song, you’re not going anywhere.”The beauty of this book is that we now get all the stories behind her music, besides the lyrics. Still…If you have seen her on stage, she usually has a little story before she begins singing each of her songs…But…This book gives not only details but pictures, as well. Which makes this book a beautiful artful musical story of her life.And…I bet all of us have some favorite songs of hers, that we still hum in our heads. For me…I love 9 to 5, Jolene, Coat of Many Colors and I Will Always Love You…Which…To be honest, I didn’t realize ‘I Will Always Love You’ was her song…Especially…Since my first time hearing it was in a movie theatre years ago watching “The Bodyguard” and listening to Whitney Houston belt it out. Of course…Now that I have seen a variety of Dolly Parton shows on Netflix, I have come to recognize her as the original songwriter/artist. And…Her rendition of it is uniquely appealing. Mostly…I love the complicated reasons (shared in this book) behind the song that make it such a powerful one.One more thing…About ‘I Will Always Love You,’…Did you know that it was also re-recorded for the soundtrack of her 1982 movie with Burt Reynolds, for “The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas?” That was 10 years before Kevin Costner’s movie, “The Bodyguard.” Anyway…This book gives us the songs and their stories divided into 3 key areas: song lyrics, archival photos and written passages that feature her retelling of various events.  And…She shares the telling of these events in such a folksy way. Along…With grace and humor. Especially…When she combats insults by beating people to the punchline. (We know which body parts of hers have gotten the most attention.) And…One of her most famous comeback lines has been…“It costs a lot of money to look this cheap.” Still…Regardless of all the attention to her physical anatomy or over-the-top, flamboyant costumes and plentiful iconic wigs, we are interested in her. From…Her impoverished childhood in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee, to her subsequent move to Nashville to make her fortune. Along with the tumultuous 1980’s that created many challenges for her that sometimes caused depression.This story…Her-story gives us Dolly in all her down-home warmth and goodness. Where…She hasn’t forgotten her roots or her community…Because…We relate to her songwriting…And…It is her authenticity that makes her fans continue to appreciate her. One last note…Carl Dean, her husband is real. Pictures and wonderful words of love for him, are included by Dolly. We also learn about the songs he inspired in her. And…For Dolly fans, and those just curious, this is a beautiful book. ...more

title: The Library Book
author: Orlean, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. How can a lover of books resist a book about books?  “All the things that are wrong in the world seem conqueI am now bringing my  to Goodreads. How can a lover of books resist a book about books?  “All the things that are wrong in the world seem conquered by a library’s simple unspoken promise: Here is my story, please listen; here I am, please tell me your story.”For many people, I imagine libraries are like places of worship - everyone is made to feel welcome and part of a greater community. I certainly have felt this way about our local Library.A library, is not only a community of readers, but also of people looking for help, or someone to answer their questions, teens wanting a safe place to hang out, adults taking free classes, book discussion groups, children’s reading hours and programs. . . the list is endless. Our community libraries fulfill many roles. If you haven’t hung out in one long enough, please do so. You will be pleased with the results. Back to this …The Library Book is centered around the biggest fire to ever hit a library.It happened on April 29, 1986 at the Los Angeles Public Library. But along with learning what happened that day and the investigation afterward, Susan Orlean has chosen to use this book to give us facts about reading, libraries and books.I was a bit disappointed that the story took such a meandering path around the actual fire and crime. Especially with me being such a fan of mysteries. I’m one that wants to delve into the mystery - dig deep into what happened and gain more insights into what actually happened on that fateful day. Yes, she does provide some background by sifting through some newspapers stories and investigators' reports, but it seemed to get lost within the pages, as other stories were unfolding, too. Still...I also began to appreciate just how much the author put into this book to cover so much other information. To remind people about how important libraries are to their communities. In this way, the author was the perfect saleswoman. For that she gets an extra star. ...more

review: I read this a while ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I want to say I am typically a fan of Barbara O'Neal, but this one didn't work for mI read this a while ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I want to say I am typically a fan of Barbara O'Neal, but this one didn't work for me. This was, in my opinion a soap opera melodrama mess. The narrative bounced around between the melodrama and quiet introspection, and it really just never balanced out. It starts out with sommelier/vinter Maya chopping open casks of wine as an act of rage, an accident among many spurred by her alcoholism. Already, I am not sure I like her. Off to rehab she goes. Then her celebrity chef Dad, Augustus dies unexpectedly. Moving on...Maya continues to struggle with her sobriety and several unplanned twists in her personal life. Then there is Meadow who is in her own whirlpool of grief. Meadow actually had been Augustus partner in creating the restaurant that brought the fame. She's Augustus' second ex-wife, Maya's mother being the first. I should have left the story at this point. Are you following this soap opera mess? Not yet. How about... did I tell you about Norah, Augustus' current girlfriend? Don't care? Good. Neither do I. Anyway, there are more characters, and to be honest, I started getting a headache, trying to keep track of their drama. The Book suffered from info dumping, too many characters with too many problems. Too much was centered on Augustus who seemed like a cad. Everyone was stuck in a past, and grief over this cad. Honestly, the book needed to be more than grief over this one man. My solution: Move on. Find another book to read. I did. 1.5 stars. ...more

review: Sometimes I am in the mood for a good romance. As long as it is not obvious. The storyline, I mean. I am just asking that the author be creative. I reSometimes I am in the mood for a good romance. As long as it is not obvious. The storyline, I mean. I am just asking that the author be creative. I really want them to think outside the box. I have read enough Colleen Hoover that sometimes I am hearing the word "formulaic" in my ear, and that isn't good when I start to feel that happening to me.I look for a story that gives me quality of narration, character arcs, plot, twists, world building. Am I asking too much? With romances, I just think it matters. I like to believe with romance, that either a story gives me butterflies or it doesn't. Like falling in love. Or frog vs prince charming. So here is The Flatshare. After a really bad breakup, Tiffy is practically on the street. She needs a cheap flat, fast. Leon needs more cash than he can earn by working night shifts as a palliative care nurse. He has a one-bed flat that is empty at nights, and he has this big idea. Since Tiffy works days, and Leon works nights, why not share the apartment (and bed) - simple right? So even though they never meet, they soon grow more familiar with each other than two virtual strangers ever should or could. How did I feel about this premise? How many of you have fallen in love via post-it-notes? Well...the premise was cute...but...was it romantic? I think it was cute. I don't think I can really tell you much more without spoiling the story. It's just there was a moment where the book had certain (implied) promises. And then it started taking some unexpected turns, and well, it just felt uncomfortable for me. I guess I was hoping for more light and fluffy. So maybe it was my problem with expectations? But for the most part, it still was cute. 3.5 stars....more

title: The Complete Stories
author: O'Connor, Flannery
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…I have to admit when this was dropped off as a donation, I was immediately taken in by the book cover. I was then embarrassed. I knew the Catching up…I have to admit when this was dropped off as a donation, I was immediately taken in by the book cover. I was then embarrassed. I knew the author’s name… But I knew so little else about her. Who was she? When I looked her up on Wikipedia I was surprised to learn that she had only written two novels. But…Also, 31 short stories. Perhaps because she died at 39 years old.And…After reading this collection of short stories, I was not surprised by the description of her style…“She was a Southern writer who often wrote in a sardonic Southern Gothic style and relied heavily on regional settings and grotesque characters, often in violent situations.”Yes.When I picked up the book, there was a note inside. The note said…“Summer – I started to read Flannery O’Connor when I was in college and just love her. I suggest starting out with ‘Revelation.’ Talk about a wake-up call!!! Another good one is ‘A Good Man is Hard to Find.’ Enjoy – Torrey.” Well…Torrey, I don’t know how Summer felt, because the book ended up as a donation in my Little Free Library Shed. So…I started to read, the stories in the order you suggested. And…Yes…What a wake-up call, indeed! In this collection, 12 had not been read prior to this publication. This was also published 7 years after her death. What I came to discover as I read her, is that she put human style out in front: hard, straight, incomplete, sin – all its ugliness taking physical form. She was relentless and unsparing. And…Certainly, in that time and era…There was no political correctness to her. She didn’t care what was coming out of her characters mouth, it was just going to be said. The thoughts could be cold and heartless, too. But…They described the truth of how she saw it. And…How people truly behaved…And…Felt. They were just being…Themselves. In their stupidity, their meanness, their puzzlement, their Southern “ruralness.” And…As the reader, we could recognize this in the characters. We are not shocked by their attitudes or behaviors. We just know this instinctively as their nature, their life. Because the author through her writing reveals an uncanny grasp of the nuances of human behavior. Her descriptions of human faces and human bodies, are so apt, you felt as if you were in the room with them. But…At the same time, you didn’t want to be noticed, for fear one of the characters might include you in the story, too. It was said that her illness, lupus, which took her father’s life as well, influenced her writings. She suffered with it for 12 years before dying at such a young age in 1964. She was…A complicated person with an unapologetic writing style.This truly is a stunning and compelling collection of stories....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Now bringing my  to Goodreads.Premise: Alice marries handsome American Bennett hoping to escape her stifling life in England. But small-town KenNow bringing my  to Goodreads.Premise: Alice marries handsome American Bennett hoping to escape her stifling life in England. But small-town Kentucky quickly proves equally claustrophobic. Especially with her overbearing father-in-law. So when she has the opportunity to deliver books for Eleanor Roosevelt's new traveling library, Alice signs on. This is actually based on a true story.Triggers: abuse, incest, accused murder, misogyny. To be honest, I am not a real fan of this author. But, I am a fan of Eleanor Roosevelt. So, I was interested in this story, because of her. The part I loved about this story - is that it was a love story to literature - and books and the bonds of female friendship. The progressive women characters in this story were amazing. Inspiring. In many ways they were ahead of their time. The hard part of the story for me were the triggers I mentioned earlier. It is hard to read stories with that kind of focus. I wonder sometimes if it is really necessary. There was also some controversy with this book in 2019 by author Kim Michele Richardson to her book, The Book Woman of Troublesome Creek. She felt there were too many similarities. The publisher totally defended Moyes story. Both stories were evaluated and no further course of action was taken against the author Moyes.Readers, can always choose to read both books. I have ed both. 3.5 stars...more

review: I read this awhile ago and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Premise: 1982. New Years Eve. Oona has her whole life before her. At midnight she I read this awhile ago and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Premise: 1982. New Years Eve. Oona has her whole life before her. At midnight she will turn 19. What will she do with her life? Go to London and study economics or remain at home in Brooklyn to pursue her passion for music and be with her boyfriend? What does she do? She faints and wakes up 32 years in the future. She is now 51, greeted by a friendly stranger in a beautiful house that is hers. She learns that each year she will leap into another age at random. And so begins the story.This is a time traveling story that is quirky, unexplainable, that does nothing for any threads in the black holes out there - so just suspend disbelief and go with it. If anything the premise makes one think. What if we all had this magical opportunity to change our future or avoid painful moments, or ... wait, would that mean we could miss out on some special, memorable moments, too? But, wouldn't I want to miss out on getting my heart broken for the 16th time? Wait. Life is for living, and really, we are in it to live it. But Oona, that is a different story. Oona doesn't spoil things for herself. There is a big aha! that comes...did you see it coming? Even the author's characters were incredibly real. I really wanted them to live their best lives. The story, different, but heartwarming, creative, sweet. Out of the box. I was in the right mood to receive it. ...more

review: I read this awhile ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Is this really good? I put it on my good shelf, but I am not so sure. I am rethiI read this awhile ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Is this really good? I put it on my good shelf, but I am not so sure. I am rethinking this, as I write this . Premise: Two missing girls. One who disappeared 10 years ago. One who went missing a few weeks ago. Then, we are transported back two weeks before that date to right after the second disappearance to slowly piece the puzzle back together, day by day. The problem is the story is told backwards. When we begin, the protagonist Nicolette presumably knows the answers to the mystery, yet she doesn't tell us, the readers what she thinks about it. The intention, probably, is to create suspense. But for me, it only created frustration. The book is told in first person narrative, yet, we aren't being given privy to her thoughts and feelings or her full knowledge as to her actions or inner thoughts. What? Is this really fair? Okay, we could suspend disbelief. But, really? How much? Apparently, this is the author's first novel for adults. She had previously been writing for a YA audience. Maybe she underestimated her reader audience for this book? Or me. So, was this a good read as a mystery? No. It was only ok. I am changing my shelf now. 2.5 stars...more

title: The Maidens
author: Michaelides, Alex*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It has been awhile, so I felt it was time that I write this  for Goodreads. I have to admit I was completely enchanted with The Silent Patient.hIt has been awhile, so I felt it was time that I write this  for Goodreads. I have to admit I was completely enchanted with The Silent Patient.https://www.goodreads.com//show... It really is shelved as one of my all time favorite books now. So, when the Maidens came out, I couldn't wait to read it. Let me start by sharing the basic premise of the story. The book's protagonist is Mariana who specializes in group therapy in London. She gets a call from her niece Zoe who shares that her friend Tara has been murdered. In a rather gruesome way. Mariana heads to Cambridge to be with her niece. Police arrest someone who Mariana believes is innocent, and thus she starts her own investigation. That was my first problem with the book. She zeroes in on Edward Fosca a charismatic classics professor, who has a cult like female following, (which included Tara), called The Maidens. Hence the title of the book. Are you still with me? On to my second problem with the book. Now all this back story about Greek mythology slows the story down. In my opinion, it was cumbersome. But the story picks up pace with all the dead bodies. Is that really how you want to capture our attention? Shouldn't the story just flow?Now, I must be honest here. I am not one for gothic storylines, so we are off to a poor start for me. Perhaps that is my third problem with the book. And the climatic all around problem with the book is...The creepy atmosphere doesn't help the unsatisfying plot and sometimes exasperating protagonist (is it really her place to be doing this investigation?). And the book's ending, while surprising just doesn't feel earned. Is this really a 2.5 stars rating? Okay, I'm being generous, I rounded it to a 3, which isn't typical for me to do. I really wanted to like this one. I hope the author's next book is better....more

review: Have you ever picked up a hot book that was on the bestseller list, so excited it finally came in from the library, that you just couldn't wait to reaHave you ever picked up a hot book that was on the bestseller list, so excited it finally came in from the library, that you just couldn't wait to read it? Well, that was me a while ago with this book. I was over the top beside myself because of all the s I had read about how good this book was. The basic premise of the story was that Millie has to find a job before she lands right back in prison or she will violate parole. One wrong move and she will be trapped again. So, what could be more exciting than working for Nina Winchester? Well, she does exactly that. She becomes her housemaid. She takes care of her home under her watchful eye and her spoiled daughter. But Nina isn't exactly the best boss one could ask for. And it doesn't help that Nina has an attractive husband who isn't quite happy in this marriage. So, I am already having trouble with characters I am not liking. This is not working for me. What am I going do? This was called a psychological suspense story. I felt it was more creepy. Also, this author seems quite content in coming up with a variety of twists. I, on the other hand, was so exhausted by the twists, and overwhelmed by the nastiness of the characters that I just couldn't take it, and had to walk away. I know. This is a hot, popular book. I abandoned it. I left. I gave up. I'm sorry. Now you know why it is a thumbs-down. 1 star. From me....more

review: I read this long ago and now I am finally bringing my  to Goodreads.This is truly an enchanting tale. Premise: It is about a boy who loses his GI read this long ago and now I am finally bringing my  to Goodreads.This is truly an enchanting tale. Premise: It is about a boy who loses his Grandfather, and a journey he takes with a talking cat to save books. Now, anything that has to do with books, I am all in. Of course, anything with talking animals, I am there, too! There are clearly learning messages for readers to capture throughout this book. Not just for Rintaro (the boy) to grasp, but for us readers to gain. The talking cat, Tiger, leads his young student through these trails (the journey) with a mixture of aloofness (after all he is a cat) and charm. Still…Rintaro is high school age, dealing with loss, going through a difficult time in school. There is a sense of youthfulness to this story – addressing lots of issues important for this age group. Yet…This story can appeal to anyone. Regardless of age. It is a journey not just through books, but through identity and the processing of grief. This is a lovely story for any book lover. It is charming in that we gain a sense of friendship, and love, and healing from grief. And of course, the mission to save books from various perils. If you like books about books, this might be a great one to cozy up to – or discuss with a group or friend. ...more

review: I read this awhile ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I picked up this book because of the title. Having facilitated a library book discussI read this awhile ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I picked up this book because of the title. Having facilitated a library book discussion group for over 12 years, I was interested. I like to read about people in book clubs. What is it like for them? So…this is what led me to this book.Premise: This is a story about the lasting value and importance of women’s friendship. It is set amidst a group of Army wives with chapters taking place in both present day and 10 years earlier. As readers, we experience close connections, long grudges, and the possibility of reconciliation and renewal. In the present, Regina and Sophie both receive an “SOS” from their old friend Adelaide. They both come to her aid. Not realizing that she has called both Regina and Sophie to come, who are estranged from each other. (Oy!) But…This is about Adelaide, and the women put their differences aside. Meanwhile we are taken back in time to how they first met on the Army base, since their husbands were in the same military unit. Adelaide organized a book club for spouses, and this is where an unbreakable bond between these women is initially formed. But…Something happens to break that bond. And details/reveal doesn’t come until later. Again, had it not been for the title of the book, I would not have been drawn to the story. The most interesting part for me were the sections corresponding to the books the group is reading, and it made sense thematically and from an entertaining perspective. Still…The drama of the women… been-here-before. ...more

review: This was originally posted on my Facebook page. Bringing my  now to Goodreads. History is interesting in its own way…Especially when there are rThis was originally posted on my Facebook page. Bringing my  now to Goodreads. History is interesting in its own way…Especially when there are rumors about famous people that made an impact on history. For example...Did you hear the rumors about General Dwight Eisenhower having an affair with his driver Kay Summersby during WWII? Well... If you did or didn’t, this novel will give you the fictionalized account of the perceived relationship between the two. The novel is heavily based upon the authors in-depth research and his interpretation of such events. I have been a sometimes fan of World War II historical fiction. Learning about the private side of a celebrated figure can be very enticing. Still...Did Ike have a wartime affair with Kay? Does it matter – or have an influence on history, if he had?As the reader, you can make your own decision. ...more

title: White Like Her: My Family's Story of Race and Racial Passing
author: Lukasik, Gail*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this in 2018 and I’m now bringing this  to Goodreads. I saw the author, Gail Lukasik in a televised interview and felt compelled to get hI read this in 2018 and I’m now bringing this  to Goodreads. I saw the author, Gail Lukasik in a televised interview and felt compelled to get her book.It was on the hot list at my local Library, so it took awhile before it was available for me to read. I believe the foreword by Kenyatta D. Berry, J.D., Host of Genealogy Roadshow (PBS) says it best when she shares: “This book adds to the ongoing conversation about race and racial identity in America because it looks at the ramifications of institutionalized racism and racial passing through one family’s story. Passing is something we don’t talk about in our society, but in the African American community we know it exists. It’s part of our collective history as Americans. Passing meant better opportunities for jobs, education, and quality of life. Racism and the continued oppression of African Americans exist today. This book will be the impetus to conversations about periods in history that have been forgotten but still resonate in people’s lives today whether they know it or not. Some too painful to remember, but we know ‘it wasn’t right.’” A powerful read. Not perfect, but it was her story to tell. ...more

title: The Night Travelers
author: Correa, Armando Lucas*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…I am wondering. What do we look for when we read each other’s s. Do we want to know about the story so we can decide if it is somethCatching up…I am wondering. What do we look for when we read each other’s s. Do we want to know about the story so we can decide if it is something we want to read?Or…Do we readers of this  want to know how the er feels about the book they just read?I don’t give spoilers. I don’t think it is right to tell too much, because then what is the point of reading the story if all the details are splashed across the . Right? But…I have wondered, what attracts anyone to read anybody’s s? To follow any of us? I’d like to believe it is how we tell the story of anything we read. Which leads me to this book…I wasn’t sure how I felt about this book. This author definitely has his pulse on historical events. He begins this story with a poet having to protect his mixed-race daughter from Hitler’s racial laws. The author then follows the heartache that her grown daughter endures, having to send her own daughter away to save her life during the Castro revolution. Readers are then slipping forward and backward through eighty-six years. We go from Germany, to Cuba, to New York and back to Germany in 2015.Interestingly enough…Even though the Holocaust plays a memorable role – front and center – and it is very-well researched by the author – the main characters are not Jewish. The author does however, feature some graphic experiences of the Holocaust…And… The voyage of the St. Louis liner from Hamburg to Havana, which carried mostly Jewish refugees. This Holocaust coverage might be considered a trigger warning for some readers. No doubt, there is a lot of crime against humanity, and many moral issues presented throughout this story – in which the generations of women that are travelling through those 86 years are touched – which makes this a very good book discussion selection. So…How did I feel?Anger. Grief. Helpless. Sad. Hopeful. I’d like to believe that books like this can educate. That perhaps we can learn that hate isn’t the answer. That we are entitled to think and believe differently. And have varying opinions. And be respectful of those differences....more

review: Special Note: Even though this is a long-standing series, you can read this as a stand-alone. Yes, the characters do grow as the series progresses, buSpecial Note: Even though this is a long-standing series, you can read this as a stand-alone. Yes, the characters do grow as the series progresses, but Lovesey is a master at treating each book as if it is a stand-alone. So this is how the book starts…“The old lady lifted a black velvet bag from her sewing box, loosened the cord and took out a silver Smith and Wesson revolver.” What are we in for here?Premise: For 6 years, the hit TV series Swift has been plagued with misfortune. The media is quick to decide the program is cursed, but who is to blame? The filming is now in the Bath area. Detective Superintendent Peter Diamond’s investigation into the suspicious death of one of the stars takes a turn when one of the rigging crew goes missing soon after. I love Peter Lovesey’s Detective Superintendent Diamond. His series has wit, humor, clever plots, and of course, the iconic Diamond. He also has created a great team that puts up with his quirks. At the same time, he also has Diamond appreciative of them. There are a lot of things to unravel before solving the case, and I was fine not figuring things out right away. I enjoyed the deviousness of the plot. I especially appreciated the interactions between the characters. Especially when they took readers backstage to look at the filming of a hit TV show. Page-turning, fun, cozy, popcorn popping good series! ...more

I don't have to take forever to figure them out. Peter Lovesey is a Mystery Writers of America Grand Master. What does that mean? It means he has been bestowed the highest honor by the organization - recognized for lifetime achievement and consistent quality. Outstanding! We know him for his detective, Peter Diamond. But, that isn't the only character(s) that shows up in this book.This is a clever collection - some of his oldest stories that launched his mystery writing career - and some new ones, too. I have always found short mystery stories fun to read in-between novels - when I need a breather. Or a brain teaser. Enjoy this one!...more

review: Cleaning shelves - adding new ones for Goodreads.Olive scores a free vacation when her identical twin sister and new brother-in-law get food poisoningCleaning shelves - adding new ones for Goodreads.Olive scores a free vacation when her identical twin sister and new brother-in-law get food poisoning at their wedding buffet and are too sick to go on their honeymoon. The only catch is that she will have to share the honeymoon suite with her least favorite person - Ethan Thomas, the brother of the groom. To make matters worse, Olive's new boss and Ethan's ex-girlfriend show up in Hawaii, forcing them both to pretend to be newlyweds. Okay, readers...let us pause in this moment here and breathe. How many times have we seen this scenario acted out? Another rom-com book? A tv movie? Tell me you haven't read this, or seen this played out before? Yes, I know there is witty banter, healthy adult communication, and fake newlywed chemistry. The authors even throws in heartfelt and funny moments. And of course, the enemies-to-lovers romance! But for me, it has been read, said, and seen before. So...Sorry. 2.5 stars. That was the best I could do....more

review: Another book read before to bring to Goodreads. We meet a boy. Overly protected by parents. Grandparents help him to spread his wings. He learns pianoAnother book read before to bring to Goodreads. We meet a boy. Overly protected by parents. Grandparents help him to spread his wings. He learns piano on a Steinway purchased by his Grandmother that follows him through his life. The gift of a puppet leads to setting up a puppet theater in the attic of his home. The morally serious student doesn't fit in at Dartmouth transfers to the music school at Rollins in Florida. He meets Joanne, the love of his life. While Joanne completes her studies, he goes to New York, gets a job as an apprentice on NBC, and before we know it, so much happens with his life. Even as he tries the seminary (that isn't a good fit), he still sees he is good with children. As readers, we see him as perennially kind and caring in everything he does. He may not have been best with his own sons, but, he found a way to translate how to be a good Dad on to the television screen. Rogers lived simply. He sang and spoke through puppets. To read about him is to be elevated. But mostly it is to ask ourselves one simple question, "am I a good neighbor?" If you are interested in knowing more about the man, this book will give you those insights. 3.5 stars....more

review: This was a book that I read a while ago that I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. To be honest, it took me a few times picking it up and putting This was a book that I read a while ago that I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. To be honest, it took me a few times picking it up and putting it down before I finally picked it up one last time and couldn't put it down. This can be considered a contemporary novel with a twist. Set in a small cafe in Tokyo, those who know of this particular coffee shop, know that it hides a secret. One seat in particular allows a person to go back in time. This story is told through the eyes of 4 people seeking this chance to go back in time. But, with some very specific rules - most importantly, that they must return before their coffee gets cold. You were wondering about the title of the book? Well, now you know. I don't think I gave away any spoilers here. The question for readers is, what if you were given a chance to go back in time - would you? And if you had only one chance - who would you choose to see? This is a character-driven story in which we are introduced to them not so casually facing these questions. Some things about the story felt incomplete. Something I really can't explain, but it did raise a lot of questions of what we would be willing to do for the people we love. 3.5 stars....more

title: Perfect

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up...Is time relative? Does it make a difference as to what will happen in our lives, if it is tampered with? Now…This is a typical question Catching up...Is time relative? Does it make a difference as to what will happen in our lives, if it is tampered with? Now…This is a typical question that gets me each time I read a book about time travel. But…This one is not about time travel. So, why do I bring up the question here?As it so happens, the story begins with this sentence…“In 1972, two seconds were added to time.”And thus…The story unfolds. How did changing the clock by two seconds impact these characters?Joyce tells the story in 2 narratives; the story of Byron and the present-day story of Jim. There are segues between the 2 narratives as the connections between them are slowly revealed. But…For me, it just felt like too much was going on. And…There is a darkness, sadness, and loneliness to this story. The moorland setting definitely affects the mood, as well. Joyce allows readers to feel the weather effects including fog and a wild rainstorm. Even if Joyce felt that “life can change a little for the better” I wasn’t totally convinced, even though I will be the first cheerleader for hope.Still…Even with its flaws, this book has characters that are trying their best to find a place in the world. Trigger warnings…OCD, depression, mental illness. Finally…I am a huge fan of Rachel Joyce, but this story did not work for me. Maybe, you might feel differently....more

title: Miss Benson's Beetle
author: Joyce, Rachel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…At the back of the book, the author shares that this book came to be based on a photograph. It actually started with visions she had of twCatching Up…At the back of the book, the author shares that this book came to be based on a photograph. It actually started with visions she had of two women, and then months later, she actually found a photograph of the same two women she had seen in her vision. Although…She was never really able to explain to herself why this had happened to her, it was important enough to turn these women into characters that would soon become Margery and Enid. Premise: Miss Margery Benson is considered a spinster teacher in her mid-40’s. It is England in 1950. She has been teaching at a girls’ school and she just has had enough. But…It was her father showing her a picture of the legendary golden beetle of New Caledonia, seen but captured, that convinces her she must find it. Especially since her 4 elder brothers had been killed, and her father, had shot himself because of it. So…Off to Caledonia she goes looking for this mythical insect. Along with an assistant named Enid, and a stalker. Now…Let me just say, I was a fangirl of this author’s “The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry.” Review here: https://www.goodreads.com//show...And…The Love Song of Miss Queenie Hennessy: https://www.goodreads.com//show... So…I was ready to read anything this author had to offer. But…This story just didn’t do it for me. If the plot was meant to be tongue-in-cheek, it fell flat. It was more like a fantastical plot that tried to look like a humorous fairy tale, that just didn’t work. And…At almost 400 pages, it was just much too long!I know I am probably an outlier, and I will be skewered for it…But…Go ahead…I’m ready…...more

title: The Happiest Man on Earth
author: Jaku, Eddie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: He was 100 when this was published. But he was more. He was a Holocaust survivor. This is his story. He takes his time telling his story. The process He was 100 when this was published. But he was more. He was a Holocaust survivor. This is his story. He takes his time telling his story. The process is sometimes heart-wrenching, because obviously the experiences are. It is his experience. And yet…He is composed. Even as he shares some of the most horrific crimes committed against the human race in Nazi Germany. And…He’s not shouting. It’s almost as if we’re children listening to a bedtime story by our grandparents – although, it’s not the greatest subject, it is an important one. A memory that needs to be preserved for posterity. This is a highly readable memoir. His stories of the dreadfulness of the death camps and the Nazi efforts to kill him would cause anyone to live in bitterness and anger…but to him, he doesn’t feel that is a solution. He tells his story without bitterness. He inspires readers to make life beautiful even under the most unfavorable situations. He says, “I will tell you my story. It is sad one in parts, with great darkness and sorrow. But it is a happy story in the end because happiness is something we can choose. It is up to you. Through all of my years I have learned this: life can be beautiful if you make it beautiful.”We can learn a lot from Eddie Jaku. The 15 chapters give us much to contemplate.In today’s fast-moving- post-truth world, no one is naïve as to consider that sacrifices, speeches, or sentiments are enough to change the course of history. But… We cannot afford to let the hate that permeated during Nazi Germany ever happen again. Under no circumstances can the horrors of Nazi violence or its magnitude be undervalued or taken lightly. His memoir forces us to reflect and gather the courage to not lose hope even in the most difficult times. Personal note…I believe in Hope. I have courage in a better world. I want to believe. Eddie’s survival through what he went through tells me we can do better as a human race. He reminds us of hope, compassion and kindness. Let us go to a place of hope, compassion and kindness, always. On October 12, 2021 Eddie Jaku passed away in Sydney, Australia. Goodbye, my dear new friend....more

title: The Last Equation of Isaac Severy
author: Jacobs, Nova*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The book asks the question, “What if mathematics not only described the universe, but could actually predict the future?” So, what if life and death cThe book asks the question, “What if mathematics not only described the universe, but could actually predict the future?” So, what if life and death can be determined with math? What happens if there is an answer, and it was in the wrong hands? When Isacc, the patriarch of the eccentric and gifted family dies under suspicious circumstances, his family gathers for the first time in years. Alternating between Hazel’s POV and her brother Gregory, and her Uncle Philip, there are a series of puzzling clues and plot twists, trying to find the answer to the question (which Isacc’s life work professed to have found the answer to). The quirkiness of the characters, and the family drama made this story cute, but a little over the top. The grief felt about losing their patriarch, that felt real. And for that, I appreciated that part of the story. ...more
