review: This is another Andy Carpenter mystery that can be read as a stand-alone, but to truly have fun with this series, it is better to start from the beginThis is another Andy Carpenter mystery that can be read as a stand-alone, but to truly have fun with this series, it is better to start from the beginning. Jenny Nichols was a hometown girl that is now a famous actress. Andy loves to mention how he use to date her when they were in high school whenever he has a chance. As it so happens, they have stayed in touch, and she is back in town and meets up with Andy, Laurie (Andy's wife) and their friends for dinner. Unfortunately, her ex, who happens to also be a famous actor, shows up at this same dinner, makes a scene before the team kick him out. That same night, he winds up dead, at Jenny’s house with a knife in his back. Now Andy is representing Jenny and his team is doing everything to prove she didn’t do it. Will they be successful?As in any Andy Carpenter mystery, there is snarky humor, along with twists, turns, suspense and a satisfying end. With…Much dog-love!Series fans – keep an eye out for ‘Twas the Bite Before Christmas’ which will release in October....more

review: Catching up...This is the first in Anthony Horowitz’s James Bond series or Extended Series #47. And...This book also contains original, never-before-pCatching up...This is the first in Anthony Horowitz’s James Bond series or Extended Series #47. And...This book also contains original, never-before-published material from 007 creator/author, Ian Fleming. 007 returns to his roots with this story set in the late 1950’s. Horowitz manages a tricky tightrope walk of presenting Bond as the type of man he was as originally written while pointing out all his failings and still somehow making him heroic despite those flaws. As an example M says to him: "I think you're a sexist, misogynist dinosaur. A relic of the Cold War, whose boyish charms, though lost on me, obviously appealed to that young girl I sent out to evaluate you."Overall...This is an entertaining retro version of a James Bond story that is kind of silly but fun. And...If you like the Sean Connery movies like Dr. No and Goldfinger then you’d probably enjoy this book. 3.5 stars rounded to 4. ...more

author: Horowitz, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up...For those of you who have been following my s, you know I have been a fan of Anthony Horowitz. He has an extraordinary flair for tCatching up...For those of you who have been following my s, you know I have been a fan of Anthony Horowitz. He has an extraordinary flair for telling a story, and has been quite successful in getting contracts by the Arthur Conan Doyle estate to write about Sherlock Holmes and the Ian Fleming estate to write about James Bond. He has also written for television, and movies and has quite the successful teen series. Forever and a Day is the second book in his James Bond series – or #48 in the Extended Series. I have a request in to the library to read his first in the series, Trigger Mortis. But...For now, let me get Back to Forever and a Day. Overall... The book is a quick and enjoyable read. Bond fans will find a lot to like here. As I read, I kept on hearing both the music and the "My name is Bond, James Bond" playing in my head, as well as having Sean Connery parading through the pages. And...Great characters, a wonderful 1950's setting & a truly superb Bond adventure, if a bit predictable.Still...I recommend it....more

She walks into a Dallas art studio in search of a job, and finds herself attracted to artist, Owen. Unfortunately, Owen is hiding a secret. Well, this isn't good. So...The only way that Auburn can get her life back on track, is to cut Owen out of it. Can she?Is this the part where we as readers are left distraught?How much more tragic can these stories get? Of course, I find myself speeding through the night to get to my happy ending - isn't that what we all want in the end? Especially when Hoover makes her men as swoon-worthy as Owen. review: I promised myself that I would not read another CoHo book again. I didn't like the direction she was taking her stories, but...This one was a donationI promised myself that I would not read another CoHo book again. I didn't like the direction she was taking her stories, but...This one was a donation to my Little Free Library Shed, and so far every one that has been donated, has not returned. So obviously they are popular books in my neighborhood. So...What was I to do?I opened the pages and began to read.Premise: Beyeh has only known poverty and neglect. 2 months before she is finally free, an unexpected death forces her to spend the remainder of her summer in Texas with a father she hardly knows. And then there is Samson, a brooding guy who lives next door to her father. A summer fling?The premise is nothing new. Been there, read that. Familiar beat. The author gives us a kind-hearted and fiercely loyal character in Beyah who is incredibly sympathetic, especially of those who have fallen through the cracks of life. Still, the storyline is familiar. But, I like her. She is even good when Samson is annoying. (BTW, what is with the naming of these characters?)This story is a slow burn. It is all about these 2 characters. Are they or aren't they going to be more than just a summer thing? What will we find in this story? - Romance. Secrets. Class prejudices. Troubled Characters. Doing the best they can.But still...The same old story, just with different characters in a different setting. But readable. ...more

review: I read this a while ago - now bringing my  to Goodreads. What is interesting about this book, is that it is Colleen Hoover's debut novel that shI read this a while ago - now bringing my  to Goodreads. What is interesting about this book, is that it is Colleen Hoover's debut novel that she self-published in 2012. It became a hit on social media. Premise of story: Layken's father dies suddenly. Now her mother takes a job across the country. Her new neighbor is Will Cooper. Attraction ensues between the two. Will this relationship survive every challenge put before them?This story deals with grief, responsibility, growing up, as well as romance. And slam poetry. It's just the drama was a little over-the-top. Will said he couldn't date Layken. (No spoilers from me.) Despite the added drama that unfolds, the circumstances that they had to overcome regarding the viability of their relationship seemed to be conquered....eventually...too easily. And I think this took away a bit, from the story, for me.Side note: The relationship between Layken and Eddie is a compelling story.For the most part, this is a readable and entertaining book. 3.5 stars....more

review: Catching up…This past Monday, I was graciously invited to participate in the Mobile Public Library’s Book Group’s Zoom discussion of Practical Magic lCatching up…This past Monday, I was graciously invited to participate in the Mobile Public Library’s Book Group’s Zoom discussion of Practical Magic led by my Goodreads friend, Librarian Chris Cox. Chris is an amazing facilitator, and the group was delightful, inspiring, and quite welcoming in allowing me to be included in their tightknit group! Being apart of this discussion reminded me that I still had not posted my  of this book. So, I bring it to you now.This book finalizes the Practical Magic series. So, let’s begin at the end. This is how the author starts this book. “Some stories begin at the beginning and others begin at the end, but all the best stories begin in a library.” Oh yes. The library. And for anyone who has followed this page-turning fairy tale series through its previous three books, Practical Magic, Rules of Magic and Magic Lessons, along with its star-studded movie adaptation, then you know there is a lot to learn about the Owens saga. The Book of Magic begins at the end, which really is the demise of Jet, the beautiful witch who, with her sister Franny are now considered the matriarchs of the Owens clan. So, coming to the library, readers learn along with Jet that she has 7 days left with her life. What will she do with it?And thus, the story takes off. Much will happen with an abundant cast of characters, that may bog down the story a bit. And if the ending seems a bit sweet after all that messy, just remember that this was a witchy fairy tale, meant to be a bit imperfect. Just let yourself go with it!...more

title: Silent Parade        (Detective Galileo, #4)
author: Higashino, Keigo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Here is another book I have read that I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. First I must apologize. I came into reading this series at #4. So, I aHere is another book I have read that I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. First I must apologize. I came into reading this series at #4. So, I am reading it as a stand-alone, unaware of the history of these characters that existed through books 1-3. Second this book is translated into English. The good news, (I have come to appreciate), is that there was no need to have read the others to enjoy this well-crafted captivating mystery with suspense and twists as well as showcasing a good police procedural. Did I scare you there for a moment? I wanted to share this, because sometimes translations, and books being read out of sequence (which I have a tendency to do), can be tricky. On to the story...Detective Galileo is Manabu Yukawa, a perceptive physics professor, who occasionally assists the Tokyo police department. There is a complex case the Detective Chief and Detective Sergeant would like his assistance. There is an assumption of murder from a crime that has taken place approximately three years prior where a body was completely concealed and almost destroyed by fire. Of course, it now has been found. They have a primary suspect, but, he chooses not to confess to the crime. And now to the parade - the title of the book. Taking advantage of the distractions provided by the festivities, what should occur but...another crime! Is the incident connected to the first crime? Lots will happen...no spoilers from me! Just when it seems like all shall be solved, Detective Galileo uncovers another long-buried secret. What shall this long-buried secret be? How will this tie up all the loose ends? The book has its way of finding closure that is satisfying for readers. There is a hint of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Agatha Christie amongst these pages. If you are fans of both those authors (I am), I think you might enjoy this one....more

title: Book Lovers
author: Henry, Emily*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are many ways to begin a love story...and we have come to read many of them. Friends to lovers. Co-workers to lovers. Grew up with my neighbor tThere are many ways to begin a love story...and we have come to read many of them. Friends to lovers. Co-workers to lovers. Grew up with my neighbor to lovers. Fake lovers to lovers. Strangers to lovers. The list goes on. But, what seems the most attractive plot line for contemporary romance of all is...enemies to lovers. While I don't personally get it, because I would rather have my significant other absolutely adore me than abhor me - this seems to be the go-to story line. Think about it. Pride and Prejudice. When Harry Met Sally. We seem to be attracted to weirdly charged meet-cutes and declarations of hatred that turn into passionate kisses. Hmmm. Book Lovers is centered around a literary agent named Nora and a literary editor named Charlie. We are supposed to believe these two "love interests" are enemies from one interaction that lasts about 3 pages. Somehow, that one memorable lunch hour was enough for Nora to remember Charlie years later when she runs into him while on vacation. And now, all these years later, they are striking up this will-they-won't they romance, born from unfounded hatred. Oy! Did I care? It seemed like manufactured sparks between these two. The characters were boring, undeveloped and had no sense of voice. I was disappointed that the author seemed to be more focused on trying to make the plot quirky and flirtatious as opposed to focusing on characterization. I was sincerely disappointed. Probably the only one....more

review: Catching up…So…The first time Poppy meets Alex, she hopes she doesn’t see him again. Well…You know what that means, right? They have to end up togetheCatching up…So…The first time Poppy meets Alex, she hopes she doesn’t see him again. Well…You know what that means, right? They have to end up together. Which means…This is a typical rom-com romance-made-in-heaven, friends to lovers, trope.Still…Even if we are familiar with this ride, it doesn’t erase for readers, the fun of the journey. Now…Don’t get me wrong, I love a good romance. And…This felt a lot like my all-time favorite movie, “When Harry Met Sally…”But…That doesn’t necessarily mean that it worked for me. There has to be some level of chemistry for that to occur. Even if the author tries to convince us that there is romantic tension.The friendship played well…But…All the angst of the broken friendship…And then…Let’s patch the friendship up…To…Let’s be together…Seemed contrived.I know I am not going to be popular with this . So many of my friends gave this book 4 plus and/or 5 stars. But…I was needing a special sparkly feeling – and I just didn’t get it. What it did do…Is made me want to go watch “When Harry met Sally” again. ...more

review: Catching up...Kent Haruf wrote Our Souls at Night (179 pages) under a death sentence. Despite knowing his life was coming to a sooner end than it shouCatching up...Kent Haruf wrote Our Souls at Night (179 pages) under a death sentence. Despite knowing his life was coming to a sooner end than it should, or perhaps because of this, he created a story about finding love in the final chapter of one’s life. I fell in love with this book from page one, the first sentence and beyond. I fell in love with Louis Waters and Addie Moore and how they talk into the night about their lives and pasts, their transgressions, their hopes and desires, their losses, their families and how they bring joy to each other to ease the loneliness. I love how the title so perfectly reflects this. Our Souls at Night is simply, profoundly, an exquisite homage to love. And it broke my heart. Because, the story just has a way of capturing your heart enough to feel strongly about what you are witnessing (through reading and through watching on film). I read Our Souls at Night in one sitting and wept in the final pages. Haruf passed away in November, 2014 at the age of 71. He will be missed. The Netflix film first aired on September 29, 2017. It is a wonderful translation to film, capturing the essence of the book extraordinarily well, and with performances that are as wonderful as the written characters. I recommend both wholeheartedly. ...more

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Harari, Yuval Noah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Why did I read this? A friend gave this to me, I believe and insisted. They said I was smart and would benefit from it. I thought they were kidding meWhy did I read this? A friend gave this to me, I believe and insisted. They said I was smart and would benefit from it. I thought they were kidding me. It seemed to be something way beyond my capacity of understanding. Could it capture my interest? I began to read.Let me just say it takes ambition for any one to describe the history of humanity in 256 pages of full-color illustrations and easy-to-understand text. But this author did. He was engaging and often provocative in his writing style. We are learning about early humans living alongside other primate species. We are seeing revolutions that transformed first people, and our planet. He even touches on the changes in agriculture. The portrait offered is frequently violent. (Especially in those early stages.)As he gets closer to modern age the tone and selection of topics change. They become more eclectic. There is talk of happiness. Religion. Human psychology. Media. Language. Social movements. Still...The author is inspiring, too. Whatever the flaws, and believe me I am no expert on history, this book was certainly compelling. ...more

title: Asymmetry
author: Halliday, Lisa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At first, it seems like we have been here before. Alice launches an affair with Ezra, decades her senior. For the first few chapters, it seemed too tiAt first, it seems like we have been here before. Alice launches an affair with Ezra, decades her senior. For the first few chapters, it seemed too tired and too insular a story to hear again. But…As the story progresses, the undercurrents grow stronger and the story resolves into an interesting meditation on creativity, empathy and the anxiety of influence. We watch as Alice struggles to escape from Ezra’s certainty. I won’t go into details, it gets into spoiler territory. Years pass and a new book begins. One about a Muslim man. Amar is an economist, the son of Iraqi Kurdish immigrants. He is detained at Heathrow airport on his way to Iraq where his brother has disappeared. Amar’s story, in contrast to Alice’s is bold, mournful, unabashed, told in a graceful forceful first person POV. The book’s final chapter is an interview with Ezra, some years later. (I won’t reveal the spoiler here of what was disclosed.) What are we learning about Alice?What are we learning about Ezra?Are they living their best lives?In some ways we feel that by herself, Alice is forgettable, but in Amar, she demands to be remembered. A very different literary reading experience.Asymmetry could be considered a guidebook to being bigger than ourselves. ...more

title: The Plant Paradox: The Hidden Dangers in "Healthy" Foods That Cause Disease and Weight Gain        (The Plant Paradox, 1)
author: Gundry, Steven R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wanted to love this book, because after all a Doctor that proclaims that some "healthy" foods can cause disease and/or weight gain must know what thI wanted to love this book, because after all a Doctor that proclaims that some "healthy" foods can cause disease and/or weight gain must know what they are talking about, right?But the more I delved into it, the more skeptical I became because it seemed to exclude A LOT of really good foods that for years, I have been told by many doctors I should eat. Besides, years ago, I read a book called "Diets Don't Work" by Dr. Bob Schwartz and since that point in my life, I have felt that any time some one tells me what I should or shouldn't eat to lose weight, I am going to end up gaining it back once I reintroduce it back into my body. So, I don't believe in diets.And then...I found myself skeptical. And concerned. And I started to ask questions. And do some research. And I found that there were doctors and nutritionists and scientists that were criticizing this book. There was one Wikipedia article by Michael Matthews calling this author's diet/book a scam. He said: "The Plant Paradox is rife with inaccuracies, misrepresentations, and outright misinformation, and the diet espoused in it is unnecessarily restrictive and blatantly designed to sell people overpriced and ineffective supplements...there's enough high-quality research to say we know enough about lectins to blow all of Dr. Gundry's principal hypotheses out of the airlock and thereby dismantle and disarm The Plant Paradox."Matthews saw it as fake science. So, it doesn't appear that his book is based on scientific driven facts or medicine. As a reader, I would be concerned. It is our body. It deserves our protection....more

review: I read this one a while ago. But since I am now ing Party of Two https://www.goodreads.com//show..., I thought I better also bring this reI read this one a while ago. But since I am now ing Party of Two https://www.goodreads.com//show..., I thought I better also bring this  to Goodreads, as well. What I will say is this, before we start…Alexa and Drew are related to Olivia in Party of Two. They will make an appearance in that story, but you need not read this story, to read Party of Two. They are stand-alones. Premise: Alexa and Drew meet in an elevator. It just so happens to get stuck, so why not start flirting with each other. Drew invites Alexa to his ex’s wedding. Now, this isn’t something she would normally do, but there is something about Drew that she is drawn to, so she agrees. Drew is a pediatric surgeon, and Alexa is the Chief of Staff for the Mayor of Berkeley. What is in store for these 2?Humorous. Light-hearted. Sexy. Lots of sexy. But…There are also a lot of hard-hitting issues, too.The author addresses interracial dating, white privilege, growing up in ethnic backgrounds, and racial bias from law enforcement. Alexa makes these points to Drew as to what it was like for her growing up as a woman of color. Drew uses this knowledge to reflect and be more aware. Although this seemed like a situation of insta-love romance, the couple seem to want to make this relationship work, despite the many fights and misunderstandings. Still…A bit too much been-here-before set-up, though. This was the author’s debut novel. 3.5 stars...more

review: Apparently, I read this a while ago, but had forgotten. So, when this was donated to my Little Free Library Shed, seeing that it was a Grisham novel, Apparently, I read this a while ago, but had forgotten. So, when this was donated to my Little Free Library Shed, seeing that it was a Grisham novel, I was excited, picked it up again to read again, and realized I had already read it. Oy!(Has this happened to you?)I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Quick summary...A partner steals millions of dollars, fakes his death, moves to South America, but four years later, he is caught. Then the beginning of the book starts off. What?This book is another case of a decent plot going about it from a strange angle. We eventually learn in Chapter 1 that Patrick Lanigan, the one I described above, is the one we are talking about who was caught by bounty hunters and turned over to the FBI. This is all summed up in the first 30 pages. So, what more was there to say in this book, Mr. Grisham? I guess Mr. Grisham wanted us to know why Patrick did what he did. Which really was the slow moving part of the book, and least interesting. This made the book dull and the plot a struggle. The only interesting part was what happened to Patrick at the end. Maybe that gives this book the extra half star. 2.5 stars. ...more

title: A Time for Mercy        (Jake Brigance, #3)
author: Grisham, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…I read this quite some time ago. It is now time to post my  here on Goodreads. It is not hard to be a Grisham fan of his older booksCatching Up…I read this quite some time ago. It is now time to post my  here on Goodreads. It is not hard to be a Grisham fan of his older books. Especially when he features Jake Brigance. For those who haven’t read Jake, this is his 3rd outing, so, if you haven’t heard of Jake Brigance, then you may not want to start with this book. Jake is a small-town Mississippi lawyer who specializes in unpopular cases that on the surface seem unwinnable. He first appeared in Grisham’s debut novel, “A Time to Kill” which also became a popular movie starring Matthew McConaughey and Sandra Bullock in 1996. Jake returned in “Sycamore Row.” With “A Time for Mercy” Jake is still living with the repercussions of the earlier murder trial. Hence, the reason why readers need to read the books in order. Jake is broke, taking any case he can get, which also appear unwinnable, with a new client that seems guilty of murder. The back story of the murder is fairly clear to readers within the first few pages. And his client appears to have killed a cop. But, is the killing warranted? Defendable? As it appears?Jake is up against the wall on this one. But this is a complicated town, and a driven community. Readers will see issues of race, class, religion, politics and family dynamics played out and not always with sympathy or grace. This story is masterfully plotted and slowly paced with an eventual courtroom drama to experience. Will justice be something different in this case?...more

title: The Guardians
author: Grisham, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…Long ago read, now bringing my  to Goodreads. I am and have been quite a fan of Grisham’s earlier novels. I like courtroom dramas, aCatching up…Long ago read, now bringing my  to Goodreads. I am and have been quite a fan of Grisham’s earlier novels. I like courtroom dramas, and attorney dilemmas. I love the mystery of it, and the intensity…Because…As readers we are given inside views into both the defense attorney and prosecutor’s world. And…For me, finding justice is always the best reward. So…I am open to reading legal thrillers. Which is typically Grisham’s wheelhouse. And…When someone is wrongly convicted, it is always an interesting case to see how it is addressed. Which…Brings me to this story. As readers we are meeting Cullen Post, an “innocence lawyer” who is focusing on the apparent wrongful conviction of a black man named Quincy Miller…Who…Was believed to be set up to take the fall for the murder of a white lawyer, 22 years ago. Side note:Grisham has served on the board of directors of The Innocence Project.Now…Taking on this case isn’t going to be easy. Because…When you believe someone has been wrongly convicted, that means there is somebody else out there who really did it. How are they going to feel about having this case reopened? And…Just because someone claims themselves to be innocent, are they really?Any way we look at it, Post is in for an important role that will put him in provocative and dangerous circumstances. The question is…Will he be able to handle it?And…In Post’s efforts to turn justice around, will it be served?In some ways this felt like a mature version of Nancy Drew adventures. But…Grisham has created an interesting, likable character in Post which makes this a truly worthy read. ...more

review: Catching up...The s were amazing and I thought, well maybe this will be a good mystery because everyone says so.Well...I lasted a few pages befoCatching up...The s were amazing and I thought, well maybe this will be a good mystery because everyone says so.Well...I lasted a few pages before I skipped to the end, and then asked myself why I did even that much!But...This is what I got in those first few pages…The protagonist is Claire DeWitt, who calls herself the Best Detective in the World. If I saw Claire headed my way, I would cross the street, if not run away. Why? Well consider this…The book opens with a traffic "accident", that Claire thinks was an attempt to murder her. She's on the gurney in the ambulance, pulls herself together, assaults a woman police officer and steals her radio and Taser. A bit later, she goes into a bar, and steals a woman's purse. Then she steals an old car, likely from a poor person. Who is this woman anyway, and do I really care? No, I do not. Back to the library you go. Maybe you might feel differently about this series?...more

review: Bringing this  to Goodreads.This is the second in a series about action thriller writer Ian Ludlow. Like True Fiction, https://www.goodreads.comBringing this  to Goodreads.This is the second in a series about action thriller writer Ian Ludlow. Like True Fiction, https://www.goodreads.com//show... this story combines an over-the-top plot which is not to dissimilar to Goldberg's screenwriting style. The pace is brisk, the dialogue clever, the premise cheesy, and kinda fun. Ian doesn't look anything like the character he has created - the cool action hero Clint Straker. Ian actually is a rather unattractively described writer with a few extra pounds who lives in a bland apartment. Now, as a best-selling thriller writer, he has snagged a movie deal and has been invited to be a part of the promotional jaunt in Hong Kong. While working on his next Straker novel, some bad guys are working on a real-life operation similar to his book. They assume that Ian is a CIA spy sent to thwart their operation. And that is where the craziness begins. Campy style, pop culture, laugh-out-loud silly moments. Suspend disbelief, prepare to be entertained, enjoy the crazy ride. And above all else, don't take this book seriously. 3.5 stars....more

review: I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Typically I absolutely love Lee Goldberg. We know him as a successful television writer, he has written severI am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Typically I absolutely love Lee Goldberg. We know him as a successful television writer, he has written several other books, and screenplays. He is well known. So when this series came out, I was ready for him. Or so I thought. This book is pure silliness. It is like watching theater of the absurd. Ian Ludlow is a writer who is asked by the CIA to attend a retreat and brainstorm potential plots that would threaten national security. The problem is suddenly, these brainstorms are putting Ian on the run. So, what do we do as readers? Suspend disbelief. Because the kind of characters that walk through this novel...oy! This is the beginning of the series. I know I went at it again, and read another one in the series, but...why did I? Because I still love Lee Goldberg. I don't know...will I ever learn?...more

review: Catching up...This was originally read and posted on my Facebook page on this date in 2018.I was reading another book in which the character was readiCatching up...This was originally read and posted on my Facebook page on this date in 2018.I was reading another book in which the character was reading a mystery series book featuring a ‘Mrs. Pollifax.’ So..I went to our library to find out if such a series existed. Sure enough it did – so I went ahead and ordered this book to read on our quick RV trip up north.  Apparently... This is the 8th book in the series, which appeared obvious when several cases were referred to in this book reminding us of some of Mrs. Pollifax' adventures and the sticky situations it would get her in. So...It is recommended that you not start with book 8. Go back to the beginning of the series. It will probably be easier to understand the characters and their back stories. Moving on..Mrs. Pollifax looks like an ordinary person but with extraordinary skills. The author shows these skills as she takes us through a story that includes some drug smuggling, kidnapping, rather bumbling agents and geriatric martial arts…albeit with some humor. After all...How many characters do you find that can be simultaneously part of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and the garden club at the same time?This is truly a comfort read – light, fun, and adventurous. Unfortunately, the author died in 2012, so, even though there are 12 to the series, that makes it the end. It was noted in an obituary page from the New York Times that "ers sometimes quibbled about the improbability of her novel's basic premise." Still...Her books proved popular because Mrs. Polifax made "an irresistible early, feminist heroine." So...Should I read more of her? I haven't, but who knows......more

review: Still playing catch up with my s. Here is another one, I want to share on Goodreads. With this one I am excited to say was a wonderful debut novStill playing catch up with my s. Here is another one, I want to share on Goodreads. With this one I am excited to say was a wonderful debut novel. This is a London-based thriller featuring DC Cat Kinsella. Cat isn't exactly the empathetic type (with live people), but she is with murder victims. She is a believably flawed, self-deprecating, and quite human character that I really enjoyed. And she gets along with her older partner - DS Luigi Parnell, a devoted husband and father, who is generally well-liked in the department. As readers, we are dropped right into the middle of a crime scene - and it isn't pretty. As Cat and her partner dig into the victim's life, something comes up that turn's Cat's life upside down. And this is a spoiler I am not going to share. Just know it has an impact on the story. As readers we will find that this isn't just a murder mystery with twists (shocking twists, by the way) it's about Cat learning her way into her herself and her career. All I will say is this, if you haven't read this by now, you might want to put this on your "must read" list soon!...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It has all that a lover of good books longs for: tea, extensive libraries, conversations about books, friendship over books, and romance of the best kIt has all that a lover of good books longs for: tea, extensive libraries, conversations about books, friendship over books, and romance of the best kind (the type that is unseen, but you can feel it). The author does a beautiful job as she captures the themes of literature, philosophy, the search for happiness, and love within the pages. It is full of substance, and one can safely expect to find beauty, truth, and goodness in it. It asks the right questions and provides the proper directions for the reader to find the answers. It is, at the very least, a call to deeper thought, and at the very most, a call to much higher things. One can expect to find within these delightfully water colored-covers the key to the good life. As an example, many times I had to stop and pause because I was so swept up in the philosophy discourses between the characters (at times trying to sort it out while having the secret wish to have that mind). I even copied a few sentiments down so I could return to them. As an example, on page 243, “If you travel in a hurry, without pausing or resting, you’ll return without having found what you’re looking for.” How many times can you relate to that on your travels? And…on page 54, “This is where she discovered that intelligence, this wonderful gift, grows in silence, not in noise. It was here too that she learned that a human mind, a truly human mind, is nurtured over time, with hard work and discipline.” As a life-long learner it gives me a wondrous thrill to know learning never stops, and that my mind is still in the process of nurturing and/or sharing what I learn… and, that intelligence can be ever growing. I loved this book. I was not only charmed and delighted, but obliged to sit and truly contemplate its message. This is the book for book discussion groups to discuss! As a final note, I did something I haven't done in a long time. I purchased a copy of this book for my personal library. And I put my  between the pages. To remind me of the love that I feel for it. Sometimes a book does that to you, long after you close the last page....more

title: The Night Watchman
author: Erdrich, Louise
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…I really wanted to love this one. After all, it won the 2021 Pulitzer Prize for fiction. Then again…Not all Pulitzer Prize winners are greCatching Up…I really wanted to love this one. After all, it won the 2021 Pulitzer Prize for fiction. Then again…Not all Pulitzer Prize winners are great books. And…This one has mixed s. I am one of them.The novel takes place in the 1950’s. The novel’s title character is Thomas Wazhashk. He is a night watchman for a factory where women work during the day using gemstones as drill bits for the Defense Department. One of the workers is his niece, Patrice, also known as Pixie. Thomas’ main job is to watch over the gems, and protect them from thieves. The novel will follow the fate of these two characters. This story is inspired by Erdrich’s grandfather, who wrote many, many letters to politicians in Washington, in an effort to save his tribe from termination. The current and ongoing nightmare of missing and murdered Native women lurks in the shadows of the book. Although moved by the subject matter...I had difficulty connecting to her writing of it. I appreciate all that the author shared about her grandfather, and the historical issues shared in her afterword notes. Including Erdrich’s following note…“Indeed, the Trump administration and Assistant Secretary of the Interior Tara Sweeney have recently brought back the termination era by seeking to terminate the Wampanoag, the tribe who first welcomed Pilgrims to these shores and invented Thanksgiving.”It was mostly through this history, past and present, that encouraged her to write this story. So…Even if the story didn’t resonate with me as much as I would have liked, we all see and read the same book and have our own perspectives. I encourage you to still read this one, and form your own thoughts about it.I leave the last words with Erdrich…“…if you should ever doubt that a series of dry words in a government document can shatter spirits and demolish lives, let this book erase that doubt. Conversely, if you should be of the conviction that we are powerless to change those dry words, let this book give you heart.”...more

review: I wasn't sure I wanted to read this book. First, let me just say I am typically not attracted to science fiction. Nor time travel. And if it is a loveI wasn't sure I wanted to read this book. First, let me just say I am typically not attracted to science fiction. Nor time travel. And if it is a love story, I want to believe in it. And then it is written in epistolary style, too. And sometimes I am not always comfortable with this style, unless it flows. So why did I pick up this one? Let's just say I was intrigued. We have a story that consists of letter exchanges between two time-traveling secret agents on opposite sides of an inter dimensional conflict. An epic game of cat-and-mouse through history. The format felt unique to me. Not because of the letters - but because they spanned across time, and space. One writes a letter, and then one responds to it. And then there are the characters. The story just reeled me in. The characters did it, too. The relationship felt poignant. I wanted it to work somehow. And even though I felt this way, don't think I am going to all of sudden start wanting to read science fiction. This was a one-off for me, okay?!...more

review: This story is about Enzi, and the mishaps that shape his life by the individuals he allows into them. He is dyslexic, and amazingly well-managed for aThis story is about Enzi, and the mishaps that shape his life by the individuals he allows into them. He is dyslexic, and amazingly well-managed for an individual who sought his own life at the age of 14. As we first meet Enzi we are drawn in to his world by the author’s thoughtful way of presenting him – soft, invisible, resilient, awkward, likable, human, gracious, survivor. And then… We have an opportunity to meet Enzi in the future as we come into the next chapter. As his older self, we watch Enzi navigate some difficult decisions. The flow of writing kept me engaged and interested and concerned about what was happening, or could happen, or why he was doing what he was doing. And oh what a tangled captivating crime mystery thriller plot for us readers to experience. Some bad things will happen, and we will be stirred and gripped as we follow along wondering, what will Enzi do? Will Enzi grow wise, or will his trust in others guide him down a path he will regret? Will he show courage to change, or grow into a better version of what he always hoped for himself? The supporting characters are believably real. You can feel like you know them. Even if you don’t want to. Mostly, the author makes us want to turn pages as quickly as we read them. In this way, the author is an artist with words. Highly recommend that you take a walk through Enzi’s life in this stunning novel. Many thanks go to the publisher Flooding Island Press for providing me with a copy of this print book. The opinions I provide are mine alone. I also wanted to share that I didn’t read anything about the author’s background until after I had completed the book. After reading his back story, I have a greater appreciation about his talent at the written word....more

review: Robert Dugoni is one of my favorite thriller writers. And the Tracy Crosswhite series is usually one to follow. In this second installment, Tracy is sRobert Dugoni is one of my favorite thriller writers. And the Tracy Crosswhite series is usually one to follow. In this second installment, Tracy is still suffering from the loss of her younger sister, and her relentless pursuit of her sister's killer. Dugoni is good at pacing the suspense and crafting wonderful characters. Tracy is a strong protagonist. And his psychopaths, well...eerie. Then there is her boss. I don't know if I could ever work for someone like him. Actually, I know I couldn't. Still, Dugoni finds a way to bring in all sorts of characters into his stories, with a variety of personalities that as readers we have obvious reactions to them. Well, at least I do. This story is crafty plotting and high energy with a wild finale. And don't believe in coincidences. They are there for a reason. Sit tight. It will be a bumpy ride! ...more

title: Summit Lake
author: Donlea, Charlie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Here is another book that I have read and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. First let me say that I have been a long time fan of Charlie DonleHere is another book that I have read and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. First let me say that I have been a long time fan of Charlie Donlea. So, any time a book of his becomes available, I am usually ready and willing to check it out at our local library. And sometimes, I decide to look back and see if I can play catch up on some I may have missed, like this one, which is his debut novel. So where do I begin in trying to describe this one - because I have lots of mixed feelings. That is why I would say it is a 3.5 star for me. Let's start here.Gripping. Edgy. Dark. Suspenseful - murder mystery. It opens with a shocking scene and ends with a shocking twist. However, it also leaves readers with some unanswered questions. In my mind, that is a big no no. As much as I am a lover of mysteries, and crime fiction, and such, I am not in to darkness. Okay, I loved Harry Potter. But, if it is too dark, it's like watching a horror film, and I am going to be the one that will walk out of the room, or cover my eyes, and say, "is it over yet?" Kind of hard when you are reading a book. How do you know when to come back to the right page? Anyway, this story is fast-paced and can be considered captivating told in a past and present timeline with alternating points of view between Becca (her story before her death) and Kelsey (an investigative reporter looking into her death). Yet, in many respects, these alternating P.O.V.'s were the interesting parts of the book. Still...Step into this book cautiously - especially when in the dark....more

title: The Poacher's Son        (Mike Bowditch, #1)
author: Doiron, Paul*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…When this was donated to my Little Free Library Shed, I was intrigued. It was the first in the series, so I was safe. I wasn’t going to goCatching Up…When this was donated to my Little Free Library Shed, I was intrigued. It was the first in the series, so I was safe. I wasn’t going to go down that troubling path of reading a book series out of order. So…I began to read.Our main protagonist is Mike Bowditch, a young Maine game warden. Now, what is particularly tricky, is that he is put into the middle of a very serious investigation.The main suspect…His father. How does one overcome this?So…What readers come to experience is a young man’s struggle, at the beginning of a promising career, attempting to balance the demands of a profession, with the expectations of family loyalty. An interesting premise, to say the least. Readers have the opportunity to tag along with Mike wondering how he is going to handle his dysfunctional family circumstances.Did his father commit the murder? No spoilers from me.At the same time, readers are also getting to know Mike. And…Is he a character we are going to want to root for and follow into a successful continuing series?Most importantly…Will he do the right and just thing? Tracking down his father, through the Maine terrain (an interesting character in itself), readers experience Mike and his father navigate their past and present relationship. What stands out the most…Is the attention paid to location and sense of place. I have said this many times in my s how much a place can be just as much a character – because it appeals to our senses – the images – the awakening of our imagination to the location, that some of us may never witness. (I for one, have only seen the tip of Maine from an airplane.) So…What do I really think?This is an engaging plot with solid characters… Because…Of the environment and the conflicts that arise within it. I imagine that the series will prove to be quite successful, too. ...more

review: I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. French exit = a hasty exit made without saying goodbye. This novel is about awful upper class Americans who I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. French exit = a hasty exit made without saying goodbye. This novel is about awful upper class Americans who are portrayed as people who just simply get up and go. They are sophisticated and wealthy on one hand, but, on the other hand, not very pleasant. In other words, did they really pay their way? We have Frances the mother of adult son, Malcolm who still lives with her and isn't handling his finances well. Frances has been famous, rich and stylish. Her husband, Franklin was a corrupt, scary lawyer. He dies in bed, and now his money has run out. So Frances, does what she needs to do...a French exit out of New York, to Paris, hatching a cunning plan to get her and Malcolm out of their money woes. That involves taking their mean cat, Small Frank. Yes, we have a cat as a main character. And it is through this crazy plan, the people they meet, the Paris apartment, and a somewhat predictable outcome, yet tragic finale, that all things go with this story. It will be up to readers to decide whether they want to read it or not....more

review: Elle will have to decide between the world she has made with her much-loved husband Peter, and the life she imagined would be hers with her childhood Elle will have to decide between the world she has made with her much-loved husband Peter, and the life she imagined would be hers with her childhood love, Jonas, if a tragic event hadn’t forever changed the course of their lives. She will have 24 hours. Why would she walk away from her marriage and have “illicit sex” with her childhood love the night before while her husband and children slept inside? And do it while her mother is cleaning the dishes? What has come over her?The story is told in flashbacks and present day. Giving readers a sense of what leads up to this moment. The writing is rich, sharing the New England landscape, the racoons outside and the mice in the ceiling. As readers we are being introduced to the wildness of nature, while the humans place constrictions on their lives and control their animalistic side of themselves. This is an absorbing family saga packed with intrigue and complicated characters that transport readers to Cape Cod. Soon to be an adaptation....more

review: Time to post this  to Goodreads.Liv. Constantine. Actually they are two sisters writing this novel. So, if it feels disconnected in its writing,Time to post this  to Goodreads.Liv. Constantine. Actually they are two sisters writing this novel. So, if it feels disconnected in its writing, maybe that might be a clue. Plot: the book follows 3 major characters - Amber and the rich but troubled Jackson and Daphne Parrish. Amber wants to replace Daphne as Jackson's wife and win all the money that comes with being Mrs. Parrish. But...There is more to the Parrish family than meets the eye. Isn't that typically what we have come to expect for a "psychological thriller?" The plot started slow but picked up. But even as it picked up, the characters were really, really bad people. Malicious. Thankfully there was justice in the story, but it takes so longggg to get there. There was mystery, but it was predictable, but we just needed to figure out the characters motive for doing what they were doing. But, as I mentioned, the writing wasn't my favorite. And was anybody really likable? Content note: language, violence, abuse. Reader direction is advised....more

Also, there is...Excellent execution of an interesting premise (which I choose not to share so that I don’t include any spoilers). This book was clever and fast paced. title: The Golden Spoon
author: Maxwell, Jessa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wanted to read this book because I have a secret passion for The Great British Baking Show, better known in Britian as The Great British Bake Off. HI wanted to read this book because I have a secret passion for The Great British Baking Show, better known in Britian as The Great British Bake Off. How can you not appreciate famous bakers Mary Berry (original), or Prue Leith and Paul Hollywood judging these passionate amateur bakers? And we as viewers get to salivate over the amazing dishes they are baking. For those who are also fans, have you ever tried to bake any of them? And if you did, have you come close to succeeding? (Sorry, I couldn’t help but ask!) Of course, it is the ultimate baking battle for the crown of Best Amateur Baker – given as a glass plate. Now, with this story (yes, finally the  of the book), we have an Americanized version. We are introduced to six amateur bakers who will compete in a tent (sound familiar – to those who may also be fans of the show), vying for the coveted Golden Spoon. (Hence the title of the book!) While competing they will be staying at a beautiful manor in Vermont owned by the famous baker, cookbook author and hostess of Bake Week, Betsy Martin. She has been doing this show solo for 12 years, but now this year she is having to co-host with someone she resents, award winning baker Archie Morris. Archie Morris’ character when described sounds very similar to popular Hell’s Kitchen host, Gordon Ramsay. So, you can imagine how keen Betsy is about having Archie as her co-host. In her mind, he’s just not the right person for her cerebral cooking competition show. Now that we have the basics out of the way…let’s begin at the prologue. It’s a rainy, thundering dark and stormy night. When Betsy ventures out to check if everything is okay out in the tent, she sees red. And it probably isn’t frosting. Did someone conveniently leave something off of their resume when they applied to be an amateur baker for this show? The ultimate exciting beginning to a cozy mystery. Or not. Sound cliché? Do we now get a chance to know what this red is all about? Has a murder occurred – and if it has, can we know who the victim is? Of course not! On we go to meet all the contestants! And this is how the story goes. Each chapter is told in different narrative voices – the competing bakers, and Betsy, over the course of the competition – bread, pie and cake. And it’s not until approximately page 217 that we hear a blood curdling scream (oh sorry, maybe that was me!), and finally we as readers are faced with the body! The victim. By this point, do we care? What will happen now? Who did it? Why? But things aren’t as it seems. There are some twists and turns in this silly who-dun-it. If you are willing to stick with it. Is there justice in the end? Some readers might salivate over the culinary sections, but non-foodies may be bored by all the relentless details. For the record, I really wanted to like this book, but when the characters aren’t even likeable, it makes it very difficult to care what happened next. I hear that this book is in development as a limited series for Hulu. Maybe, that might be a better medium to convey the novel’s intent? And usually, I am one who likes the book better than the movie. Oh my....more

review: This is the first in the Sam Johnstone series. We are introduced to the disabled war veteran who is looking for a simple and peaceful life after many This is the first in the Sam Johnstone series. We are introduced to the disabled war veteran who is looking for a simple and peaceful life after many years of faithful service. So he takes a job as an attorney for a small law firm in a small Wyoming town. Unfortunately, a local woman is murdered, and he ends up defending the suspect who happened to sleep with the victim. Running into walls of politics and bureaucracy, Sam realizes Tommy’s only chance at justice is for the truth to come forward… which isn’t going to be easy. The author attempts to throw readers clues every now and then. At times making us feel as if we are also part of the investigation. Yet…Something was missing. The politics, the bureaucracy…felt like weak plot devices. Almost like social commentary that didn’t quite fit. I was sensitive to Sam’s PTSD and alcoholism, but at times it became too tedious to read. I wanted more law. More courtroom drama. 2.5 stars...more

review: I read this one in 2019, and now I am bringing my  to Goodreads. As I have said numerous times, I don't typically read science fiction fantasy. I read this one in 2019, and now I am bringing my  to Goodreads. As I have said numerous times, I don't typically read science fiction fantasy. (But, sometimes, there is always one that is just the right one. And I let myself in.) It happened here. This particular time travel adventure takes a look at what happens if things in the past are changed by time travelers. Time Travel, you say? Stay with me. There is more to consider.How do you reconcile being stuck in one time period and belonging to another? What are the benefits – the consequences – what do you change in one-time era when you get left behind? What will you do to protect your child? Overall, this book was a real page-turner and a story of love and parenthood that hits your heart in all the right places. Does this mean I am going to read more science fiction fantasy? The jury is still out on that one! Maybe, another Mike Chen book. 4.5 stars....more

review: I was going through my legal thriller stage, and searching through my local library for anything I could check out that matched courtroom dramas. ThisI was going through my legal thriller stage, and searching through my local library for anything I could check out that matched courtroom dramas. This one popped up, so I tried it out. It is the second in the series for Eddie Flynn, a defense attorney. His first was The Defense. I loved that one! You can still read this one as a stand-alone.Premise: Eddie is approached by a federal agent to represent David Child. Child is a billionaire investor of an algorithm that a prestigious law firm is using to launder money. Child is not charged with any white collar crime, and is assured this is an open and shut case. What he is charged with is the murder of his girlfriend. Not all things are going to be simple for Eddie. There is a catch. Or shall we say an incentive. Eddie's wife is also an attorney, and apparently she has signed a paper that could implicate her in an illegal operation that could get her prison time. So... if he can get David to obtain a plea deal, the Feds will drop the case against his wife. What is up with the Feds and this case, really?So Eddie meets David. He believes him to be innocent. But, court cases are not about truth, they are about what can be proved and what a jury will believe. As Eddie attempts to prove his clients case as innocent, things start to happen to Eddie. And as readers, we are treated to page-turning tension. We can also look forward to courtroom drama which is always my favorite kind of reading experience, too....more

author: Castillo, Linda*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…First, let me just say that I am a fan of Chief of police Kate Burkholder, and this series. And…I have a tendency sometimes to read these Catching up…First, let me just say that I am a fan of Chief of police Kate Burkholder, and this series. And…I have a tendency sometimes to read these books out of order. Not on purpose. It just happens with the older books. I read this a while ago and a few of you travelled to my posting of it, only to see that I gave a star , but no written . So…I am now offering my written  of this particular book. And…Let me share that you can read this as a stand-alone, although readers following the books in order will note character development over time. Premise: Rachael was rebellious, and chose to leave her Amish culture behind. Thus, finding herself estranged from her family. But…She decides to return, only to have her homecoming met with immediate tragedy – her murder. So…Why was she coming home? What secrets did she bring with her? Who was threatened by her return? And…As Chief of police, how will Kate solve this crime?Especially…When she was once part of the local Amish community herself, and also knew Rachael as someone who was a fun-loving, mischievous free spirit that she once babysat?The Amish setting is very much a character in this story. The story moves at a steady pace, with much mystery and intrigue. One thing to note…Why the title “Fallen?” It could refer to Rachael’s fall from grace from the Amish perspective. Or it could be about the murderer. Could it be someone seemingly respectable yet driven by desperation to commit murder?It is these kinds of questions that drive this complex story.Trigger warning: there is some brutal violence. ...more

title: The Gifts of Imperfection
author: Brown, Brené*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…This is more a reflection of how I felt about what I read than a … In her book “The Gifts of Imperfection” Brené Brown tells the stoCatching up…This is more a reflection of how I felt about what I read than a … In her book “The Gifts of Imperfection” Brené Brown tells the story of meeting a young woman at a media conference. She is excited to meet this woman because she had bought a beautiful pair of earrings from the woman's online store."How long have you been a jeweler?" Brené asks.Blushing, the young woman answers… "I wish. I'm just a CPA. I'm not a real jeweler.”Brené writes… 'I thought to myself, I'm wearing your earrings right now, not your abacus.' She pointed to her ears… "Of course you're a jeweler." The woman smiles and replies… "Well, I don't make very much money doing that. I just do it because I love it."Since when did our passion require an apology?Or, let’s ask it this way; since when did paying attention to and following our heart require some kind of justification?And tell me, what's the detriment in being “just a” CPA?It's as if there is some capricious seed of scarcity that takes root in our spirit, and measures everything we do, or yearn for, or desire, against some unattainable bar of "not good enough." For whatever else happens, when it comes to our heart, we believe--and convince ourselves--that we're not jeweler enough. Or CPA enough. Or good enough. Or... fill in the blank... enough.There is no doubt that our sense of not enough is exacerbated in a world under a cloud of uncertainty and fear. Days when we don’t have words (or solutions, or prayers) enough. To make things worse we are susceptible to the cultural hook that what we are paid for, is who we are. And we park our identity there in the never ending place of: "So... what do you do?"So... let us Change the question. Instead of ‘what do you do’ – ask yourself and others: ‘what fuels you? What makes you come alive?’ This way we don’t allow our well-being to become attached to the wrong measurement.“Just” Instead... Live in Your Passion....more

title: An Unexplained Death: The True Story of a Body at the Belvedere
author: Brottman, Mikita
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up...I read this a while ago...And...I'm now bringing my  to Goodreads.The book was described as “an obsessive investigation into a mysCatching up...I read this a while ago...And...I'm now bringing my  to Goodreads.The book was described as “an obsessive investigation into a mysterious death at the Belvedere – a once-grand hotel.” So...How could I resist? The third paragraph into the first chapter reads: "The poster is new. I notice it right away, taped to a utility pole. Beneath the word 'Missing, ' printed in a bold, high-impact font, are two sepia-toned photographs of a man dressed in a bow tie and tux."And thus...Begins the author’s obsession into finding not only the man, Ray Rivera, who is missing, but what happened to him once his body is discovered (suicide or homicide?). Like life though...This is not a straight forward true crime book, with easy answers. Still...I found this a fascinating read, to some extent – even though the author rambled through discussions that had no relevance to the subject at hand…i.e., what really happened to Ray Rivera? But...I'll say upfront that I wasn't completely convinced by the final outcome/conclusion.And...That's okay because this is a book that is about the journey, not the destination (even if I wanted a resolution that everyone could agree with in the end). ...more

review: Catching up...(This was written awhile ago, and I am now just posting it. I no longer have Hulu, so I am unaware as to whether the series is still on.Catching up...(This was written awhile ago, and I am now just posting it. I no longer have Hulu, so I am unaware as to whether the series is still on.)Are you aware of the television series, Cardinal? If you have Hulu, check it out. Of course, most series are based on books, so that is what led me to read this one. We had already finished season 1 of the TV series, and are in the midst of Season 2, so I thought I would move ahead to read this book, which Season 3 is based on. Why go backwards when all the spoilers came out in the television episodes? Anyway...I like the character, John Cardinal and was eager to read this book. Giles Blunt is actually considered one of the best mystery writers in Canada, and, I was not disappointed. Thank goodness! Amazing writing, and strong characterization. But...I will warn you, the two storylines are very dark and serious issues that may arise for most any reader. Still...The author’s development of his characters provide a stimulating, page-turning read. ...more

review: I read this a while ago, and when it came in as a donation to my LFL, I had an opportunity for a refresh. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.ReaI read this a while ago, and when it came in as a donation to my LFL, I had an opportunity for a refresh. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Readers learn quite quickly that this is the story about Beth Murphy who has taken elaborate steps to plot her escape from an abusive husband. We also find that Sabine Hardison’s husband comes home to find Sabine is missing. There is one detective very determined to find out what happened to these 2 missing women. The author, goes into immense detail about how Beth planned her escape, what steps she takes to bury her identity, and how and why she chooses Atlanta as her final destination. What readers don’t find out is the name of her abusive husband – because in Beth’s anguished musings, he is you – the reader. (Kind of creepy, right?)Alternating with Beth’s escape narrative is the story of missing wife Sabine. Her husband Jeffrey comes home from a 4-day seminar to find his house empty. Let’s play our own detective, shall we?Beth drives away on Oklahoma’s Muskogee Hwy, she meets an accomplice in Tulsa Oklahoma. Jeffrey and Sabine share a house on the Arkansas River. Could Beth be Sabine? Is the author playing with readers?Beth is doing the been-here-before kind of stuff – the cutting of the hair – dying it – checking into seedy hotels – going back in time with the memories of abuse, et al. Now Ingrid, Sabine’s twin sister is all mad at Jeffrey, wanting to know where she is. She begins to interrogate him. She has no fear of him. But no answers are forthcoming. So, the questions remain. Where is Sabine? And who is Beth? Will Sabine be found alive and will Beth survive if her husband tracks her down?This is a terrifying page-turner with a conclusion that is entirely unexpected. Don’t read this one in the dark....more

review: A book I have read I am now bringing this  to Goodreads. Atlantic City, 1934. Florence Adler is training to swim the English Channel. She dives A book I have read I am now bringing this  to Goodreads. Atlantic City, 1934. Florence Adler is training to swim the English Channel. She dives into the ocean and disappears beneath the waves. Left on the beach are her parents and her niece and a German woman named Anna. Who they don't tell about this tragedy is their other daughter, Fannie, who is pregnant and on hospital bedrest. The secrets and lies insulate her but eventually cocoon the entire family. The story flowed, despite the complexity of the lie and how it affected the various characters. It drew the reader into an intimate family drama which was actually based on the life and tragic death of the author's true great aunt. (Actually, great-great-aunt.) It was a lovely story, skillfully told. But...It had cracks that just made it hard to connect to the characters. So, sometimes I felt close to them, and sometimes, not. Maybe, that is how families are? 3.5 stars....more

title: The Man Who Loved Books Too Much
author: Bartlett, Allison Hoover*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Finally bringing my  to Goodreads.This is about a man obsessed with books. Between 1999 and 2003, John Gilkey used dozens of credit card numbersFinally bringing my  to Goodreads.This is about a man obsessed with books. Between 1999 and 2003, John Gilkey used dozens of credit card numbers acquired from his department store job to steal $100,000 worth of rare books before he was caught and sent to jail. It was through the efforts of one bookseller named Ken Sanders that Gilkey found his way to jail, and Bartlett’s interest as a journalist, that this story found its way into its own book.Bartlett seems to want to make something more of his crime by asking, “what is it about books that made him continually risk jail time for them?” But what we come to learn, through her interviews with him, isn’t his obsession with books, it’s his obsession with stealing, period. On the other hand, we have the thief’s antagonist, Ken Sanders, a “rare-book dealer and self-styled sleuth.” He was the one who helped track down John Gilkey. His job is to protect booksellers from theft and fraud. But what we learn is that his role is mostly sending out e-mail. So, how important is this book really?Who gets more book time in the end? The journalist herself… the author. She even spends time touring a bookstore with Gilkey that he once victimized. The story reads okay, but it lacks depth, because the true-life characters didn’t really have any. 2.5 stars...more

title: When Women Were Dragons
author: Barnhill, Kelly*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…Reading a GR friends beautiful  reminded me that I needed to get mine posted. Alex is a budding scientist, grows up in a small WiscoCatching up…Reading a GR friends beautiful  reminded me that I needed to get mine posted. Alex is a budding scientist, grows up in a small Wisconsin town, in a household full of secrets. No one will tell her why her mother disappears for months, and/or why her unmarried Aunt Marla moves in to take care of the family. Or…Why her father disappears into his work, sometimes not returning home at night. Meanwhile…Something is going on in her community, as women spontaneously “dragon,” erupting that sometimes levels buildings. Of course, these isolated eruptions are suppressed and not discussed by local news or police, and fire crews respond to the “incidents.” Scientists who seek answers to the phenomenon are called in for questioning and blackballed from their universities. Considering this stifling environment, Aunt Marla is a breath of fresh air. As a mechanic in a body shop she stares down men who cross her. Then Aunt Marla disappears during a “mass dragooning” of nearly 650,000 women, leaving a baby behind. Beatrice is adopted as Alex’s “sister,” and any mention of her aunt or dragons is forbidden. Her mother begins obsessively weaving knots, and her parents cut off Alex’s friendship with a neighbor girl, who then disappears. The odder things became, the more Alex is forced to pretend she doesn’t see what she sees.The silence and conformity – “mass forgetting” are as suffocating as a world that uplifts men while constraining women to secondary roles. As a reader it feels like an indictment of a system of gender apartheid.And yet as readers…We have an opportunity to watch Alex navigate her first relationship and find her own path, and shift from the suffocating conformity of the 1950s. But…We can’t help but feel the bruising of the current decisions of the Supreme Court that have affected women, and the push to ban books, and how important freedom is…Especially the voice of women. We don’t ever want to lose that. I believe the author was making a point here. And…It wasn’t subtle. Books can provide important messages that way. But…Did she do it effectively?...more

review: I read this a while ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.This is another Amos Decker thriller, Baldacci’s FBI high-profile consultant, who waI read this a while ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.This is another Amos Decker thriller, Baldacci’s FBI high-profile consultant, who was a former cop and football player. For those who have been following the series, Decker is known as the Memory Man because he was sidelined after a head injury with the most unusual side effect: a perfect photographic memory. This serves him well in investigations. He has a partner, Alex Jamison. Before I begin, I have to say…This may be the most unusual, strange, fun, Decker story yet. The story begins with Decker and Alex being sent to an area to investigate a murder, which is actually controversial in real life. And Baldacci is known for bringing “real life” issues into his fictional stories. In this case, North Dakota is the oil fracking center of the nation, so as readers we are getting a blow by blow on how it is done and what adverse effects it brings. Still…It has been a boom for this small town in which this murder has occurred, making the city fathers very rich, and well, somewhat strange. Now…it gets a bit stranger. Down the road is a sort-of-former Air Force early warning facility that has some mysterious goings-on. Even stranger…A religious cult commune which is next to this sort-of-former Air Force facility, had employed the dead woman as a school teacher, when she wasn’t working as an escort. (Are you following all of this?)The coroner keeps uncovering clues, Decker’s brother-in-law shows up, and the story keeps getting stranger. But as readers, we keep wanting more…information that is! Because this is Baldacci, after all! But then…Who should walk in…but…Super-secret agent/assassin Will Robie and his partner Jessica Reel, accompanied by their super-secret boss Blue Man (from another popular Baldacci series) to help. Did I say this was going to be fun – or what? Just go with it. It is Baldacci....more

review: I read this awhile ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.One of my favorite genres to read is legal thrillers. I love to be in the courtroom. I read this awhile ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.One of my favorite genres to read is legal thrillers. I love to be in the courtroom. I love watching Justice in action. Especially after they have done all the work to catch the “bad guy.” And as readers, we typically know or suspect who the bad guy is, so to see the lawyers work their magic (the authors write it) is always fascinating to me. I also typically like this author. So, I was ready to read this one. Premise: Jason Rich is an attorney. He is an alcoholic who has been reprimanded by the bar for appearing under the influence in court. And now his sister, Jana has been arrested for the murder of her husband. The killer has been arrested but he says he was paid by Jana to do the job. Jana asks Jason to defend her, even though he has never tried a criminal case in his life. Jason decides to take the case on mostly because he cares about his niece. This is the first book in the series, so there is a lot to set up – getting us familiar with Jason, his background and his struggles. This takes up about the first half of the book – and this in some ways drags the book down for me because of all the subplots. Maybe they will show up in future books? Either way, it just seemed to be a bit much, and took away from the story. I also am not one to feel comfortable with a character and their addictions. So, I was glad that not too much attention was put into this other than to make note of it. Still, because this is an issue, it makes me less than comfortable whether it is a character/series I would want to follow. Also, the ending was a bit unsatisfying. Was the author trying to lead us to the next book? And if so, I am not happy that we as readers are being set up in this way. Sorry, no spoilers. Yes, there was courtroom drama. I will give it that…But…For all the other reasons… This is why the stars are low on this one. And why you won’t find me following the Jason Rich series. ...more

title: The Power

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What if women were in charge? Would everyone cry out “reverse sexism?” The novel depicts a world in which women, empowered by a genetic mutation that What if women were in charge? Would everyone cry out “reverse sexism?” The novel depicts a world in which women, empowered by a genetic mutation that enables them to harness and wield electrical currents, ultimately find themselves capable of the same greed and cruelty as their male counterparts. In many ways, this novel wants to be introspective, exploring the many reasons why a paradigm in which gender expression aligns with power – physical, economic, even political – in creating a better world than we want it to be. The premise of this story, is that Neil Armon has written the novel that he turns over to the writer, Naomi Alderman for an early read. In this novel he gives a physical ability to young women (typically teenagers) that spreads quickly as a viral video, simultaneously awakened in girls around the world. This power, an electricity gathered in a physical organ connected to the collarbone called a “skein,” is coursing through their bodies. With the touch of a fingertip, or water, they can shock another person. Torture and kill, too. And thus, the zapping begins. Can you imagine what the world might have looked like with the reversal of the 2016 election?This book does. I won’t go into all the places this plot goes with this zapping – the variety of characters – the satirical upside-down world created between the author’s book world and what does or doesn’t happen. What I will say is…There is truly an underlying message regarding women’s empowerment. My question is…Is this the appropriate way to create this message – through this story? The jury is still out for me. 3.5 stars. ...more

review: One day I came out to the Little Free Library Shed, and my donation basket was full. My heart was overflowing with joy. When I looked inside, I saw maOne day I came out to the Little Free Library Shed, and my donation basket was full. My heart was overflowing with joy. When I looked inside, I saw many John Grisham novels. Now my heart was palpitating! Someone must have given me and this neighborhood heaven on earth! (Okay, I may be exaggerating here – I know not everyone is a Grisham fan, and sometimes, not even I give him 4-5 stars (see above for this one), but, seriously, he really is a good writer, for the most part – and that day was a good day for my LFL!)On to my .Premise: The story begins with young brothers Mark (11) and Ricky (8) witnessing the suicide of a lawyer. But before dying he shares some secrets about the murder of Senator Boyette. The incident leaves Ricky in a coma and Mark shaken. Enter the FBI to solve the murder of Boyette. Mark is terrified something is going to happen to him so he refuses to talk. Reggie a lawyer is assigned to help Mark. There are some good characters here. Mark for one. He’s young. Brave. Courageous. Strong. Fierce, while being naïve, terrified and willing to cry. Reggie the lawyer. Sweet, tough, funny with heart. Also, strong and fierce when it was called for. She could also be witty and sly.Judge Harry cared about the kid’s welfare. We don’t always see this, and he was portrayed well. The story gives excellent insight into child mentality while also touching on some of the social aspects of child delinquency.The suspense of the story is quite compelling. There are other areas of the story which moved slowly and seemed over-used as the criminal element. (Won’t say because I don’t want to give away any spoilers.)Yet...The story is good with some action and suspense and courtroom drama to keep readers engaged.Still…The end. Emotional. (I am not going to say why. I’m just going to say, I felt abandoned. – If you have read this, did you, too?) 3.5 stars. ...more
