title: Daisy Jones & The Six
author: Reid, Taylor Jenkins*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this long before the tv adaptation came out. I am now bringing my book  to Goodreads.The book opens with a question no one appears to havI read this long before the tv adaptation came out. I am now bringing my book  to Goodreads.The book opens with a question no one appears to have the answer to: Why did Daisy Jones & The Six (a fictional) group that has the charisma of Fleetwood Mac and the artistry of Joni Mitchell, break up at the height of their popularity? Told in a series of interviews (the book is made up entirely of dialogue from the members of the band and their inner circle), the story gives readers a backstage view of the epic rise and agonizing fall of the band.For those who love music, 70's rock n'roll, you can feel it playing out of the pages. For those who grew up during that time (myself included) I can see a turntable spinning nearby and feel the passion of that troubled era. But, that doesn't necessarily mean I liked that troubled era either.Still...There is a lot to appreciate about this story. Nostalgia. Rock n'roll. (I know, I said that...but, it is the key to the story.)And much to cringe about too. (I wasn't a fan of the drugs/addiction - even hated watching what it did to my peers.) And some of the characters. Well not always likable. Any way you look at it, this story will tug at some hearts. Hit nerves and create discomfort for others. Me included. So, it wasn't my favorite, but it was still good. ...more

title: Finding Me
author: Davis, Viola
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…I remember my first time seeing Viola Davis on television. She played Annalise Keating in “How to Get Away with Murder.” I was mesmerized Catching up…I remember my first time seeing Viola Davis on television. She played Annalise Keating in “How to Get Away with Murder.” I was mesmerized by her smart, sassy, hypnotic performances each week. The depth of her acting was fierce and I remember my husband and I shaking our heads each week wondering…Who is she really? When her memoir came out, I was first in line to check it out at my local library. I wanted to know more about the person behind the persona. By this time, I had now had the opportunity to see several of her movies and other television productions. I was definitely a fan. I had already determined that she was an astonishingly, multidimensional, superbly, talented and gifted actor. What would her story reveal to me, as a reader?Her memoir opens with a telling scene from her childhood. An upbringing marked by trauma, that undoubtedly took years to process. This scene involved bullying, something that would follow her throughout her young life.“This was one more piece of trauma I was experiencing – my clothes, my hair, my hunger, too – and my home life being the big daddy of them all. The attitude, anger and competitiveness were my only weapons.” And thus…We know where she came from and why…And what motivated her to be what she would become. Her home life is described matter-of-factly. She doesn’t downplay any of it. We will read the good, the bad and the ugly of it. And…It becomes all too clear, how the angry, defensive child – with everything against her – would have just enough fight in her – to go on to Juilliard – because of that same fight in her – to eventually win two Tony awards. She also won an Emmy for “How to Get Away with Murder.” This memoir is also a testimonial to the hard work it takes to overcome adversity. And…It also is great advice for aspiring actors. She is a prideful, Black woman, hoping for more opportunities for other Black women that won’t just be relegated to a convenient folder labeled “Black performers.” Still…It is about joy with life. Her prose is forthright and supple and delightful and direct. An excellent read....more

title: Of Mice and Men
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a short book that we read during my last weeks as the facilitator of my library book discussion group. Let me say, even for a novella, this isThis is a short book that we read during my last weeks as the facilitator of my library book discussion group. Let me say, even for a novella, this is an amazing selection for a discussion with a group of people. It is a tragic story that touches on class struggle, race, sexism, alongside the main theme of friendship and loyalty. George and Lennie are journeying on foot through rural Depression-era CA. They are headed towards a ranch where they hope to get work. George is small and sharp, but can be easily frustrated. Lennie is huge but very simple-minded and impulsive. The two together are trouble. Yet, they also have a dream of the future where they hope to work their own land and have a simple life. In many ways we hope that George and Lennie can realize their dreams. But, you also know that Steinbeck isn't that kind of writer to make it easy on his characters. He sets too many other things in motion that creates conflict. And through this short novella, there are powerful scenes, relevant themes with much room for interpretation. Is this the American Dream? What about the imbalance of power? Were the characters more caricatures than characters because the story was short? Whatever anyone thinks about this story, it makes one think. And talk about it. That in itself makes it good....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you have been following me, you have probably noticed a lot of s lately...it is me catching up on a lot of books I have read, but have not yeIf you have been following me, you have probably noticed a lot of s lately...it is me catching up on a lot of books I have read, but have not yet posted the s. So here is one of them for Goodreads now. Lo, our main character is in a shaky relationship with her boyfriend. One night while he is away, her place is burgled, and she is attacked by someone who seems intent on harming her. Her boyfriend returns to comfort her for a few days, but then he leaves, and then she leaves for an assignment. Her assignment as a reporter on a cruise ship leads her directly into a supposed murder scene. I say supposed, because it appears that only Lo seems to be the one to have "witnessed" the event. Apparently Lo has been taking anti-depressants and drinking (a lot), so her accounting of what occurred is not something to be exactly trusted, since nobody else seems to believe her, and no body seems to have been found. Of course, by the time any one is rounded up, where is the body? Now, being on a cruise ship, it is almost like this is a locked room scenario. So the killer must be on board, and does any of this have to do with the burglary and/or attack to Lo prior to the cruise? Lo's POV sometimes feels misleading, unreliable, and the drug-induced affects just gets to be too much. The constant reference to her "state of mind", and drinking ... well it grew tiresome. After awhile I wasn't sure I could believe anything - or whether I cared, or if I wanted to believe anything. The overall (plot) storyline seemed like it could be intriguing, but by the time it got to the ending I felt somewhat exhausted and disappointed. Yes there was suspense, but it was chaotic, and that didn't work for me. 2.5 stars....more

title: We Should All Be Feminists
author: Adichie, Chimamanda Ngozi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…Another Library Book Discussion selection. Not unexpected since we had also discussed Americanah. Review here: https://www.goodreads.com/rCatching Up…Another Library Book Discussion selection. Not unexpected since we had also discussed Americanah. Review here: https://www.goodreads.com//show.... And not surprisingly, we had a lot of men in the group, as well. Which…Added a fresh and engaging perspective to the discussion. In this small, but mighty book, the author’s intention was not only to shine the light on feminism but to redefine it by making readers aware of what she believed has been the “blatant discrimination and insidious, institutional behaviors that marginalize women around the world.”Her intention was to showcase cultural biases, by showing how the culture treats boys and girls differently, and how the gender divide could be harmful for women and men alike. “We do a great disservice to boys in how we raise them. We stifle the humanity of boys.” She argues that feminism aims to deconstruct gender roles and binaries that are harmful to males, too. Through our discussion we wondered if gender privilege for men came at a price. As readers, we could surmise that her hope is that we as a society can affect change. She shares a desire for hope by creating a reframing of feminism in the modern era.And yet…She was still shining a light on her awareness of invisibility as a woman of color. And…Of women in general. And wondered if that would ever change for women. There was a section in the book where she discussed how women feel the need to dress like men in certain situations in order to gain more respect. We wondered how that made each of us feel – men and women alike. And…Why? Is it because of the definitions we assign to gender within our society and culture?This was an amazing book discussion selection. Her book had so many relevant issues to address. And…So many questions to uncover and strip away about gender roles and identity and respect and the gap between male and female success and mobility. Highly recommended....more

title: The Murder of Roger Ackroyd        (Hercule Poirot, #4)
author: Christie, Agatha
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Did you know that in 2013 a group of 600 professional writers in the Crime Writers' Association voted this book the best crime novel in history? I agrDid you know that in 2013 a group of 600 professional writers in the Crime Writers' Association voted this book the best crime novel in history? I agree. This novel is worth the acclaim. It was perfectly planned and expertly executed. Mysteries should be cunning and clever, and Ms. Christie was brilliant with this one. The title tells us that Roger Ackroyd is murdered, and the story attempts to sift through various clues to determine who committed the crime. There are many culprits. It appears so standard on the surface as to what could have happened, but it is anything but standard. What is masterful about the plot is that we are kept guessing until the end. And that has a lot to do with the characters, and the narration. But most importantly is the end. What makes it so climactic is the build up without the reader being aware of where it is going. Even if we suspect, the ending is still SO satisfying it leaves readers much room for plenty of theorizing and contemplation. Brilliant. Brilliant. Brilliant. Thank you Madame Christie....more

review: On the first anniversary of Arthur’s wife, Miriam’s death, he discovers a charm bracelet of hers with a phone number. He decides to call it, and discoOn the first anniversary of Arthur’s wife, Miriam’s death, he discovers a charm bracelet of hers with a phone number. He decides to call it, and discovers something about his wife he never thought possible. He was married to her for 40 years. How is one to feel when learning a secret he never knew about her? This charm bracelet leads him on a journey away from a life he has always known to something out of his comfort zone. Arthur is a seemingly ordinary person, who now must come to terms about the revelations about his wife and her past. Will he be able to process it? Will he make peace with it? Will he be able to come to terms with his loss of Miriam and embrace the people that are still in his life?This is a story of self-discovery. This is the story of a journey - and the many interesting characters met along this journey. The characters are well-drawn, likable and charming – especially Arthur. The book moves at a good pace. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…Lucy Barton is a distance relative of Olive Kitteridge. Review here: https://www.goodreads.com//show... She is a writer who is quiteCatching Up…Lucy Barton is a distance relative of Olive Kitteridge. Review here: https://www.goodreads.com//show... She is a writer who is quite attached to books, because, “they made me feel less alone.” And…So, her point was if she wrote, others would feel less alone, too. Lucy’s story is about loneliness. It shares glimpses of her childhood of hardship, shunned by her Amgash classmates, as well as, living in a world not quite open to hugs by her adult friends in New York. In fact, her current friends wouldn’t have an understanding of what it was like to live with little heat, or food or no books, or no magazines or tv. So…Now, there was a lot for Lucy to catch up on. This is a story, too about Lucy’s time in the hospital with a mysterious infection for almost 9 weeks in New York in the mid-80’s. At that time, she had a husband and 2 small daughters aged 5 and 6, but she had been largely estranged from her parents since her marriage. Mostly, her father, didn’t like her husband because he was of German extraction with “blond German looks.” And… As a WWII veteran, that was blasphemy for his daughter to marry someone of German descent. But…Because Lucy is in the hospital, her mother comes for a visit, and she remains in the hospital room with her the entire stay. And…Slowly the ice between them melts. While…Spending time gossiping about the fates of some of the girls and women of Lucy’s youth. But…They don’t talk about Lucy’s dad. Or her brother. Or her present life in NY. Or even her present success as an author. Or even her young family and new friends. Lucy was just happy to have her mother with her.For readers, we can reflect on family. Solace and love. The need for healing. The importance of mothers. Forgiveness. Redemption. The words: I love you. When not being said, but how much it is felt. A story filled with emotion. From darkest suffering to simple joy....more

title: All the Light We Cannot See
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This story is about a blind French girl named Marie-Laure and a German boy, Werner whose paths collide in occupied France as both try to survive the dThis story is about a blind French girl named Marie-Laure and a German boy, Werner whose paths collide in occupied France as both try to survive the devastation of WWII.It alternates between multiple perspectives, but we read it from their POV’s. Marie-Laure lives in Paris near the Museum of Natural History where her father works. When she is 12, the Nazis occupy Paris and they flee to live with their uncle by the sea. They take with them a valuable and dangerous jewel from the museum. In a mining town in Germany, Werner, an orphan, grows up with his younger sister, enchanted by a crude radio they find that brings them news and stories from places they have never seen or imagined. Werner becomes an expert at building and fixing crucial new instruments and is enlisted to use his talent during the resistance. It is clear that Werner does not believe in the Nazis even though he is forced to join them. “Werner is succeeding. He is being loyal. He is being what everybody agrees is good. And yet every time he wakes and buttons his tunic, he feels he is betraying something.” (Page 250)What will be key here, are not just the characters and what they “see” or “hear” but what the importance will be with the jewel. How will their lives intersect and why will it be important? Doerr has a way with words, his description of things, his flair for aesthetics. Did I sense a little magical realism here? Werner is supposed to be a villain. He is after all a Nazi, right? But why are we liking him? There is conflict here, and yet we are watching and waiting as to how the author is going to bring Marie-Laure and Werner together, because isn’t that the eventual intent? As readers, isn’t that what we are wanting? “My God, there are none so distant that fate cannot bring them together.” (page 120)...more

review: I read this before I exited my role as a library book discussion leader. This was one of the books that was discussed. I read it, but happened to be gI read this before I exited my role as a library book discussion leader. This was one of the books that was discussed. I read it, but happened to be gone the day it was discussed, but set up the questions for my "substitute" so they could lead the discussion. As far as I knew, they had an exciting time with this book. I have no doubt. How could they not? This, after all, is Tina Fey. This book is comprised mostly of humorous tidbits from her journey to stardom. She also gives advice to women in the workforce. What was obvious was the messages she wanted to get across: She wasn't there to play second to a man, she was there to do what she wanted to do whether they liked it or not. She also shares strong advice for women: 1) Use their voice. 2) Speak in statements rather than apologetic questions. She writes, "Don't be fooled, you're not in competition with other women, you're in competition with everyone." Bottom line, the book seemed to be just her talking to us about ideas on how to be successful in this life - with humor thrown in....more

title: When Breath Becomes Air
author: Kalanithi, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this before my mother passed away almost 5 years ago. I remember how sad I felt about his diagnosis of cancer, and yet, how moved I was by his I read this before my mother passed away almost 5 years ago. I remember how sad I felt about his diagnosis of cancer, and yet, how moved I was by his courage. This man was so inspiring to me. His book was moving, even though there was much to read about what he was personally experiencing was heart-breaking and obviously fatal. Because…We have a young, once vibrant 36-year-old non-smoker, neurosurgeon with lung cancer. He was a rising star at Stanford University School of Medicine when he first began to experience weight loss, and severe back pain that led him to see a fellow physician which would reveal multiple tumors and his diagnosis. In that single moment, he writes, “the future I imagined, the one just about to be realized, the culmination of decades of striving, evaporated.” As readers, we can’t help but feel his heartbreak, too. Because this diagnosis not only stole his future, it stole his identity. He asks, “Who would I be, going forward, and for how long?” How many times in life have we gone through a life introspection? The why am I here – where do I want to go now? What am I meant to do now? Kinds of questions. We are given great insights into his medical training, his steady diet of literature, his learned background, his contemplative disposition and his kindness. Many times, we understand that some doctors want to become doctors for the money, status, and what they can gain from their position. For him, he wanted to “forge relationships with the suffering, and to keep following the question of what makes humans life meaningful, even in the face of death and decay.” And now what about his own? Here he is as a patient. His words are endearing for his honesty. We watch him persevere through tortuous chemo treatments. But he was unable to finish the book. His wife, Lucy wrote the epilogue, and finished the manuscript. Even Abraham Verghese’ foreword adds some perspective to the first-person account.There are so many moments in the book. Kleenex please. Holding his child for the first time, as he lies on a cot in the same hospital room where his wife has just given birth to their daughter, he writes, “the possibilities of life emanated before us.” And yet, a few pages later he says we are reminded that only memory and words, “have a longevity I do not.” Please…Pass the Kleenex. 4.5 stars...more

title: Chestnut Street
author: Binchy, Maeve
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…This book was recently donated to my Little Free Library Shed, so it gave me an opportunity to re-visit these wonderful short stories agaiCatching Up…This book was recently donated to my Little Free Library Shed, so it gave me an opportunity to re-visit these wonderful short stories again. I always enjoyed reading Maeve Binchy short stories in-between my novels. She was such a cozy writer in so many ways. Besides, what better way to travel to Chestnut Street in Dublin, Ireland and meet up with the neighbors?Binchy was such a lyrical writer, too. (This book was published after her death in 2012.) You almost feel like you are one of the many people present in the story. In this collection, her husband tells us in the introduction that Binchy wrote the stories over a period of decades, with the intention of tying them together so that they just would flow between each other. Her editors attempted to do that with the 36 they collected for this volume.Readers can sense the feeling of community and connection through the lives and loves and relationships of the various individuals who come and go through the pages. What I have always loved about Binchy is her ability to capture human nature in such a realistic way. Even if there is tension, or more questions than answers, there is a story to be told, and characters and settings that have been brought to life. Sometimes characters may even pop over into another story. Most importantly, it reminds us that there is something important about being a neighbor. When was the last time you said hello to yours?...more

review: Catching up…This  came up on my Facebook page under memories. At the time, I was sharing that we would be discussing this in our Library Book DiCatching up…This  came up on my Facebook page under memories. At the time, I was sharing that we would be discussing this in our Library Book Discussion Group in 2017. And…That this was the author’s companion novel to her 2013 bestseller Life After Life in which she brings back familiar characters…But…Creates many new ones, with different ends. So…Why is God in Ruins?The author wants readers to see that a man is a god in ruins. The quote she shares by Ralph Waldo Emerson from his essay “Nature” says…“When men are innocent, life shall be longer, and shall pass into the immortal, as gently as we wake from dreams.” This is a sprawling, epic novel. But…A God In Ruins doesn’t follow Life After Life's mysterious central plot device. It has one of its own, but it's a familiar literary trope that felt like an afterthought…Especially…When it doesn’t do it’s reveal until literally the last few pages. Instead…The book's strengths come from seemingly infinite possibilities. Both novels spread across generations, tracking the changes decades bring to societies and individuals. Both delve deeply into the experience of war, the pain of the aftermath, and the way history casually swallows so many deeply personal details.But…This one still had a flow to it, that made readers want to discover it’s potential. Which…Made this a great discussion book. ...more

review: Catching up…I read this one quite some time ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I didn’t think of this book until one of my Goodreads frCatching up…I read this one quite some time ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I didn’t think of this book until one of my Goodreads friends, Renee told me about how she felt about it when responding to my  of “The Fury.” Renee’s  of “The Girl on the Train” is here: https://www.goodreads.com//show... So, after my “conversation” with Renee, I thought, the least I could do was catch up on my  of this one. Afterall, it is one of the most checked out and donated books in my Little Free Library Shed. I wonder…is that a good thing?So why just a 1-star rating?Well, I didn’t like anybody. Especially our unreliable main narrator, Rachel. It was definitely difficult to feel any sympathy or empathy for her obsessions about her ex-husband and/or blackouts because of her unhealthy relationship with alcohol. Memory and imagination are definitely confused here. And that to me is an annoying plot trick. At least in this story.Also, readers are being led in different directions because of the shifting timelines and alternating points of view. Which makes it hard to keep up with what is, what isn’t and what’s what. The physical violence and mental manipulation were also hard to read. And there just didn’t seem to be any character to root for or care about in this story. Even though the author insisted we do with the various positions she put her women in. title: Bel Canto
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was another one of our favorite authors with our Library Book Discussion group. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Did you know that this This was another one of our favorite authors with our Library Book Discussion group. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Did you know that this book was actually based on a true story? Set in South America, readers find themselves in a large room filled with mostly affluent bureaucrats and CEO’s that are suddenly taken hostage by terrorists during a beautiful soprano opera performance by the book’s female lead, Roxanne Coss. The story remains in that same setting, and the hostages are held captive for over 4 months. So what was intended to be just hours, turned into days and then months of standoff. And... Patchett shows readers exactly how universal humanity is... Our cares, our fears, our talents, our values, our love. Where what once was terrorists vs hostages now blurs and becomes a giant group of humans, together. Are we now seeing friendships forming? Maybe even romance? Or…Are we experiencing Stockholm Syndrome? (feelings of trust or affection felt in many cases of kidnapping or hostage-taking by a victim toward a captor.)Are the hostages learning to adjust to this new normal – finding ways to appreciate their spouses better? And the terrorists – some were teenagers with minds and talents – being used in this heartless way – could we humanize them?And then there is Roxanne Coss. Her voice and her music touches everybody. There is something magical and lyrical about her voice that seems to calm everyone. The beautiful, tender, lyrical language. The character development. And then…What was the point of that epilogue? Everything was going so well until then. Is that really how you are going to end this? I’m not sure I could accept it....more

review: Catching Up…This is the story of Jean Perdu, a middle-aged bookseller who lives in an apartment house in the Marais with some very interesting neighboCatching Up…This is the story of Jean Perdu, a middle-aged bookseller who lives in an apartment house in the Marais with some very interesting neighbors. He has a bookshop on a barge in the Seine that he calls the Literary Apothecary, because he doesn’t just sell books, he prescribes them to suit psychic ills he diagnoses to his customers. Yet…He can’t seem to cure his own depression.Which…Is caused by the disappearance of his great love who left 20 years earlier. We eventually learn that her name was Manon. Soon…Catherine arrives. A tearful almost-divorcee with no furniture who moves into the flat opposite Perdu. He gives her a table that he locked away since Manon’s disappearance. She discovers a “Dear Jean” letter that she forces him to open. As it turns out, Manon left him to return to her husband in Provence because she had been diagnosed with cancer, and in the letter she had begged him to come to her and say goodbye. 20 years too late, Perdu is guilt-and grief-stricken. Despite the attraction he has begun to feel toward Catherine he decides to go to Provence to find either Manon or her widower. But…Instead of buying a ticket via train or plane, he decides to cast off the lines and sets sail with the Literary Apothecary… And…“…travel south by water to find answers to (his) dreams.” With friend in tow, and his cats, off they go. Along the way, more shipmate passengers accompany them. Will Jean find love and his dreams on this journey to Provence? Sometimes…With hope, and new found friends and a few books and something to look forward to…Maybe that is all that is needed on a literary ship bound towards Provence. ...more

review: I read this one awhile ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads."We are not quite novels. We are not quite short stories. In the end, we are I read this one awhile ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads."We are not quite novels. We are not quite short stories. In the end, we are collected works."A book about books, bookstores and book lovers. How can I not be in love? The sign above the bookstore (Island Books) of this story says, "No Man is an Island: Every Book is a World." Perfect. Yes?So, AJ Fikry is a cantankerous guy who happens to own Island Books in the fictional resort village of Alice Island, off the coast of Massachusetts. The novel begins with an encounter between Fikry and Amelia, a publisher sales rep, which goes poorly, due to his bad behavior. Now, let's not be all mean about Fikry. He is suffering, his wife has recently died. Book sales are down. He doesn't have any friends. And his prized asset (his retirement) "Tamerlane" a rare collection of poetry by Edgar Allen Poe has been stolen. The chief of police, Chief Lambiase, who is kind, gets involved because of the burglary. Now...moving on...Fikry's life becomes complicated when a precocious 2 year old named Maya is abandoned in his bookstore. It is determined that her mother drowned. So, Fikry adopts her. Moving on...Life is transformed for everyone. The author adds twists, makes it enjoyable, even if it is a predictable story. Of course, what makes it especially delicious for me, is that the main focus of this book, are the books and the character's relationship with them. Each chapter begins with a shelf talker - a mini  of a classic novel which are penned by Fikry. I was in love with the story and the premise and the characters. Even though there was sadness and misfortune, it is a moving story. Mostly it is a celebration of reading and BOOKS! We need more of this in today's world! 4.5 stars...more

He appears haunted by a cThis is the story of Tony Webster, the 60-ish protagonist of the novel. He is a retired divorcee living in suburban England. He appears haunted by a chain of incidents that occurred when he was a teenager in the early 1960's. Most significantly it was when one of his friends commits suicide after he had made a girl pregnant. Even as we visit that past event and his boyhood friends, they graduate and go their separate ways. We see Tony at university where he meets his first girlfriend, Veronica. That relationship doesn't work out for him, and she goes off to date his friend Adrian, who then he learns commits suicide. Tony meets another girl, marries her, has a child and appears to forget the whole situation about Veronica and Adrian. His wife has an affair and they divorce. Years later he receives from Adrians mother some money and his diary. Tony learns more than he ever imagined. The question for me as the reader is did I really care for the introspective musings from a middle-aged, self-centered protagonist who tried to find meaning in a rather mundane, uneventful life? Could Tony ever have been a better friend if he even tried once to get out of his head? Thankfully this was a short book....more

title: Being Mortal: Medicine and What Matters in the End
author: Gawande, Atul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…It was December 2016 when our Library Book Discussion group decided to read and discuss this book. It seemed appropriate at the time. A loCatching up…It was December 2016 when our Library Book Discussion group decided to read and discuss this book. It seemed appropriate at the time. A lot of us were dealing with either aging parents, or our own feelings about death and dying. His focus was on assisted living. I was caregiving my mother, and my husband was caregiving his father in the same assisted living environment. So, this discussion and book was very personal for me, at the time. My Mom and father-in-law have since passed on. (Interestingly, within two weeks of each other.) But I remember how helpful this book was for me, and the group of men and women who surrounded me in discussion that day. We shared how to distill what mattered most to each of us in life so that we could navigate our way toward the edge in a meaningful and satisfying way. I won’t go into the various stories that he shares about the different people through his pages, I think that is best read by readers, but he did bring up a variety of heartfelt statements that were meaningful discussion moments for us as a group. As an example…“It is not death that the very old tell me they fear. It is what happens short of death.” In our discussion, we wondered how our family would feel about telling them, “I’m ready to go” or even if we would know how we would feel when we were ready to go. It was that fine line about striking a balance between fear of death and just being ready to let go. I remember that this wasn’t an easy discussion to have with my mother. Especially as her mind began slipping from the Dementia with Lewy Bodies/Parkinson’s Disease. One day, my mother shared with me that she was afraid of her own pending death. I tried to calm her. I remember her asking me what stage she was in of Parkinson’s disease. And I tried to explain it to her as sensitively as I could. I found out that after I left, her caregiver called me and said she was in tears, because she thought she was going to die soon. I drove back to her immediately, to calm her again and reassure her that wasn’t the case. I realized then, that this was only the beginning that things were going downhill for her – mind. So much of our discussion about this book, talked about the various fears and challenges associated about end-of-life. The book asked us to consider…How can we appreciate, honor, value a life, our well-being to live and die in dignity?I certainly appreciated the experience of this book in working with my mother through her end-of-life. The author may not have all the answers in this book, but he definitely opened the conversation....more

review: Catching Up…There is something about Alice Hoffman that makes her an exceptional storyteller. She has a way of crafting a character, that makes readerCatching Up…There is something about Alice Hoffman that makes her an exceptional storyteller. She has a way of crafting a character, that makes readers feel engaged.This was another Library Book Discussion selection. The museum is a Coney Island boardwalk attraction presided over by Professor Sardie. Inside live various people with various unusual characteristics and unusual names – i.e., Wolfman, the Butterfly Girl, the Goat Boy, the Bird Woman, the Bee Woman and so forth. Also, living with Sardie, is his “daughter,” Coralie, who has, from the age of 10, spent hours suspended in a tank of water playing the human mermaid for paying customers. And…As she has gotten older, he insists she perform lewd for paying customers after hours. Coralie, who narrates part of the story, has a freakish affinity for water. Her father has trained her to swim extraordinary distances, even in the icy November Atlantic, most often at night. She is at home in the tidal currents of the Hudson River. Coralie also hides a secret shame. She was born with webbed fingers. She hides them when she is not playing the human mermaid. As it so happens…There are sightings of a sea monster in the Hudson River. And of course, Professor Sardie wants this monster as part of his living displays for his museum. Little does he know, that it is his own 18-year-old Coralie. In the meantime, one evening, on one of her nocturnal swims, Coralie emerges and catches a glimpse of a reclusive photographer named Ezekiel Cohen who likes to walk his dog in the woods of northern Manhattan. He has abandoned his Jewish faith, and changed his name to Eddie. Eddie has his own history.He was witness to the terrible Triangle shirtwaist factory fire, and he is attempting to solve the mystery of a young woman’s disappearance. Once Coralie and Eddie discover each other, their mystical attraction and mutual obsession become forces of their own, driving the story forward. There is so much to love and hate about this story. Girls with unusual talents, love at first sight, mysterious parents, addiction and alcoholism, orphans raised by unsuitable people, how people treat others that are different….I can go on. But…It is Alice Hoffman. And…As a storyteller, she does mesmerize readers with her words. And that…If nothing else…Makes for a great discussion....more

review: I read and discussed this awhile ago with our library book group and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. This is a Pulitzer Prize winner. Does iI read and discussed this awhile ago with our library book group and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. This is a Pulitzer Prize winner. Does it mean it is a good or a great book? I will be blunt with my personal opinion. My answer: No. Premise: This is the story of a teenager. Theo Decker. He survives a terrorist bombing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art while losing his mother in the attack. He walks off with the real-life 1654 masterpiece, The Goldfinch. And off we go with this story.This is a 784 page book. Another one of those books where the author feels they have a lot of story to tell. It is sprawling. It has larger-than-life characters. There are dark deeds. Surprising twists. And in the end, an emotional kick in the gut. Stephen King called this book, "a smartly written library novel that connects with the heart as well as the mind." Readers around the world agreed with him. Except this reader. Me. Maybe a few in my library group, too. I kept wondering if I was reading the same book he was? I remember sitting around the table with fellow book enthusiasts and we asked the question, what makes a work literature, and who gets to decide - especially whether it is worthy of a Pulitzer? We shook our heads and decided we really couldn't answer these simple questions - especially as it applied to The Goldfinch. Our complaint: the book seems to represent itself as serious fiction - but in our experience, we weren't feeling it. Some of the characters were more like caricatures. As far as the story, how will Theo get out of his situation? How will he grow up? Why did we have more questions than answers. It just seemed like the plot kept going on and on and on - but to where? And the characters - were any of them even likable? Most importantly...Is this a book that stands the test of time? You know like Steinbeck, or Jane Austen, or the Bronte sisters, or Wallace Stegner. You tell me. ...more

review: Josef Weber has been an important member of his community. Well-respected. But he has been holding a secret. He is a murderer. He decides to confess tJosef Weber has been an important member of his community. Well-respected. But he has been holding a secret. He is a murderer. He decides to confess to Sage Singer. She is a young woman who has trusted him as her friend. His truth shatters her experience of him. How do you work through the horrors of war to the person you have known? How do you find forgiveness? Obviously, Josef has off-loaded his story onto Sage. And now Sage has to reconcile this. The content wasn't always easy to read. But it was important. Powerful. This is where Picoult's research benefits her storytelling. Picoult examines the strength of human nature even when humanity is at its worst, making the book immersive - emotionally wrenching. The characters feel authentic. Believable. We experience the guilt, grief, forgiveness, human history, loyalty, obedience, power, racism, family, relationships, and what it takes for survival in every form. This book is multi-layered leaving us with an ending that is...(spoiler free from me.) ...more

review: Our Library Book Discussion group enjoyed this experience years ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.If anyone is looking for a fun book discOur Library Book Discussion group enjoyed this experience years ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.If anyone is looking for a fun book discussion selection, go here. Hilarity ensues with this one! It is a screwball comedy about a brilliant, emotionally challenged geneticist who is determined to find a suitable wife. His way of doing it…Design his own questionnaire with the help of a patently unsuitable woman who keeps distracting him from his search. Of course, you have to appreciate the sweetness and charm with Don Tillman’s (our protagonist) geekiness. As our narrator, we can appreciate how appealing he is despite his eccentricities.What is obvious is that humans typically can’t see what is clearly in front of them, and that is what this book seems to play off of really well. And… Don’s character who is somewhere on the autism spectrum, is oblivious about his attraction to Rosie Jarman, a beautiful doctoral candidate in psychology. Because he can’t get his social cues, he thinks she is part of his “wife project.” Rosie, on the other hand, is on a Rosie “father project” trying to identify her biological father. The two are fun to watch. This book is charming, warm-hearted, amusing. Sharp dialogue. Terrific pacing. A couple to root for. Twists, too....more

review: This is a story about 17-year-old Mia who is in a car accident with her parents and 10-year-old brother. She survives but remains in a coma in criticaThis is a story about 17-year-old Mia who is in a car accident with her parents and 10-year-old brother. She survives but remains in a coma in critical condition. As readers, we see her watch everything around her as she decides whether she will stay or let go and die. The story is told in flash backs, showing her life as a normal teenager living in Oregon with a brilliant life as a cellist and her prospects of going to Julliard before her. We also see her relationship blossoming with her boyfriend Adam, who also has a passion for music. And...We are also aware of her close-knit family. 'If I Stay' is a reminder of how short and innately sweet life is, and how we can’t take advantage of those people who matter most to us in our lives. Some ers saw this as sappy, and full of teen angst. At the time I read it, I guess I was up for just letting the feelings flow. I could feel the emotion. Sometimes it was… heart-wrenching and heart-warming, and at times funny. 3.5 stars.The movie version was released in August 2014. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Whenever his book was made into a movie, I always wanted to read the book first, and this is what led me here. I am finally bringing my  to GoodWhenever his book was made into a movie, I always wanted to read the book first, and this is what led me here. I am finally bringing my  to Goodreads.Premise: This book takes place in Germany, and has 3 primary POV’s, though Le Carre adds a few more later. The central protagonist is Issa Karpov, the son of a Russian war criminal and his Chechen “war bride.” Issa claims to have been tortured in prison. He now appears to readers as a traumatized refugee in Hamburg being sheltered by a couple of frightened Turkish immigrants. He seeks help from Annabel, a German civil rights attorney, who is sympathetic to his story, and attracted to him, as well. Issa leads her to Tommy Brue, a British banker, whose bank stashed his father’s fortune. Annabel seeks him out. Issa says he wants to become a doctor. Brue also wants to help Issa out, because he finds himself attracted to Annabel. Although it appears like a potential love triangle, nothing more than touching hands occurs. Apparently, as Annabel and Tommy attempt to help Issa, the Germans, the British and the Americans all want a piece of him. Why?The author appears to be doing a critique on the war on terror, but if that is all readers see, then the point is missed. Issa can be any stateless individual from the wrong place with the wrong background. No one really cares about his religion, only what he knows and who he knows. Le Carre does a good job of not being too preachy, but if he was attempting suspense, he failed at it. The story line is rather predictable. Still…The author attempts to write a complicated and compelling story. This isn’t necessarily a spy thriller, as the spies take a background seat, and the civilians take center stage.What we have here are grubby, believable, morally compromised protagonists. The question then becomes…Which was better – the book or the movie?...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was another library book discussion selection that I got to lead a time ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I want to start out by beinThis was another library book discussion selection that I got to lead a time ago. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.I want to start out by being honest with you. I am conflicted about this one. This is a story about the Iraq war. It was a finalist for the National Book Awards, and one of the New York Times 10 best books of 2012. It also won the PEN/Hemingway award. In many ways it was a beautiful book, about this man's experience, but it was difficult to read, to discuss, because there are so many opinions about it (and I'm not just referring to the book). The war in Iraq was horrible, and such an infuriating and heartbreaking mistake. It was so costly to so many, and this author, captures much of that. He wants those of us who were untouched by the war to experience it from his perspective - what it meant - the damage it created to those who fought it - and the book brings it out. So what is my problem?Before I go there. Yellow Birds is described as a "story of two soldiers trying to stay alive." The narrator is 21 year old Bartie and an even younger soldier, Murphy, that Bartie befriends. The setting is Al Tafar, a horrific battleground. The author does a wonderful job of giving us a great description of the city, of the death...of the bodies. He doesn't hold back on the brutality of the situation. I think what was happening to me as a reader, was that I felt the author was speaking SO loudly to me. It just was too much. Was I being too sensitive as I was reading the story? It is powerful. It is a graphic testament to the pain of war. Maybe we (who weren't present) needed to be shaken out of our ignorance and complacency. Although I didn't feel that was how I was about it - I protested it vehemently - but, in truth, I wasn't in the midst of it. I have no doubt this book was received well. It probably should be. It just was difficult for me for all that I shared. Side note: It was a great discussion group selection. For us...Lots of emotions, thoughts and opinions came out on the table that day. We kept it even keel - stable, balanced, as best as any facilitator could under the circumstances of the subject....more

review: I read this awhile ago. But to be honest, I didn't really finish the book, so if you choose not to read this , I am good with you walking away rI read this awhile ago. But to be honest, I didn't really finish the book, so if you choose not to read this , I am good with you walking away right now. Because that is what I did with this book. I will share what I recall. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.This is a story of the unraveling of a marriage - well one that was based on being together for 20 years - maybe not in law, but time. The story begins about domesticity and ends as a whodunit. Each chapter has alternating voices between Him and Her giving the readers dual perspectives on the couple's life together. Jodi, the "wife" is a psychotherapist. Todd, the "husband" is a real estate mogul. Todd is an adulterous creep. Sorry...I couldn't help myself - it was my best description, in the moment of this . Jodi is uncomplaining, a rather...well... silent wife. One of the lines in the book shares...She knows Todd is "a cheater, and he knows that she knows, but the point is that the pretense, the all-important pretense must be maintained, the illusion that everything is fine and nothing is the matter." Why does Jodi put up with this? Apparently there is something from her past that keeps her tied to him. No spoilers from me. Todd in turn has his own excuses for his bad behaviors. And it gets disgusting - his latest, he has known since she was a baby. Can it get any worse? Yes, they named their dog, Freud. Is this the point where I exit the book, left?The author died before publication. Still the darkness of this story, the explicit sexuality. It left me extremely uncomfortable. I did what I needed to do...I walked away from the book. ...more

title: The Invisible Bridge
author: Orringer, Julie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another Library Book Group selection. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Sometimes it is hard to go into another WWII holocaust story knowing whAnother Library Book Group selection. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Sometimes it is hard to go into another WWII holocaust story knowing what to expect. I was hesitant to read it, but, willing because I could appreciate a good discussion. And with WWII books about the holocaust, sometimes the books can showcase a new or different perspective – a part of history that hasn’t been told. It makes the story more palatable. The author’s central character, Andras Levi, is a promising student of architecture who leaves his native Hungary to study in Paris in the late 1930s — until his scholarship is revoked when anti-Jewish laws go into effect. As you might expect, the trials he and his wife and their extended families face will grow worse in the years to come.  Orringer provides another literary glimpse of the day-to-day horrors of that time, and also reminds us of the potential contributors to the postwar world – the architects and painters, the professionals and tradesmen – who were lost from this horrific war not just from battle but also from inhumane treatment. The strength of this story is her ability to make us care deeply about the people in her all-too-real fictional world. As horrific as this time period was, we can’t help but feel what the horrors were, and what was in store for the characters we grew to care about. This is what made this a great book discussion selection. ...more

review: I read this a while ago, and I'm now bringing my  to Goodreads. First, do you have Kleenex nearby? This is a YA novel. It deals with cancer.It dI read this a while ago, and I'm now bringing my  to Goodreads. First, do you have Kleenex nearby? This is a YA novel. It deals with cancer.It deals with young love.It deals with the hard realities of growing up fast when faced with a cancer diagnosis. We meet Hazel who is 16 with cancer who joins a support group. There she mets Augustus. They find comfort, love and hope with and through each other. As readers we learn about their inner struggles. We are let in through Hazel's story to the emotions brought on when having to face life and death discussions. The book helps readers to approach the topic of death with humor, dignity, grace and emotion. Even though parts of the story moved me to tears, I never felt it was morbid or depressing. I could appreciate the thoughtfulness of the love story. As readers, we can appreciate Augustus' (Gus) character as he is filled with vibrancy and life. He teaches Hazel how to be strong. Even though we only see his character through Hazel's eyes, he is someone who is impossible not to love. This is definitely a difficult topic, yet Green has done an amazingly wonderful job in using warmth and humor to tell this story. 4.5 stars...more

title: Defending Jacob
author: William Landay*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…This was a Library book discussion selection. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.For anyone looking for the perfect discussion book,Catching up…This was a Library book discussion selection. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.For anyone looking for the perfect discussion book, this one fits it. We are dealing with a suspenseful mystery, family and courtroom drama. The story opens amid a grand jury hearing with Andy Barber, a former assistant district attorney being grilled by Neal Logiudice. Neal happened to be Andy’s protégé at one time.The questions and concerns involve whether Andy should have been investigating the killing of a boy named Ben Rifkin. Why is this important? Because…The victim was a classmate of Jacob Barber, Andy’s 14-year-old son. What exactly are we implying here? This is where it gets interesting. Hold on…Because the author takes readers on an interesting ride between a legal thriller and an issue-oriented family breakdown. At times readers feel left in the dark, as much as Andy…As brilliant as he is as a prosecutor, how smart is he really about his son?Is he innocent or is he guilty?It seems that before the murder, Andy and his wife, Laurie, just didn’t seem to know much about their son. As suburban parents, they think they have done right by him. But…Jacob found Ben’s body. And…Ben was a bully, with Jacob as his frequent target. And…Apparently, Jacob’s classmates have found him a bit strange. The more his parents uncover, the more the story heats up. And…The more we as readers question Jacob’s innocence.And…When more is discovered with Jacob, the more the title of this book makes sense. The courtroom drama is spectacular. The author pays a great deal of attention to the legal and dramatic tactics, which makes readers feel as if we are actually in the courtroom. There is much to appreciate about the drama, family dynamics and mystery in this story, along with the opportunity for discussion.Also...There is an Apple Plus+ TV series based on this book. But..Don't count on it following the book verbatim. ...more

title: Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore        (Mr. Penumbra's 24-Hour Bookstore, #1)
author: Sloan, Robin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this year’s ago, but because I just read Sourdough by the same author, I felt it was time to bring this  to Goodreads. Review for SourdouI read this year’s ago, but because I just read Sourdough by the same author, I felt it was time to bring this  to Goodreads. Review for Sourdough here: https://www.goodreads.com//show...Of course, I was immediately attracted to the book because of its title. A bookstore. For any of you who have been following my s, I love books about books. Bookstores. Libraries. I am in love. So that starts me off on a good footing with the book. I am hopeful and ready to begin with a smile. Open the pages. Here we go.Premise: Clay Jannon, an unemployed Web designer, takes a job working the graveyard shift at a 24-hour bookstore, owned by the strange Mr. Penumbra. The store in itself is rather odd. It has two kinds of customers – random passers-by who stop in so rarely that Clay wonders how the store is able to stay open; and, a “community of people who orbit the store like strange moons…They arrive with algorithmic regularity. They never browse. They come wide-awake, completely sober and vibrating with need.” So, who are these customers?Well…These particular customers seem to borrow a mysterious set of books, which Clay has been warned not to read. Now, how can you tell someone “not to read” something. Of course, this is going to make him want to…read them, right?Not an easy task…because…They are written in code. So…He seeks the help of his roommate, his best friend, who also happens to be his romantic interest and a wiz at software, to help him unravel this code. She also happens to work for Google in data visualization. And what should happen…A greater mystery is stumbled upon. Mr. Penumbra has disappeared. And off they go to track him down.This is an enjoyable, warm, intelligent, plot with lots of philosophical questions about technology and books and the power that both contain. The prose maintains an engaging pace.The characters are quirky, and there are charming moments. And modern moments. It’s not a perfect book, it tries to be clever where it doesn’t need to be. But…If you can overlook that, it can be a joy to read....more

review: I read this years ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.The snow child. The question always was, is she real or is she imaginary? The authI read this years ago, and I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.The snow child. The question always was, is she real or is she imaginary? The author sets the tale in the wilderness of Alaska where a couple (Jack & Mabel) have relocated after the birth of a stillborn child. One evening after a playful snowball fight, Jack carves a girl out of snow. In the morning, the couple catches sight of a tiny child running among the pines. She is dressed in the snow girl's red hat and gloves. When she presses her nose in the window, her face is a mirror of the one Jack carved out of snow. Is she the daughter that Jack created in the snow the night before? Real? Imaginary? We are in the midst of magical realism here. When the couple visit with her, the world is beautiful and new and quiet. Is that something we long for? But then, as the story goes, the winter recedes, and so does the snow child. We feel the loss. About a third of the way through the book, the story lost a bit of its magic. It was as if the author had to find an ending. But, it just didn't fit. I wanted something more. Was I wrong to?...more

review: This one is about detective, Mike "Scorcher" Kennedy on the Murder Squad. He lives in Ireland around the time of the recession. He's called to investiThis one is about detective, Mike "Scorcher" Kennedy on the Murder Squad. He lives in Ireland around the time of the recession. He's called to investigate the murder of the Spain family. I have some issues with the author that deflect from my enjoyment of this story. They are:As part of this story, the author spends a lot of time sharing observations about murder and human behavior. Including the investigator's role in crime solving. Now, yes this can be interesting. But...These author's observations can also deflect from a reader's interest. It becomes overbearing and takes up too much space (in my opinion). It causes the novel to become too lengthy, and thus, in my case, I found myself needing to skip read, to get to the point of the story. Also, because of the author's writing style, some of the characters were flat. I noticed on several occasions where the author chose to cut off the dialogue with too many explanations about what was going on - in the mind - or the body of the character. We as readers could infer this on our own by the characters actions - if written in as part of the story, just fine. This style of writing was annoying. Anyway, other than that...Could this have been a good mystery? ...more

review: This is truly dog-love in every way. Can I just start off with Kleenex? Because, if I don’t, I won’t be honest with this . Enzo is a dog. And EnThis is truly dog-love in every way. Can I just start off with Kleenex? Because, if I don’t, I won’t be honest with this . Enzo is a dog. And Enzo is our narrator. And this book draws us in from the very beginning. His loveable and loyal nature kept me engaged throughout this story. And… Well, I couldn’t help but look over at my dogs every now and then and wonder what they were thinking about me – you know what I mean? Premise: Enzo belongs to aspiring race car driver Denny, his wife and young daughter. Enzo’s goal is to finish his life as a dog so that he can come back as a human and no longer rely on gestures to communicate. But in this life, he also has a purpose. To protect and support his family. And while he might be restricted to gestures, those gestures offer his family a lot more support than he may fully realize. It is a compelling story with an almighty twist. No spoilers from me. The story isn’t just about Enzo. It encompasses the human lives struck with joy, tragedy, failure, success, setbacks and ultimate triumph over adversity. It is also about life and death. And ultimately…It is a love story…To our 4-legged friends. Both heart-felt and heart-breaking. But… A must read....more

review: We read this for our library book discussion group during one summer years ago, and I kid you not, 40 people showed up to discuss it! What? I was amazWe read this for our library book discussion group during one summer years ago, and I kid you not, 40 people showed up to discuss it! What? I was amazed at how many adults were interested in this YA novel. There were some teens that came, but for the most part, the majority in the circle were adult women. Some men, but mostly women over 50. The discussion was filled with high energy and enthusiasm. I thoroughly enjoyed leading this discussion. The story is about 16 year old Katniss who lives with her mother and younger sister in a present-looking future in which 12 outlying districts send one boy and one girl to appear in an annual televised event called The Hunger Games at the Capitol. It is a fight to the death. And...it is on live TV. This way the public can cheer on their favorite players. How best to describe the book:Impressive world-building, breath-taking action and clear philosophical concerns (which were great for discussion)... besides the romantic moments, made for spell-binding reading and discussing experiences in this first edition of the trilogy....more

review: Catching Up…This was another Library Book Group selection. In France this was a critical and popular sensation. So, why not adopt Renee, the outwardlyCatching Up…This was another Library Book Group selection. In France this was a critical and popular sensation. So, why not adopt Renee, the outwardly plain concierge (hedgehog) of a swanky Parisian apartment block, as our discussion topic. She is secretly passionate, and self-taught, and spends time with Tolstoy or weeping over an Ozu film. For those who don’t know who Ozu is, think…Tokyo Story. (I know, I had to look it up, too!) Coincidentally…Another of the block’s inhabitants, 12-year-old Paloma is also a secret intellectual: alienated from her bourgeois family and precociously alert to the futility of her life. So much so, she has decided that her mission is to…Commit suicide on her 13th birthday. In the meantime…Paloma keeps a diary of “profound thoughts.” But then…Both lives are transformed by a new tenant, a retired Japanese businessman called Mr. Ozu. This story is…Moving, funny and triumphant, showing quiet victories of the inconspicuous among us. And it has…Quirky types of characters and a storyline that creates great opportunities for lively discussions....more

title: Hotel on the Corner of Bitter and Sweet
author: Ford, Jamie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching Up…Did you know that the Hotel actually existed? It is Seattle’s Panama Hotel, and in the novel, Henry Lee stands there as the book opens andCatching Up…Did you know that the Hotel actually existed? It is Seattle’s Panama Hotel, and in the novel, Henry Lee stands there as the book opens and he is remembering an old, doomed love. Premise: This hotel has been boarded up for over 40 years and the new owners have made a discovery. The basement is filled with the personal items of Japanese American residents who were sent to internment camps during WWII. The sight of a flowered parasol sends Henry back in time to 1942 and his experience during what he always refers to as the war years (always italicized). The story is told through Henry and his friend Keiko in 1942 and the story of Henry and his son in 1986 as Henry begins to share long hidden pieces of his past. What results is a story of a shameful period in American history and the resurrection of relationships based on this time of cultural significance and misunderstanding. By far the strongest part of Ford’s story is his ability to draw the reader into the life of young Henry as he navigates being a teen, prejudice and a world at war. As readers we can feel the national embarrassment that was the internment camps, the stoicism and loyalty of those sent away and the callous disregard with which their departure was greeted by their neighbors of all ethnicities. Seattle wasn’t just a country at war with the world, it was a city divided and at war with itself. The less convincing part of the story was Henry’s relationship with his son, tainted by the anger and resentment of the relationship Henry had with his own father. More detail went into the back story, and maybe that was for the better, because it was more interesting, and I found myself enjoying that part of the book more. Still…The story is strong. Characters feel real and believable, for the most part. Henry is a likable and complicated protagonist....more

title: One Good Dog
author: Wilson, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up.We read and discussed this in our Library Book Discussion group years ago. And…It gave me a different appreciation for pitbull dogs. But…ICatching up.We read and discussed this in our Library Book Discussion group years ago. And…It gave me a different appreciation for pitbull dogs. But…I have had a personal experience with one that I will share at the end of my  which changes things for me. Still…It doesn’t change how I feel about this book.Premise: This is the story of Chance, a pitbull puppy that was raised in a puppy mill and then turned over into the world of dog fighting. This is also the story of Adam a person who has destroyed his career and his marriage. Violence and uncertainty surround both of these two, which don’t make for a very good beginning. They both seem to be running away – Chance from the people who will put him in the pit to fight again and Adam from the hurts of his past. Then…Through some act of kindness, they come together. And…This becomes their story of how lives can change.The story was beautifully told. It was one where readers rooted for both Chance and Adam. Also…Readers could feel the pain and angst of the horrible life that was bestowed upon Chance. It definitely made me feel some compassion for his breed after reading this story. But…Our personal story, if interested…An incident occurred in our corgi dog, Oliver’s second year. We were in our off-leash training cycle, having a leisurely beach walk with our dogs. Now, understand, Oliver is a very friendly boy. He loves everybody – people, and dogs. So, when he saw this other dog, he wanted to greet him, and off he went, despite our cries of stop! We were beside ourselves, and my husband went running quickly after him, while I stayed with my other dogs. But…He wasn’t fast enough.When suddenly…The dog took Oliver in his jaws and began shaking him. The owner did nothing to stop his dog. My husband was still running frantically to stop and get Oliver from the clutches of his dog, before something tragic happened. When my husband, approached and asked for the owner to please help (please note this was all happening in fast-time), the owner splashed his beer in my husband’s face. Granted, at this point, my husband was rather frantic, and his voice was probably begging rather loudly asking him to please help, because the man just stood there belligerently while it was happening. (My husband sensed he was also drunk, which didn’t help the situation, either.)All my husband could do at this point, was try and distract the owner’s dog from Oliver so he would release him from his clutches, which he eventually did. The incident probably took about 15 seconds. But it felt like minutes!The owner did nothing but walk away from us with his dog, as we lifted our bleeding Oliver and rushed him back to our car and to emergency surgery. Yes, he was a pitbull. And… Thankfully, Oliver survived. He had deep puncture wounds to his neck and leg. And…Gratefully, Oliver is still a loving, happy-go-lucky guy who still loves people and other dogs. And yes, we take full responsibility for Oliver being off-leash, even though dogs could be, in this place. We were in training, and it was an awful situation that could have been prevented, if he were on leash. Unfortunately, we had no idea this would be the outcome. Since that incident, I have been somewhat reluctant to be around pitbulls, recognizing that even if their owners teach them right, there is still an internal instinct that dogs have, that cannot be ignored. I know sharing this incident is not part of the … But… It is part of my story. If interested, I have pictures of Oliver posted on my profile page. He is the blue merle, 4-year-old, cardigan corgi....more

title: The Lincoln Lawyer        (The Lincoln Lawyer, #1; Harry Bosch Universe, #16)
author: Connelly, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this long before it became a successful Netflix series. And Season 2 is just about to be released on July 6 (Part 1) and Part 2 is coming AugusI read this long before it became a successful Netflix series. And Season 2 is just about to be released on July 6 (Part 1) and Part 2 is coming August 3. So, those who have been fans, will also love Netflix’s interpretation, as well. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads.Believe it or not, this is Michael Connelly’s first legal thriller. And of course, he would choose to create a cynical defense attorney as his defining character and lead protagonist. Mickey Haller has spent his professional life afraid that he would not recognize innocence. He is a pro at defending criminals – out of the backseat of his Lincoln Town Car. And he doesn’t have many friends in cops, prosecutors, or even clients, at times. From bikers, to con artist to drunk drivers or even drug dealers, Mickey Haller doesn’t care – this is his client list. But one day he accepts a rich Beverly Hills bad boy as his client. This could be the paycheck he has been waiting for – especially when he believes this new client is innocent of the crime of brutally beating a woman. But an investigator is murdered when he gets too close to the truth, and Haller is realizing something isn’t quite right with this justice system. Even though Haller is handling some very shady characters, there is something about his character that we can appreciate as readers - he has an interest in coming to an honorable resolution that respects and upholds both the law and his morals. I also felt I was given good insight into the legal system with some behind the scenes information and how the justice system works and can be manipulated. I also love courtroom drama. So, I felt the courtroom scenes were very compelling showcasing some excellent legal strategy without being tedious. As is typical with any Connelly book, there were many twists, turns, surprises and tension. The action was fast paced and it captivated my attention throughout.I loved the character development and the plot flowed with steady builds. And, once pulled in it really was hard to put this one down. If it seemed like it was too tidy of an ending – (let’s shoot up the bad guys kinda deal) – maybe that is what was needed, to get to the truth. I am not one for looking for revenge as the best outcome, but I do like lawyers with a heart of gold, and Mickey Haller is one....more

review: This was another library book discussion selection that I enjoyed leading. The room in which we all sat to discuss it was overflowing. So many were exThis was another library book discussion selection that I enjoyed leading. The room in which we all sat to discuss it was overflowing. So many were excited to be present to discuss this one. The book was set in Jackson, Miss, and revolves around the life of 3 unforgettable women - Abilene, Manny and Miss Skeeter. The trio embarks on a dangerous journey to challenge the status quo and make the masses hear the voice of the often-unheard section of society. The author does not write with the sole purpose to capture the dark days as a maid, but really wants us to see the reality that people were facing in that day and time. (Unfortunately...It still feels so present, doesn't it?) We hear the story in the 3 women's narrative voices. The story is fast-moving and intriguing. It brings to life the racism that was (is?) prevalent in America at that time. This is definitely a woman's story, sharing about dark times that feel so real even now. (I know I keep saying that...but...)...more

review: We read and discussed this in our Library Book Discussion group. I am now bringing this  to Goodreads.Oscar prefers to do things his own way. HeWe read and discussed this in our Library Book Discussion group. I am now bringing this  to Goodreads.Oscar prefers to do things his own way. He has an appetite for books and is obsessed with non-mainstream films. Oscar is not exactly a lovable character. Yunior, who is the narrator, is pretty much everything that Oscar is not. While Oscar is socially inept, Yunior is a womanizer who romances and cheats on Oscar's sister. But, like Oscar, he still has some redeeming values, though as the reader, we need to be patient, to find them.The book group was inpatient with Oscar, at first. It took a while to warm up to the story. It was complex. But, we could all agree that the story was multilayered with commentaries on isolation, love, politics, and humanity. If readers can be patient with this book, we can allow ourselves to also be open to Oscar. 3.5 stars...more

title: Olive Kitteridge        (Olive Kitteridge, #1)
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this a while ago, and actually had the experience of discussing this in our Library Book Discussion group. I am now bringing my  to GoodrI read this a while ago, and actually had the experience of discussing this in our Library Book Discussion group. I am now bringing my  to Goodreads. Where do I begin with what has become the first in an Olive sighting series. I believe there are now at least 7 books now in which Olive makes an appearance! But let’s just begin here. Now typically I have issues with characters I don’t like. Because I like to connect and root for them. And if I can’t connect with them, it makes it really hard to get into the story. So, here is a perfect example of a character readers may not be friends with, but we can’t stop reading about…Olive Kitteridge. I know. She was really annoying, but I still couldn’t stop reading about her. Picture this. Olive is at her son’s wedding. What is she doing? She is looking through her new daughter-in-law’s closet. And she doesn’t stop there. She takes a magic marker and draws a black line down the arm of a beige sweater. What? No, she didn’t stop there either. She steals a bra and one loafer. She imagines her new daughter-in-law saying, “I must be losing my mind.” Would we even think of doing that to our daughter-in-law? Well…maybe? If we didn’t like her?In reality, we (or at least me) couldn’t wait to see what Olive was going to do next. What is happening to me here? Olive is as annoying as could be, and yet I am giddy as can be, watching who she is going to annoy in the next chapter. Small town in Maine. Ordinary people? Doing ordinary things? Secrets kept? Secrets told?What is Olive’s husband up to? The writing is epic. The story is vivid. A great discussion book. And even if Olive may annoy us (or is it just me?), we really care what happens to her. Whatever you decide...Start here. With Olive Kitteridge. It is a book that reminds you of why you love to read books....more

title: In the Neighborhood: The Search for Community on an American Street, One Sleepover at a Time
author: Lovenheim, Peter*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Catching up…This was another Cuesta College community read with the local libraries. So…It was inevitable that our Library Book Discussion group wouldCatching up…This was another Cuesta College community read with the local libraries. So…It was inevitable that our Library Book Discussion group would also discuss this. Interestingly…The most significant question became…How many of us, truly knew our neighbors?I recognized that living and working in my community as long as I did, I didn’t really know my neighbors that well. It wasn’t until I had opened up my Little Free Library Shed years later, and the pandemic hit, and the libraries were closed, that neighbors started coming more to my LFL. And…That made it possible for us to…Talk more to each other. Why did it take so long?Because we just were too busy with our lives, and working, and raising families. And…In most suburban neighborhoods, that is how life had become. Lovenheim’s quest to get to know his neighbors was a murder-suicide a few houses away. He wondered if a tragedy could have been prevented if the residents on Sandringham Road had known each other more closely. One of his ideas to get to know his neighbors was to institute a sleepover. You know…The kind of thing best known amongst kids, but now doing it amongst adults. Learning about each other’s families. Of course, not everyone was up for the idea. Still…He was curious. And…He continued to explore his neighborhood.And…As he did…He would find the professionals, and the one battling cancer. He even spends time getting to know the street’s mail carrier and the newspaper deliveryman. Each add perspective to how the neighborhood feels. There is also the “walker” in the neighborhood. What does she see on her daily walks? Why would she not like living there even though she admires the beautiful homes?And…Even though it may be an affluent neighborhood, the question becomes, does socio-economic status play a role in lack of neighborliness?Or…Are they just too busy, as well?And then…There are the dogs of the neighborhood. Of course. How can we not enjoy the special relationships they bring?The experience of reading such a book, allowed participants to truly appreciate the importance of neighborhoods, and a sense of community. And…Taking time to really find out about your neighbor. And just…Check in. We don’t always know what goes on behind closed doors. Who may need our help…or not. A book worth checking out. ...more
