title: I Have Some Questions for You
author: Makkai, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a successful podcaster, Bodie Kane has an opportunity to return to her boarding school, where she spent some awkward and depressing early years. ShAs a successful podcaster, Bodie Kane has an opportunity to return to her boarding school, where she spent some awkward and depressing early years. She will get to teach for a couple of weeks. Spend some time with good friends. But... There will be some difficult memories that will be upended – family tragedy, dejection, but most significantly the murder of her former roommate Thalia. Omar was convicted of her murder, but…so many are still convinced that he wasn’t the one who did it. What happens when Bodie’s memories of the events of this time in her life are challenged? This story is unquestionably dark. It is uncomfortable at times because it deals with issues we don’t always like to talk about like, racism, sexual abuse, grief, the nature of collective memory, privilege and the way humans want to be at the center of tragedy. Some short chapters make it easier to navigate. Still the novel is engaging. Readable. Twisty. Makkai is a phenomenal storyteller, for sure....more

title: Unsolved        (Invisible, #2)
author: Patterson, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Take a formulaic author and pair him up with a second author and you might have a page-turning twisted tale that sets a couple of FBI agents on the taTake a formulaic author and pair him up with a second author and you might have a page-turning twisted tale that sets a couple of FBI agents on the tail of a serial killer. The question is, will they be able to figure out in time who he or she is before it is too late, or he/she gets them first? I use to love James Patterson, and couldn’t wait to read anything he wrote into my hands. But then I found his stories carried the same formula and I grew bored – hence the term formulaic author. But then he started a trend – he began to team up with other authors to create storylines. This seemed to be his way to back away and give other authors a chance to make a name for themselves by letting them take the writing lead (it was my take on it), but also a process perhaps to move away from his formula story line. However, when it comes to this book, I’m not sure whether it succeeded. It felt like another old formula losing steam. Like a re-tell of a story we’ve read before – the characters we know (love and hate) – bad guys hidden among the good guys – the worst of the worst – and we as readers are racing through time, just like the main characters to capture him or her. Of course, let the authors throw in a side story to complicate things, too. I’m just not sure adding a second author is going to save James Patterson any longer. What do you think? Am I being too harsh?...more

review: How lucky is anyone to have friends and mates in fifty states? As it so happens, that is exactly what gets to happen for Willie, Normie, Mickey, SusieHow lucky is anyone to have friends and mates in fifty states? As it so happens, that is exactly what gets to happen for Willie, Normie, Mickey, Susie and Ellie. Readers get to wander through the west with Willie, and nose into the north with Normie, while meandering through the Midwest with Mickey, and see the south with Susie and explore the east with Ellie. And each time we learn a little something new about each state as each one takes us through. Now, of course, those of us who live in different states, might know a little bit more about the states they visit, and it is always fun to see what they have to say when they come to our state. As an example, when Willie wandered into my state of California, I loved that it mentioned how many activities are done along the coast, since the state is right along the Pacific Ocean. I have to say, it is an enjoyable adventure to see kids having the opportunity to “travel” throughout the United States through the book and learn in this way. author: Hoffman, Alice*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is interesting that the books came out backwards – first Practical Magic, then, The Rules of Magic, and now, Magic Lessons. So, if you haven’t readIt is interesting that the books came out backwards – first Practical Magic, then, The Rules of Magic, and now, Magic Lessons. So, if you haven’t read any of these books, I would recommend you start from the beginning…Magic Lessons, Practical Magic and then The Rules of Magic. And then of course, go watch the 1998 movie, Practical Magic with Sandra Bullock, Nicole Kidman and Stockard Channing to name a few amazing actors! On to the  of this magical prequel…Alice Hoffman has a way of weaving of story. And for those of us who have been following this series, we finally get some closure. Who was Maria Owens really? Now we are finally introduced to her. Maria Owens is a woman whose legend has been well known to those of us who loved “Practical Magic” and “The Rules of Magic.” In “Magic Lessons,” - we finally learn of her story. This is a book about magic, about family, about love, about injustice and about history. And history is told as far back as the 1600’s – witches, how people felt about it at that time, et al. I was spellbound by this book. Forgive my use of words! ;) Hoffman is a gifted storyteller, and reading these pages I found this book to be captivating, endearing and riveting. I don’t need to go into the actual story per say, because I think that is for you as the reader to discover on your own. I will tell you this…I believe, it is worth your time....more

title: White Houses
author: Bloom, Amy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We all knew that Franklin had extramarital affairs. But what did we really know about Eleanor? This book professes to be a hidden chapter in FDR's WhiWe all knew that Franklin had extramarital affairs. But what did we really know about Eleanor? This book professes to be a hidden chapter in FDR's White House. As a historical fiction novel, White Houses by Amy Bloom explores what really could have happened behind closed doors between Eleanor Roosevelt, First Lady, and her "friend" Lorena Hickok. Thousands of letters, preserved at Hyde Park, attest to their passionate connection, and historians now are certain their relationship was physical. (In 2016, the two women were the subject of the non-fiction book Eleanor and Hick: The Love Affair That Shaped a First Lady by Susan Quinn, which expanded on revelations in Blanche Wiesen Cook’s 1999 biography of Eleanor.) Bloom convincingly weaves tender romance with hard-boiled reality. At its heart, however, White Houses feels true. In an afterword, Bloom notes that the White House staff routinely cropped Hickok out of photos. In White Houses, she’s in the center of the frame, and nobody who reads this sad, funny, frisky novel is going to forget her....more

title: Bachelor Nation: Inside the World of America's Favorite Guilty Pleasure
author: Kaufman, Amy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do you have a guilty pleasure? Well I am about to reveal what was once mine. Please don’t think less of me. Sometimes we need an escape and surprisingDo you have a guilty pleasure? Well I am about to reveal what was once mine. Please don’t think less of me. Sometimes we need an escape and surprisingly this became mine a few years back when I happened upon a spoiler article about Jason Mesnick's season by RealitySteve.com. How could people let themselves into this world, I wondered? Now I know. It really is because of RealitySteve.com’s spoilers each season, that I am able to keep myself engaged with this crazy show/franchise. So when I became aware of this book through Reality Steve’s podcast, I had to read it. Amy Kaufman did her homework well, and made this a truly entertaining read! Amy Kaufman's unauthorized, behind-the-scenes tell all book lets us in on the ridiculous world of the Bachelor Nation that manufactures those tears for our entertainment. The iconic reality television show's reach and influence is undeniable. Bestselling writers and famous actors live tweet about it. Die-hard fans--dubbed "Bachelor Nation"--come together every week during each season to participate in fantasy leagues and viewing parties. If you think about it you can only conclude that The Bachelor franchise is a stage - one in which we viewers sit back and watch wondering what train wreck will occur next. Kaufman also explores what our fascination means, culturally: what the show says about the way we view so-called ideal suitors, our subconscious yearning for fairy-tale romance, and how this enduring television show has shaped society's feelings about love, marriage, and feminism.Former basketball great Kareem Abdul-Jabbar suggested that the book contained "all the dirty secrets about how the sausage is made. It doesn't make the sausage any less delicious or addicting, but it does, if you think about it too much, roil the stomach." What I came to realize and understand was that People love to hate-watch The Bachelor. I guess that described me as well. Now I just read the spoilers. But, this book, is worth a read....more

As a reader you are intrigued, you want to know what happened, how it happened, why it happened, and will there be some justice. Mostly, what is the truth? And, do readers get your answers at the end? Scott Turow is an excellent storyteller. He has made his reputation on his ability to meld deep character study with court procedure and a twisted plot. title: The Bright Hour: A Memoir of Living and Dying
author: Riggs, Nina
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Our Library Book Discussion group read two phenomenal books over a period of several months. The first book, Being Mortal by Atul Gawande shared how tOur Library Book Discussion group read two phenomenal books over a period of several months. The first book, Being Mortal by Atul Gawande shared how to distill what matters most to each of us in life in order to navigate our way toward the edge of it in a meaningful and satisfying way. The second book, When Breath Becomes Air by Paul Kalanithi shares not only his story, but also his ideas on how to approach death with grace and what it means to be fully alive. You would think that each of these stories would be depressing, but in fact, they are not. Thus, those reading experiences led me to read this third book (not discussed in our book discussion group). The New York Times Book Review of this book..."You can read a multitude of books about how to die, but Riggs, a dying woman, will show you how to live." Her story asks: 'what makes a meaningful life when one has limited time?' What makes a meaningful life even if you don't have a terminal illness? No matter what may be happening in our life today....this is a great opportunity to learn or be reminded about the joys of living in the present moment....living in the NOW.And this book reminds of how precious our lives truly are. ...more

review: Paul Newman was tired of the tabloid depictions of his life. He wanted to tell his life story in his own way. So that is what he set out to do with thPaul Newman was tired of the tabloid depictions of his life. He wanted to tell his life story in his own way. So that is what he set out to do with the help of his long-time friend and collaborator, Stewart Stern. His intention was to bare his soul and be real in ways that expose his truth – his life, and thus he could feel right that he left his story the way he needed it to be said. Mostly for his children. And then for those who cared to read it, too. And in this way, we would learn about the man, the actor, his flaws, his imperfections, and the realness of him. As well as all the people that surrounded his life. And many had something to say, who also shared commentary throughout his story. This was a painstaking collaboration that took his recorded conversations, and translated them into a well-coordinated readable, reasonable sized book. review: For anyone who has followed this series, it is almost like being at home with the characters. You feel like you know them. The relationships ups and downs. The Ruth Galloway series is a different sort of police procedural with forensic archaeology, because Ruth (our main protagonist) is an archaeologist. She is an academic who is now head of her university department. She has been consulting with the police whenever bones are found. She also has an “interesting” relationship with officer, DCI Nelson – who also happens to be her daughter’s father, another major character. Ruth has also written successful books and made television appearances. In this book, we see not only another cold case that needs to be addressed, but the possibility of Ruth’s department being closed down, and some resolution with her relationship with Nelson (considering he has been married on and off with his wife Michelle). What makes this book even more “emotional” for us die-hard followers, is understanding that the author has intended that this book, “The Last Remains” is to be the last in her series of Ruth Galloway mysteries. Which means, walking in to it, we already know that whatever happens to the characters that we have been reading through the years…this will be the last time we will probably be turning these pages for – so whatever happens, we can only hope –– 1) she doesn’t kill them off,2) she won’t give them an unhappy ending, Or… 3) she provides us readers with something we can be satisfied with for each of the characters. I do believe, the author does justice, furthering the stories not only of Ruth and Nelson, but also Kate, Cathbad, Judy, Cloughie, Tanya…and even a surprise character from an earlier story (Kleenex, may be needed). But, I won’t tell you how. I think as readers, that is your adventure to enjoy. Regardless of the case, we can appreciate that it was a very satisfying finale indeed. Enjoy....more

review: Alex’s family is killed by an intruder and she escapes – but does she really? Especially when she is accused of their grizzly murder. And then she getAlex’s family is killed by an intruder and she escapes – but does she really? Especially when she is accused of their grizzly murder. And then she gets off, but for years she has to dodge the accusations. She begins a new life – but she still searches wondering who killed her family and why. The law firm who helped her win a lawsuit against the police department who botched the case against her now continues to protect her, and employ her as an investigator. A new case seems to lead her back to her own family murder. What does everything have in common? This exciting, twisty page turner will keep you up until the last page – and I mean, literally the last page....more
